ESG_HEADLINE: Increased exposure to carbon-related risks
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Power Asset Holdings (PAH) has been downgraded to 'BBB' from 'A'. The recent reassessment of the company indicated a decline in its ESG performance relative to its ESG industry peers, driving the downgrade. Further, our revised methodology has resulted in a higher carbon emission exposure score for natural gas power generation (11.4% of FY 2021 operations) and electric transmission and distribution (~49% of FY 2021 operations) segments, contributing to the downgrade.The company pledged to phase out coal power generation by 2035 (~41% of total installed capacity in 2021) through coal-to-gas conversion. We note new climate targets by some of its business units. The company blends hydrogen into gas distribution networks and aims to replace natural gas with hydrogen. Also, UKPN and SAPN, two electricity transmission and distribution units, adopt voltage management technologies to prepare the networks for renewables.The company continues to trail most global peers on corporate governance, notably in board structure. That said, we note no significant votes against directors at the 2022 AGM; this may indicate improved shareholder satisfaction.With a relatively diversified asset portfolio, compared to pure thermal power generators, the company has moderate exposure to risks tied to toxic releases. Recent disclosures indicate regular external audits of and ISO 14001 certifications for select operations, which may help manage the related issue.

DIC's rating is unchanged at 'A'. The company continues to lead industry peers in implementing strong carbon mitigation practices. DIC has a target to become carbon neutral by 2050. Further, its FY 2021 carbon emissions intensity of 77 tCO2e/USD million was significantly lower than the average (310) for the specialty chemicals sub-industry (constituents of the MSCI ACWI Index), as of August 2022. On the other hand, it lags peers in adopting strong chemical safety management practices.The toxic emissions intensive nature of manufacturing printing ink and paints exposes DIC to the risk of incurring potential environmental liabilities. Our research indicates 79% of its facilities are certified to the ISO 14001 standard . Further, DIC's VOC emission intensity decreased by a compound annual rate of 24% between 2017 to 2020.DIC derived 45% of its FY 2021 revenue from Japan and the US, where chemical safety regulations are stringent. It is thus exposed to potential reformulation costs. While we note the company undertakes reformulation of specific products, it appears to lack a formal plan to phase out all hazardous chemicals from its operations, unlike better-performing peers.Enhanced executive pay disclosures have contributed positively to the company's corporate governance score, which remains average compared with those of global peers. Further, while DIC has policies providing whistleblowers protection from retaliation, the company appears to lack provisions for audits of its ethics practices.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improvements in governance, but weaknesses in board structures persist; above-par talent management
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Otsuka has been upgraded to 'A' from 'BBB'. The Whistleblower Protection Key Metric under the Business Ethics Key Issue was modified. Otsuka has disclosed a policy that provides whistleblowers with protection from retaliation, which contributed to the upgrade. Also, unlike the case in our previous assessment (Nov. 26, 2021), we note the presence of an independent pay committee; this may help provide independent oversight of executive pay practices. Further, Otsuka's talent management programs continue to lead those of industry peers.Strong competition for skilled talent in the IT consulting industry exposes Otsuka to potential talent management complexity. Nonetheless, our research suggests it has industry-leading practices such as annual engagement surveys and graduate internship programs that may help recruit and retain talent. Further, Otsuka's attrition rate at 4.8% for 2018-20 was lower than the industry average of 13% (as of June 2022).Like leading peers, Otsuka appears to capitalize well on the growing demand for clean technology solutions, mainly through its digital transformation offerings, which facilitate optimization of clients' processes.Despite improvements, Otsuka still lags most global peers on corporate governance. This is because its board lacks an independent majority, and is potentially entrenched (5 of 10 directors have served over 15 years: March 2022). Also, it is led by a combined CEO/chair. Such structures may impede management oversight. Further, limited executive pay disclosures may impede peer comparison.

ESG_HEADLINE: Diverse business reduces exposure to risks tied to corruption and gambling addiction
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Aristocrat's rating is unchanged at 'AA'. Aristocrat is a gambling machine manufacturer (2021: 48% of revenue) and developer of social casual games where there is no real prize money involved (2021: 52%). The company's diverse businesses result in lower exposure to risks tied to corruption and gambling addiction than for pureplay gambling operators. Aristocrat leads most global peers on corporate governance, while it is on par with global peers in business ethics. Its responsible gaming programs are also on par with those of peers.Five of seven directors were independent of management as of June 2022, including the chair; these features are associated with strong management oversight. Also, Aristocrat's policy against corruption is reinforced by a whistleblower system. However, there is limited information on controls against money laundering.Aristocrat's gambling machines have features, such as pre-commitment and time limits, to mitigate risks tied to addiction. In 2021, the company initiated a trial of a digital wallet product for cashless gambling in Australia. While the wallet reportedly includes self-limit options, we note the convenience the technology brings--to access funds--may present risks for problem gamblers.Aristocrat's mobile games and its trials for cashless gambling may pose cybersecurity challenges as these collect personal data. The company is on par with peers in mitigating the risks. It conducts annual audits and penetration tests to assess security of its systems.

IVA_INDUSTRY: Oil & Gas Refining, Marketing, Transportation & Storage
ESG_HEADLINE: Robust R&D in cleantech ventures may help foster low-carbon footprint
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Idemitsu Kosan's rating is unchanged at 'AA'. Idemitsu primarily engages in petroleum refining and chemical manufacturing (75% operations FY 2021), and has a growing presence in renewable energy generation. Despite the limited opportunities to expand its business in the clean technology (cleantech) arena, its R&D efforts continue to lead those of its refining peers. However, Idemitsu's strategies in minimizing the carbon footprint and toxic effluents of its operations remain average compared to those of peers.In FY 2021, Idemitsu grew its generation capacity by 25% YoY to 1.8 GW, where renewable energy such as solar, biomass, wind, and geothermal accounted for 39% of the power mix. Further, it has increased R&D expenditures by 6% CAGR (2019-21), with its three-year R&D/sales average of 0.38 outperforming industry average (0.17) as of August 2022.Most of Idemitsu's operations are based in Japan (84% FY 2021) where carbon regulations are becoming stringent, based on our model. This may further expose the company to risks of additional compliance costs tied to carbon emissions. In line with its net-zero target by 2050, however, its three-year (2018-20) GHG intensity of 251.7 mtCO2e/mUSD was lower than the industry average of 267 as of August 2022.Idemitsu's operations pose lower risk of workplace incidents than those of pure-play refining peers. We note an ongoing scrutiny over a fire that injured an employee at the Kawasaki Refinery in January 2020. Unlike with leading peers, we found that limited work sites were certified to ISO 45001.

Toyo Tire has been upgraded to 'BBB' from 'BB'. As of January 2022, Toyo Tire is no longer flagged for controversies over alleged falsification of product performance data (during 1999-2015), driving the upgrade. It appears on par with peers on quality control, with plants certified to ISO 9001 standards; this may help preempt product quality lapses. Also, we note strong initiatives to mitigate risks related to environmental regulations and preempt corruption. Meanwhile, its corporate governance structures appear to be weak.Tire manufacturers face risks related to release of toxic gases and hazardous waste. Our research indicates Toyo Tire has strong initiatives to mitigate such risks: most of its plants are certified to ISO 14001 standards, and it undertakes regular environmental audits.Toyo Tire's relatively small workforce (11,258 vs. industry average of 100,711, as of December 2021), and operations in Japan and Malaysia (FY 2020: 56% of assets), where incidence of labor unrest has historically been low, limits labor complexity. Nonetheless, the company offers equity grants, and benefits such as health and welfare schemes; this may help boost morale and productivity.Toyo Tire leads industry peers in business ethics; notable practices include executive oversight and a formal anti-corruption policy. However, its board lacks an independent majority; this may limit objective management oversight. Further, limited disclosures on executive pay, together with the CEO serving as chair of the pay committee, may not align with investor interests.

Nippon Sheet Glass has been downgraded to 'BBB' from 'A'. Our research did not find detailed disclosures on Nippon Sheet Glass' (NSG) executive pay (as of July 2022); this limits assessment of such practices and results in a lower score than global peers, thus, driving the downgrade.  Further, at the 2022 AGM, three of the eight directors (2019: two out of nine) received withheld shareholder votes (more than 10%); this may indicate shareholder dissatisfaction with their performance.Typically energy-intensive glass manufacturing operations expose NSG to risks associated with increased compliance costs tied to carbon emission regulations. The company's carbon emission performance trails those of peers. Our research indicates a consistent Y-o-Y increase in NSG's GHG emissions intensity (metric tons CO2e/USD million sales) from 669.3 (FY 2017) to 784.7 (FY 2020).Based on our model, NSG has high exposure to risks of environmental liabilities tied to potential toxic emissions and waste generation in the supply chain. While we note its practices to mitigate risks tied to potential toxic releases are average relative to those of peers, the company appears to lack an environmental management system certified to ISO 14001 for all its operations.As a glass manufacturer, NSG has high exposure to risks of workplace injuries. The company leads most peers on health and safety initiatives, with a health and safety policy that extends to contractors, and targets to reduce injury rates by 20% from FY 2020 to FY 2024.

Dowa Holdings' rating is unchanged at 'A'. The company continues to lead global peers in business ethics framework. It has a detailed anti-corruption policy, backed by employee trainings on ethics. it also provides protection to whistleblowers from retaliation. It leads industry peers in mitigating carbon emissions: its average GHG emission intensity (2018-20; tCO2e/USD million) of 279 was lower than the industry average 846 (Q3 2022). The company however, trails peers in mitigating risks tied to toxic pollutants and wastes.The company has 80% assets in Japan (FY 2021), where our research indicates incidence of labor unrest has been historically low. Like leading peers, it offers a range on non-statutory benefits and employee stock ownership plans. Also, the presence of trade unions covering 31% employees FY 2021 may suggest commitment to protect labor rights.Dowa Holdings' corporate governance practices are average compared to those of Japanese peers. Though it lacks a majority independent board and an independent chair, it has a fully independent pay committee. Also, it follows the 'one share one vote' principle which aligns shareholders' economic rights with voting power.Metal smelting operations could expose the company to risks of environmental liabilities due to potential pollution and wastes. Its FY 2020 NOx and SOx emissions intensities of 0.08 and 0.03 (t/USD million) respectively were lower than the industry averages of 0.42 and 4.54. However, unlike leading peers it seems to lack quantitative pollution reduction targets.

We initiate coverage of Zensun Enterprises at 'B'. Zensun Enterprises is a property developer with its portfolio located in China. Our research indicates the company trails peers in adopting strong initiatives to mitigate occupational safety-related risks. Amid China's anti-corruption campaign, Zensun Enterprises lags home market peers in instituting strong business ethics practices. Further, its investment programs to capitalize on the growing demand for sustainable properties lag those of leading local market peers.Property developers may face operational disruptions in the event of workplace accidents. Yet, Zensun Enterprises does not appear to disclose its employee and contractor safety performance, or to set targets to improve performance, unlike leading peers.The company trail peers on corporate governance practices. Two directors of its six-member board are executives, and one holds both the CEO and chairman roles. Such a structure may result in a strong management influence on the board. Further, the presence of related-party transactions with a family firm director could create potential for board-level conflicts of interest, and undermine minority shareholder interests.China's 14th Five-Year Plan (2021-2025) brings an industry-wide trend of urban renewal, thus presenting Zensun Enterprises with opportunities in green development. While the company adopts market-standard water and energy management initiatives, we found no evidence of green building certifications for its property portfolio, placing the company behind peers.

ESG_HEADLINE: Lags global peers on corporate governance; subpar e-waste and mineral sourcing practices
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Bajaj Electricals' rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. Bajaj Electricals continues to lag most global peers on governance. The promoter group, Bajaj held 63% of voting rights as of September 2022, and has board representation--the chair is a former CEO and serves alongside the current CEO. This, combined with the lack of a majority independent board, may undermine minority investor interests. On business ethics, it does not appear to undertake anti-corruption audits. The company trails peers in responsible mineral sourcing programs.Bajaj Electricals' household electric products could contain minerals in their components that could be sourced from conflict regions; this exposes the company to reputational risks. Yet, the company does not appear to implement mineral sourcing policies or vendor due diligence that could help restrict procurement from conflict-prone regions.Bajaj Electricals operates mainly in India (FY 2021: ~97% revenue), where e-waste management regulations are evolving; this suggests moderate exposure to related regulatory risks. However, we found no evidence of leading practices such as take-back initiatives or e-waste recycling targets.Bajaj Electricals outsources the bulk of its manufacturing to third-party suppliers. This exposes it to potential operational delays in case of labor disruption in the supply chain. While the company maintains vendor policies on safety and human rights, it seems to lack regular supplier audits to monitor compliance to vendor code of conduct and provisions of action plans in case of non-compliance.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improved cybersecurity and talent management practices drive upgrade
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: BFL has been upgraded to 'A' from 'BBB'. BFL has been upgraded to 'A' from 'BBB'. Improvements in BFL's cybersecurity practices and human capital management programs contribute to the upgrade. The company has adopted data encryption techniques and has ISO 27001 certification--practices that may help mitigate the risk of cyber threats. It has also exhibited strong efforts to attract and retain talent.As a consumer finance company, BFL relies on highly skilled staff. The company actively develops new pools of talent through its campus program. Also, it has established a robust grievance redressal mechanism for employees to express complaints anonymously.BFL continues to lead its industry peers on Access to Finance initiatives. It operates through more than 110,300 distribution points across India. As of FY 2021, rural financing contributed to 9.6% of BFL's consolidated assets under management.BFL continues to lag its industry peers on the Governance assessment. The board lacks independent majority, and was overboarded as of March 2022, with 30% of non-executive directors sitting on four boards. These may limit the board's ability to provide oversight of management. Moreover, we found limited evidence of anti-corruption policies.

Blue Star's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. Blue Star's safety performance is on par with that of leading peers. Evidence indicates strong workplace health and safety programs. In 2020, its lost time incident frequency rate was 0.03 per million hours (vs. industry average of 1.68, as of December 2021). The inclusion of the Corporate Behavior Theme in the Governance assessment indicates weaknesses in Blue Star's business ethics policies and practices. It faces controversy in India over alleged misleading advertisements (December 2020).Blue Star has a small workforce (2020: 2,621) relative to the industry average (December 2021: 37,497); this may lower its labor complexities. Our research indicates its labor management initiatives are on par with those of industry peers, and its policies are generally in line with international labor conventions.Blue Star's environmental programs include those on energy conservation, water management, and waste reduction. However, we found limited information on its environmental management system, targets, and annual performance monitoring to reduce carbon emissions and toxic wastes from its operations.Blue Star's business segments, which include residential and industrial air conditioning products, present opportunities to develop cleaner technologies from the existing product lines, and capitalize on the increasing demand for energy-efficient products. However, the company lags industry peers on R&D investment: its three-year average R&D expense-to-sales ratio (2018-2020) was 0.84% (vs. 2.32%: December 2021 industry average).

We re-initiate coverage of Cosco Shipping International at 'BB'. In 2022, Cosco Shipping International's ESG Industry was changed from Marine Ports & Services to Trading Companies & Distributors, where companies face more comparable ESG-related risks. It has high exposure to potential reformulation costs and stringent chemical safety regulations owing to the coatings production business (FY 2020: 32% revenue). While it offers tin-free coating products with material safety data sheets, we found no evidence of a formal plan to phase out hazardous chemicals.The company trails global and home-market peers on corporate governance. As a state-owned entity (July 2022: 68.6% voting power), Cosco Shipping International has 3 board directors (of 6) who are state representatives; this may pose risk of government intervention in management. We also note entrenchment risk, with 3 of the 6 directors serving over 15 years and aged more than 70 as of April 2022.  Further, the company has recurring related-party transactions with the state that accounted for 51.6% of FY 2021 revenue.Similar to peers, the company has moderate exposure to risks related to health and safety. Cosco Shipping International has health and safety policies reinforced with audits, and secured certification to the ISO 45001 standard for its operations in 2021. As of 2021, Cosco Shipping International recorded  zero work-related fatalities.

ESG_HEADLINE: Weaknesses in corporate governance structure; high business ethics risk exposure
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: China Railway Group's rating is unchanged at 'B'. We note weaknesses in China Railway Group's corporate governance structure. It is a controlled company, with the government holding 47.2% of voting rights through the stated-owned China Railway Engineering Corporation. Our research indicates related-party transactions (RPT) with the controlling shareholder in FY 2021; this along the absence of a fully independent audit committee to oversee such transactions may increase potential governance risks associated with RPTs for minority investors.As a state-owned entity, the company may face increased scrutiny of its business ethics practices. It has adopted executive oversight of ethics standards and policies against bribery and corruption. However, we found no evidence of strong practices such as whistleblower protection.The company's three-year R&D/sales ratio of 2.5% (FY 2019-2021) was higher than industry average (1.1% as of March 2022), which could indicate better innovation capacity relative to peers. However, we found no evidence of targets to increase investments in clean technologies.The company primarily operates in China, where rates of industrial injuries are high, as per ILO data. This, and its heavy construction business line may expose it to higher occupational health and safety (H&S) risks. While its H&S policy is overseen at the executive level and H&S performance is linked to executive pay, it appears to lack strong practices such as detailed incident reduction targets.

ESG_HEADLINE: Leading governance practices; maintains focus on environmental and safety management
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Lendlease's rating is unchanged at 'AAA'. Lendlease continues to lead most global peers on corporate governance practices with an independent board majority and fully independent nomination, audit, and pay committees for strong management oversight. Also, the company's business ethics practices lead those of most global peers, featuring a whistleblower system which provides anonymity and protection against retaliation. Further, the company maintains industry-leading practices for health and safety as well as environmental management.Occupational hazards are common in property development (45% of Lendlease's operations in 2021). This could expose the company to operational risks in case of safety incidents. Like leading peers, the company has adopted robust health and safety initiatives, including a groupwide policy that includes contractors, board-level oversight, and regular audits.Lendlease's portfolio is primarily located in Australia (56% of operations in 2021), where the demand for green buildings is high, offering opportunities in sustainable property investment. The company leads peers on related initiatives, like green leases, which may support its goal of net zero carbon by 2025.We have revised our evaluation of exposure to product safety and quality risks by removing a company-specific component based on the size of operations, resulting in a decrease in Lendlease's overall risk exposure. However, unlike with leading peers, we continue to find no evidence of certification to external quality standards such as ISO 9001.

Coromandel has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'B'. The company demonstrates strong water withdrawal performance relative to industry peers, driving the upgrade. Coromandel's withdrawal intensity of 2,290 m3/USD million in FY 2020 was much lower than the fertilizers and agricultural chemicals sub-industry average of 19,801, as of January 2022. However, the company does not seem to have robust programs to manage risks tied to water scarcity associated with its operations in India (100% in FY 2020), a country with high water stress level.With operations in India, where chemical regulations are less stringent than in the developed markets, Coromandel's exposure to related compliance risks is low. While we found evidence of a hazard risk assessment process, the company trails peers in phasing out hazardous chemicals.Fertilizer and pesticide manufacturers generally have high exposure to risks of incurring environmental liabilities related to toxic emissions and waste. Unlike industry peers, Coromandel's programs to mitigate key air pollutants (NOx/SOx) seem limited: it appears to lack quantitative targets to reduce emissions.Coromandel trails global peers in governance practices. The presence of related-party transactions with its controlling owner (the promoter group held 57.6% of voting rights, as of January 2022), without a fully independent audit committee oversight, could pose governance risks for minority shareholders. The company does not appear to have robust compliance practices (i.e., regular audits) to preempt potential corruption risks.

ESG_HEADLINE: Perceived gaps in construction quality control and green building investment frameworks
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Daito Trust Construction has been upgraded to 'BBB' from 'BB'. The upgrade is mainly driven by improved corporate governance practices. We found evidence of detailed executive pay disclosure as well as unwinding of all cross-shareholdings, which resolved complex stock ownership. The conclusion of controversy regarding alleged improper pass-on of consumption tax to property owners following the refunds paid to affected customers in 2020 also contributed to the upgrade. However, the company still trails peers in adopting strong construction quality practices.Daito Trust Construction operates in Japan, where the government has set a target for all new houses to be 'zero-energy' by 2030. This presents opportunities to capitalize on the demand for sustainable properties. The company has adopted various decarbonization initiatives, such as shifting to 100% renewable energy by 2040 and active promotion of cross-laminated timber (CLT) housing. However, the company lags leading peers in certifying properties to green building standards and in adopting tenant engagement programs to encourage responsible use of energy and water sources.The company's operations are mainly based in locations such as Japan (86%: FY 2020), where International Labour Organization data indicates historically low injury rates, and thus has low exposure to risks related to worksite safety. While the company's groupwide safety policy is supervised by an executive committee, it lags leading peers in obtaining safety certifications and in setting safety improvement targets.

IVA_INDUSTRY: Oil & Gas Refining, Marketing, Transportation & Storage
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Bangchak Corporation's rating is unchanged at 'AA'. We note improvements in the company's carbon emissions management. In addition to a net-zero emissions target for 2050, Bangchak Corporation aims to reduce GHG emissions through energy-efficiency improvement projects (e.g., reusing waste heat in crude oil distillation, improving heat exchangers, and reducing steam use) by 30% by 2030 (vs. 2021 levels). While its health and safety performance is in line with that of peers, contractor LTIR and TRIR have increased in the three years through 2021.Bangchak Corporation's biodiesel and petroleum refining operations (FY 2021: 40%) have lower exposure to risks of increased compliance costs tied to carbon emissions regulations than its oil and gas extraction operations (FY 2021: 22%). The company's GHG emission intensity averaged 176 tCO2e/USD million (2019-21), lower than the industry average of 314 as of December 2022.Our model suggests Bangchak Corporation operates primarily in countries with low employee fatality rates (FY 2021: 75% operations in Thailand, Norway, and Japan). While the company maintains its zero-fatality record since 2014, its contractor LTIR and TRIR increased at a CAGR of 6% and 23%, respectively, over 2019-21.Our model suggests Bangchak Corporation has high exposure to corruption risks, notably due to touchpoints with state officials to secure permits and its status as a state-owned entity (39% by the Thai government as of FY 2021). However, the company's policy against bribery does not appear to extend to all suppliers, unlike those of leading peers.

ESG_HEADLINE: Subpar labor management programs and limited e-waste initiatives
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Skyworth's rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. Like most domestic consumer electronics manufacturers in China, Skyworth has vertically integrated operations. Its operations primarily rely on in-house production, and may thus expose it to risks of work disruptions and reduced staff productivity. However, our assessment indicates Skyworth lags peers in providing strong labor management initiatives. Further, while the company faces risk of compliance costs related to e-waste, its management program appears to trail that of industry peers.Skyworth's operations are primarily in China (95% of total assets in 2020), where ILO data suggests moderate risk of labor unrest. While we found evidence of employee stock option plan to help retain staff, it appears to lack a variable pay scheme to boost productivity and trade unions to help safeguard benefits of workforce.In 2020, Skyworth derived entire revenue from countries such as China, which has stringent regulations on managing e-waste. This exposes the company to high risk of penalty related to disposal of end-of-life electronic products. Yet, we found limited evidence of efforts such as take-back systems or recycling programs, to mitigate such risks.We have flagged Skyworth's board for leadership concern because the executive chair and the CEO are representatives of the controlling shareholder; this could create potential for conflicts of interest. Also, we note the presence of an overboarded non-executive director as of December 2020; this may impact his ability to effectively perform his duty on Skyworth's board.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improvements in overall governance framework and pollution management
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Shanghai Electric has been upgraded to 'A' from 'BBB'. Shanghai Electric now leads most home market peers on corporate governance (as of October 2022). The removal of the key metrics derived from accounting ratios (Revenue Recognition, Expense Recognition, and Asset-Liability Valuation) in the Governance assessment is a key contributor to the upgrade due to the company's low accounting risk compared with global peers. Further, we found evidence of whistleblower protection from retaliation; this may help preempt potential unethical business conduct.Shanghai Electric manufactures turbines and electrical equipment, mainly for energy generation and industrial applications, and may thus face environmental risks and compliance costs tied to potential toxic emissions. Shanghai Electric's pollution management program is average compared with peers. Notably, we note improvements in its FY 2021 emissions performance relative to peers: its hazardous and non-hazardous waste intensities of 0.2 and 3.4 t/USD million were lower than the industry averages of 0.4 and 4.1, respectively (as of August 2022).Shanghai Electric has labor-intensive operations (with 39,015 employees in 2021 vs. industry average of 28,077 as of August 2022) and may thus face related challenges. The company's related risk mitigation measures are average compared with industry peers. We found evidence of annual workforce surveys that may help gauge employee satisfaction. However, while it offers non-statutory benefits and performance-based incentives, the scope of these initiatives appears limited relative to peers.

Godrej Industries' rating is unchanged at 'A'. Godrej Industries maintains robust workforce management initiatives, underpinned by extensive benefits and incentivization programs for staff. Also, the company has not reported layoffs in FY 2020, despite fluctuating demand and supply chain disruptions in its agribusiness and consumer product segments (69% of 2020 revenue) due to COVID-19. However, the company lags global peers on corporate governance structures, particularly on its board composition.Though the company has a majority independent board, entrenchment risks (4 of 11 directors have over 25 years of tenure, as of November 2021) may still limit independent oversight of management. Further, the absence of a fully independent audit committee may impede oversight of risks associated with related-party transactions with the controlling owner. Nevertheless, Godrej Industries appears on par with global peers on business ethics practices: it has an anti-corruption framework that is reinforced by whistleblower protection and board-level oversight of ethics issues.Chemical registration regulations are less stringent in India--where Godrej Industries mostly operates--than in most other regions. However, its chemicals and consumer products are exported to Europe and are thus subject to strict EU REACH requirements. The company provides customers with safe-use documentation through material safety data sheets; yet, it appears to lack phase-out or product reformulation plans for substances of high concern.

ESG_HEADLINE: On-par environmental strategies but trails on governance practices
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: COSL's rating is unchanged at 'B'. COSL's broad portfolio of oilfield solutions consist of drilling (64% operations FY 2021), technical (19%), engineering (7%), and marine support (10%) services. These pose lower risks of carbon footprint, toxic effluents, and adverse impact to local ecosystems from its operations than pure-play drilling peers. It continues to adopt industry-typical strategies in managing related risks. However, overall governance practices continue to trail those of global peers.COSL's global presence, notably in the North Sea, may pose higher risks of compliance costs tied to stringent carbon regulations like those in the EU. Its three-year (2019-21) GHG intensity of 237 mtC02e/mUSD exceeded the industry average as of August 2022 (182). Unlike with leading peers, we found no evidence of reduction targets.The company is a state-owned entity (50.52% shares held by CNOOC FY 2021), and we found evidence of related-party transactions (6.8% revenues FY 2021). The board is chaired by the CEO, and four of its seven directors have ties with the management or government--such a structure may limit management oversight. It trails global peers in adopting policies against corruption.COSL's operations pose high risk of disruptions tied to workplace incidents, based on our model. Like better-performing peers it adopts a groupwide safety policy extended to contractors. Its three-year (2019-21) injury rate of 0.42 per million hours is better than the industry average as of January 2022 (1.39).

Heiwa Real Estate's rating is unchanged at 'A'. We note some improvements in the company's corporate governance framework, which is now average compared to that of global peers. As of July 2022, its board had an independent director majority--a characteristic of only 15% Japanese peers and a feature that can strengthen oversight of governance decisions. However, the company trails most global and home market peers in business ethics practices, such as provision for whistleblower protection against retaliation.Heiwa Real Estate has opportunities to capitalize on green building investments, given its focus on energy- and water-intensive office and retail properties in Japan, where the government promotes a shift towards a sustainable environment. The company remains in line with peers in adopting energy- and water-efficiency upgrades and redeveloping spaces to make them more sustainable. However, our detailed assessment indicates limited clarity on the proportion of total property portfolio covered by green building certifications, impeding performance assessment.Heiwa Real Estate's involvement in diverse real estate businesses such as property development (52% of FY 2021 operations) may pose work safety-related risks. However, it operates in Japan, where employee fatality rates are low as per our model; this reduced the company's overall exposure to such risks. While the company has an executive-level safety committee, it appears to lack a safety management system certified to standards such as ISO 45001, unlike leading peers.

Kewpie's rating is unchanged at 'A'. Kewpie leads peers on food safety. Disclosure suggests all its production sites are certified to GFSI-benchmarked food safety standards, which entail supplier audits and routine product inspections. It also conducts periodic staff training on quality assurance to reinforce food safety controls. Also, Kewpie is on par with peers in efforts to tap into the growing demand for healthy products among Japan's aging population, with an array of food items with reduced salt, fat, and artificial content.The water-intensive production of processed eggs, dressings, and condiments exposes Kewpie to the risk of increased input costs in case of higher water prices. It is on par with peers on water-risk mitigation, with a time-bound target to reduce water intensity in its own operations (-10% by 2030 vs. 2020 baseline). However, we found no evidence of water resilience efforts along the agricultural supply chain, where the bulk of its water footprint lies.Our reassessment suggests Kewpie derived over 95% of FY 2021 revenues from packaged food (2020: 72%), which may indicate increased use of disposable packaging. This, given the stringent packaging regulations in Japan, exposes Kewpie to regulatory costs tied to packaging waste. While Kewpie aims to reduce its plastic waste by 30% by 2030 (vs. 2018 baseline), related efforts seem limited to a few product lines.Kewpie lags global peers on corporate governance. Its board lacks independent majority and fully independent key committees. This may limit objective management oversight.

Toyo Suisan's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. Toyo Suisan's food safety measures continue to lead those of peers. The majority of its operations are certified to widely recognized standards, such as ISO 22000 and HACCP, which entail periodic supplier audits and product testing; these may help mitigate food safety risks such as contamination. Also, we found no evidence of major recalls involving the company during the past year (as of October 2022). Toyo Suisan's corporate governance practices continue to lag those of most global peers.Toyo Suisan's water management practices are average relative to those of peers. The company has water-saving measures in some facilities, and its water withdrawal intensity was lower than that of peers (1,694 m3/USD million sales in 2021 vs. 1,839 industry median as of August 2021). However, Toyo Suisan appears to lack measures to foster water resiliency along its agricultural supply chain, where the bulk of its water footprint lies.Toyo Suisan's product portfolio is dominated by single-serving instant noodles, which may result in high volumes of packaging waste. Thus, the company may incur regulatory costs tied to Japan's stringent packaging laws. Unlike with leading peers, we found no evidence of robust sustainable packaging initiatives and a time-bound plan to phase out single-use materials from its overall packaging mix.Although common in Japan, Toyo Suisan's lack of an independent board majority and fully independent audit committee may limit oversight of management and financial reporting.

IIJ's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. IIJ appears to have adopted industry-leading measures for data protection, notably with external audits and security certifications that cover the bulk of its business. Also, its business ethics framework is overseen by an executive and IIJ has whistleblower protection mechanisms. On the downside, it trails global and home market peers in corporate governance, notably due to weakness in its board structure--the board lacks an independent majority and has over-boarded directors.IIJ derives its entire revenue from Japan where stringent privacy laws expose the company to high regulatory risks in case of a potential breach. Its data security measures are stronger than most peers and may help mitigate these challenges.Per our model, labor unrest issues have been historically low in Japan. This, combined with a relatively small workforce of 4,147 in FY 2021 vs. 41,574: June 2022 industry average, may lower IIJ's overall labor management complexity. The company offers medical and childcare benefits along with incentives for performance, but engagement initiatives to monitor employee sentiments appear limited.Like most peers in Japan, IIJ has several executives on board who may exert influence on the board's decision-making and impede external shareholder interests. Also, the presence of recurring related-party transactions with the noncontrolling shareholder in the absence of a fully independent audit committee may pose governance risks. Further, lack of pay disclosures impedes holistic peer comparison.

ESG_HEADLINE: Strong product safety and quality performance; leads peers in health and safety management
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Sekisui Chemical's rating is unchanged at 'AA'. Like leading industry peers, Sekisui Chemical demonstrates strong performance in mitigating product quality-related risks. Our assessment this year (FY 2021) indicates its warranty payouts in FY 2021 remained low at 1.08% of revenue (vs. industry average of 6.5%, May 2022). Further, while the company's corporate governance practices are average relative to those of global and home-market peers, its business ethics framework remains robust relative to those of global and home market peers.Homebuilders could face risks tied to potential worker injuries at construction sites. With group-wide safety policies extending to contractors, safety audits, and zero fatalities in 2021, Sekisui Chemical leads most industry peers on safety practices.We found no significant votes against director election at the 2022 AGM; this may indicate improved shareholder satisfaction with the board. However, the lack of an independent majority board may impede management oversight. Further, Sekisui Chemical has been flagged for being involved in a series of cross-shareholdings with other companies; this may lead to double-counting of their equities' values and raise concerns for other investors.Homebuilders typically have fewer opportunities to capitalize on green building investments because residential assets generally have lower energy consumption than retail assets. However, despite energy- and water-efficiency efforts, the company trails peers that have strong focus on acquiring recognized green building certifications.

Zeon has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'B'. Updated water stress data and the inclusion of regional groundwater availability in our evaluation of Japan's water stress resulted in a lower risk assessment for the company, contributing to the upgrade. Further, Zeon's water performance improved-withdrawal intensity of 5,949 m3/USD million: FY 2019 was lower than the 7,851 average for the commodity chemicals sub-industry (constituents of the MSCI ACWI Index), as of June 2021. However, we found no disclosure on its water management strategies.While Zeon's business ethics practices appear above-par those of peers, corporate governance practices appear to be trailing. The company is involved in a series of cross-shareholdings with multiple companies; this may lead to double-counting of equity values. We also found recurring related-party transactions with one of the companies (Yokohama Rubber Co); this may raise concerns for minority shareholders.Zeon operates in Japan, where carbon regulations are stringent. This exposes the company to related compliance costs. While GHG intensity was lower than the industry average (247 tCO2e /USD million: FY 2019 vs. 922, as of June 2021), we found limited evidence of energy conservation efforts.Manufacturers of synthetic rubber and plastic materials could face risk of environmental liabilities associated with toxic emissions and waste. Zeon has obtained ISO 14001 certification for some of its sites; however, we found no evidence of quantitative targets to reduce NOx and SOx emissions.

ESG_HEADLINE: Lags peers in efforts to disclose detailed GHG reduction plans; weak corporate governance practices
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: GENP's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. GENP is committed to achieving carbon-neutral operations by 2030 through projects to reduce and offset carbon emissions. Yet, unlike leading peers, its efforts appear to be in the initial stages--setting baseline data for all sites. Also, GENP's corporate governance practices lag those of peers; it is controlled via a stock pyramid and has an entrenched board--4 of 9 directors are tenured for over 15 years. These structures may limit the ability of shareholders to influence management oversight.GENP continues to face heightened public scrutiny due to the perceived negative impact of palm oil production on biodiversity. The company prohibits expansion on high conservation areas and peatlands, while compliance is monitored on the ground through collaboration with local NGOs and state agencies. However, it has yet to achieve full certification to stringent RSPO standards--identity preserved and segregated supply chain scheme (3.4% as of 2021).GENP is on par with peers in water management practices--it conducts risk assessments to identify drought-prone sites and has water use efficiency programs. Yet, its freshwater withdrawal intensity remains higher than that of its peers (17,369 m3/USD million sales in 2021 vs. industry median of 8,779 as of August 2021).Like leading peers, GENP has a detailed human rights policy that prohibits the retention of workers' identification documents and the collection of recruitment fees. This policy is reinforced by a formal grievance mechanism and direct recruitment of foreign workers.

We re-initiate coverage of Gunze at 'BBB'. In May 2021, Gunze was reclassified under the 'Industrial Conglomerates' industry (formerly 'Apparel, Accessories & Luxury Goods'), given its presence in diversified segments: clothing and textiles (49% of FY 2019 revenue), plastics (40%), and real estate (11%). Further, inclusion of the Corporate Behavior Theme in Gunze's Governance assessment indicates it has a strong business ethics framework with executive oversight. Also, it operates in Japan, where data indicates corruption is low.The company is a textiles and plastics manufacturer with a production base in Japan (86% of FY 2019 operations), where chemical regulations are stringent. Thus, it faces risks of incurring product reformulation and compliance costs. Yet, our research did not detect robust chemical phase-out plans or consumer awareness initiatives.Cotton-based garments in Gunze's apparel lines pose reputational risks in the event of unsustainable procurement of cotton.  We found evidence of organic cotton sourcing for some products, although it has yet to set detailed environmentally-friendly procurement targets and adopt formal membership to international sustainability initiatives such as the Better Cotton Initiative.Gunze lacks an independent majority board--common in its home market Japan. Presence of multiple executives (63% of board composition) and a combined CEO and chairman role may further limit balanced management oversight. It also lacks an independent pay committee; this may impact oversight of executive pay practices.

Nisshinbo Holdings has been downgraded to 'A' from 'AA'. Nisshinbo's clean technology efforts include offering braking solutions for electric vehicles and developing factory automation products. However, we note a decline in its three-year R&D spending intensity by 10% CAGR (2019-2021), driving the downgrade. While the company has robust business ethics practices such as executive oversight and employee trainings on business conduct, we note weaknesses in its corporate governance practices relative to global peers.Nisshinbo has business interests in the labor-intensive electronics, radio communications, and vehicle parts manufacturing segments. Yet, it operates in Japan, China, and other parts of Asia (83% of 2021 assets), where worker strikes are less frequent per ILO data. Thus, the company's exposure to labor unrest risks is moderate relative to peers. Nisshinbo has industry-typical workforce management initiatives, including employee welfare benefits and stock ownership programs.The company trails most global and home market peers on corporate governance. Nisshinbo continues to engage in cross-shareholdings with multiple firms, despite Japan's regulatory call to limit such arrangements. Its board, like in most Japanese firms, is executive-laden (6 of 11 directors, as of March 2022); this may limit management oversight.

ESG_HEADLINE: Weaknesses in carbon emission management practices and business ethics controls persist
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: CNBM's rating is unchanged at 'B'. Cement and gypsum products manufacturing (82% of CNBM's FY 2021 assets) is generally carbon-intensive, and may thus, pose risk of liabilities related to carbon emissions. Yet, CNBM continues to lag industry peers in setting quantitative carbon reduction targets and in adopting carbon mitigation practices. Further, it lags global peers on business ethics practices. On corporate governance, CNBM is average relative to global peers, with its pay practices generally in line with investor interests.Our model suggests state-owned entities such as CNBM have higher exposure to corruption risks than other companies. While the company conducts anti-corruption training for its employees, it appears to lack strong enforcement measures such as regular audits of ethics standards, and a policy protecting whistleblowers from retaliation.The company operates in China, where our model indicates work-related fatality rates are high; this exposes CNBM to risk of production disruptions and liabilities in case of work safety incidents. Though the company conducts safety audits, the scope of these remains unclear. It also appears to lack safety targets and continues to have work-related fatalities (FY 2021: 4 and FY 2020: 5).CNBM's large workforce (153,109 employees in FY 2021 vs. 29,600 MSCI ACWI industry average as of December 2021) could make it relatively challenging for the company to manage potential labor complexities. CNBM has adopted industry-typical initiatives such as engagement surveys and job-specific training programs.

We initiate coverage of AVZ Minerals at 'B'. AVZ Minerals is a mineral exploration company focused on the lithium-and-tin Manono project in DR Congo. Exploration drilling activities can disturb natural ecosystems and local communities; this exposes the company to financial, legal, or reputational risks. Yet, unlike with peers, we found no evidence of policies for sustainable land management and community engagement initiatives. On corporate governance, AVZ Minerals leads most of its global peers, particularly in board and ownership.AVZ Minerals' assets are still in the exploration and development stages, requiring significantly less manpower than peers with operating mines. This may result in relatively less complexity in labor management. Yet, it lags peers in employee engagement efforts and in providing robust non-pay benefits and incentives, programs that could help manage employee morale.Development activities may present the risk of operational disruptions in the event of workplace incidents. AVZ Minerals has a groupwide health and safety policy. However, unlike with peers, we did not find evidence of best practices such as setting safety targets or performing regular audits of its occupational safety management system.The company's board has an independent majority and fully independent audit and pay committees; this could provide strong management oversight. Yet, its business ethics practices appear limited:  we found no evidence of compliance audits or employee training.

Katakura's rating is unchanged at 'A'. Given its investments in pharmaceuticals and vehicle parts production (51% of 2021 revenue), Katakura is exposed to risks of potential liabilities linked to product safety. Although its product quality initiatives and responsible marketing practices appear limited relative to those of peers, we note no recalls or regulatory warnings for its pharmaceutical offerings over the three years through 2021. The company, however, lags most global peers on corporate governance.Katakura operates entirely in Japan, where incidents of worker strikes are infrequent as per ILO data. The company's relatively small workforce of 1,059 employees (2021) compared with the industry average of 85,402, as of August 2022, may present low labor management complexity. The company adopts industry-common employee management strategies, including providing employee stock ownership and support for qualification trainings; these measures may help facilitate talent retention and boost staff productivity.The company's board is not majority independent from management, and its chair is a former CEO. This may limit the board's independent oversight function. Further, although the Japanese government calls for limiting cross-shareholdings, Katakura maintains such arrangements with several firms.

Pendal Group's rating is unchanged at 'AA'. The company continues to exhibit strong ESG practices relative to peers. Notably, its talent development initiatives lead those of most industry peers. The rating is also supported by responsible investment practices that seem to lead those of peers. Furthermore, its governance structures are in line with those of leading peers, with an independent majority board and a robust ethics framework. However, its privacy practices seem to lack best practices and trail those of industry peers.The company's employee management initiatives include career development programs such as tuition sponsorship and succession planning and competitive compensation. It also focuses on promoting inclusion and diversity through training programs, incentives and opportunities targeting specific groups, to attract a steady pipeline of talent.Pendal Group exhibits strong performance in integrating ESG factors into its investment processes. It is a signatory to the UN Principles for Responsible Investment. Its measures to address ESG risks include having a dedicated team to analyze sustainability-related issues and engaging portfolio companies on ESG initiatives.The company's ethics framework includes policies against corruption, strengthened by mandatory staff training on code of conduct and by a whistleblower protection mechanism. However, higher expenses toward non-audit-related services in 2021 (61% of total fees paid to the auditor) could raise concerns about auditor independence.

Nikke's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. Nikke has transformed from a pure-play textile company to a corporate group over the years, with non-textile segments contributing 72% to its revenue in FY 2021. While nearly half of its segments are typically labor intensive, a relatively small workforce (5,126: FY 2021 vs. 94,054: industry average, as of December 2022) may entail lower exposure to risks tied to labor management. Further, we found evidence of upskilling and benefits programs to enhance workforce productivity.To address saturation within its textile business, Nikke plans to expand into the luxury textile and Chinese student uniform markets; this may increase the demand for sustainable and cotton-blend products, and increase public scrutiny related to its sourcing practices. We found evidence of programs in upcycling fabrics and developing eco-friendly fibers.The company lags global peers on corporate governance. It has been flagged for leadership concerns. A former executive is the chair of the board, which also includes the CEO; this may limit management oversight. However, Nikke leads peers on business ethics: we found new evidence of ethics audits.Nikke's real estate business may benefit from the growing demand for sustainable buildings in Japan, where energy-related regulations are stringent. Further, the company's community-based properties and redevelopment of properties, present opportunities to offer affordable options. However, its property portfolio seems to lack green building certifications.

DTS has been upgraded to 'BBB' from 'BB'. Like its IT consulting peers, DTS relies on skilled talent to stay competitive, and may thus face talent management challenges. The upgrade reflects improvements in DTS' talent management initiatives, notably in adopting programs for staff upskilling and career progression. Its overall talent management programs are on par with those of industry peers. However, we note DTS' three-year average staff turnover rate of ~5% (2019-2021) was lower than the industry average of ~11% (April 2022).DTS' overall governance performance is on par with that of industry peers. It has strong business ethics policies, including practices such as extending training on ethical standards to part-time workers and contractors. However, like peers in Japan, DTS lacks an independent board majority, which may limit management oversight. Besides, limited executive pay disclosures may impede peer comparison.As a provider of IT consulting and allied IT-enabled services, DTS handles significant volumes of data and may, thus, have high exposure to data privacy-related risks. Moreover, it operates primarily in Japan, where privacy laws are stringent. DTS' data security framework is on par with that of industry peers, featuring practices such as executive oversight of data security programs, and staff cybersecurity training that extends to contractors. However, unlike with better-performing peers, we found limited evidence of an overarching privacy framework that covers all subsidiaries and business affiliates.

FUJIMI has been downgraded to 'B' from 'BB'. Our reassessment of the company's abrasive chemicals business indicates moderately high exposure to risks of reformulation costs and of environmental liabilities linked to chemical safety regulations and generation of toxic emissions and waste, respectively. FUJIMI trails industry peers in phasing out potential hazardous chemicals and in integrating environmental standards in product design. This contributed to the downgrade.FUJIMI continues to lag most global peers in governance practices. Similar to Japanese peers, the company's board lacks an independent majority and has multiple executives; this could increase management influence over the board. Further, the company seems to lack a detailed anti-corruption policy and regular audits of ethical standards to monitor corporate behavior.FUJIMI appears to lack strong programs to mitigate risks of key air pollutants (NOx/SOx) tied to its business. Also, we found no disclosures on the company's emissions data; this may impede performance comparison with peers.We note improvement in the company's GHG emission performance. The intensity in FY 2020 (39 tCO2e/USD million) was lower than the average (301) for specialty chemicals sub-industry (constituents of MSCI ACWI Index), as of March 2022. Further, FUJIMI targets to reduce its energy use by 1% by 2021 (vs. 2020 levels).

Sankyu has been upgraded to 'AA' from 'A'. The upgrade reflects Sankyu's improved carbon mitigation strategy amid stringent carbon regulations in Japan. The company has set a new target of 1% reduction in energy consumption intensity per year; it is switching to using battery- and LPG-powered cars from forklift trucks in its warehouses. Further, a scoring adjustment to the Executive Pay Disclosure key metric in cases where pay is disclosed for the CEO, but not for other executives, is a key contributor to the upgrade.Sankyu is less exposed to labor management complexities as it operates in Japan, where labor unrest has been historically low (per ILO). The company offers industry-typical benefits, including training programs and performance-based incentives, which may boost staff productivity.Sankyu's board structure, which lacks an independent majority and has strong executive presence, appears largely on par with that of Japanese firms. However, we note significant shareholder dissent to the re-election of its chair at the 2021 AGM, indicating potential dissatisfaction with his performance.Trucking and heavy construction operations face high exposure to risks of operational disruptions due to employee or road accidents. Like many of its peers, the company has a group-wide safety management system that includes trainings and risk assessment. While the company's lost time incident rate rose at a compound annual rate of 140.6% (FY 2017-20), it remained low at 1.95 per million hours worked in 2020 (vs. 3.3 industry average, as of March 2022).

K Line's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. The inclusion of the Corporate Behavior Theme in the company's governance assessment brings greater scrutiny to business ethics practices. It has board-level oversight on business ethics issues and a formal anticorruption policy. We note its ethical audit and whistleblower protection systems, but these fall short of best practices. On the corporate governance front, it lacks an independent board and has limited executive pay disclosure, which may pose risk to shareholder interests.Shipping companies are exposed to increasingly stringent environmental regulations--including the 2020 global sulfur cap and sector-wide decarbonization goal--set by the International Maritime Organization. The company has disclosed plans of using alternative fuels such as LNG and LPG, and commissioned its first LNG-powered vessel in March 2021. However, these fall short of best practices in the peer group.With the 0.5% sulfur cap effective since 2020, K Line disclosed SOx and NOx mitigation measures such as installation of requisite equipment; also, it has certified its operations under ISO 14000. However, its SOx emissions intensity for 2020 at 6.36 t/USD million sales remained higher than the industry average of 4.8.Marine operators face high risk of accidents that may lead to operational disruptions. It has a group wide safety policy overseen by its board. However, unlike many peers, we found no evidence of certification to global safety standards such as ISO 45001.

Kamigumi's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. Kamigumi continues to trail industry peers in establishing strong policies and efforts to manage potential adverse biodiversity impact stemming from its port-harbor cargo handling and transport services. The company's reliance on long-term government concessions may pose inducements to involve in corrupt business practices. Kamigumi's business ethics framework is on par with that of peers and include measures such as employee trainings and whistleblower protection.The company has a strong group-wide safety policy relative to industry peers that extends to contractors and is reinforced with audits. While the company appears to have missed its 30% YoY target to reduce vehicular accidents in 2020--increased from 3 to 5 cases--its LTIR remained low at 0.96 per million hours worked vs. the industry average of 5.81 (as of December 2021).Kamigumi's corporate governance structure lags that of global and home market peers. The board continues to lack an independent majority and to face potential entrenchment risks in relation to two of ten directors (as of October 2021). We also note the presence of a former CEO on the board. Such features may create the potential for a management-friendly board or limit the board's independent management oversight.Kamigumi has environmental policies, such as renewable energy use and waste treatment, to minimize risks of adverse biodiversity impact. However, we found limited evidence of leading programs such as environmental impact assessments or noise monitoring.

ESG_HEADLINE: Robust practices to help manage ESG risks
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: KDDI's rating is unchanged at 'AAA'. With ~60 million mobile subscribers (FY 2021), KDDI has access to large volumes of user data and is thus exposed to risks tied to consumer data privacy; more so, as it derived the bulk of its FY 2021 revenue from Japan, where stricter data privacy laws were implemented in April 2022. Like leading peers, KDDI has strong data protection practices such as external audits of IT security systems and ISO 27001 certification. KDDI's corporate governance is above-par relative to its peers in Japan.KDDI operates in the labor-intensive telecom industry; yet, it has limited exposure to labor-related risks as ILO data suggests the likelihood of labor unrest is low in Japan--KDDI's core market. Its labor management initiatives are on par with those of industry peers and include non-pay benefits and upskilling programs. Yet, since March 2021, KDDI has faced a lawsuit filed by a former employee of subsidiary KDDI Evolva alleging wrongful termination.KDDI follows the one share one vote principle, aligning shareholders' voting rights with economic exposure. Like most peers in Japan though, its board is not majority independent, which may limit independent management oversight. Also, KDDI has a detailed policy against corruption, which is reinforced through executive-level oversight. However, since February 2021, it has faced NGO scrutiny over alleged indirect involvement in human rights violations due to restrictions ordered by Myanmar's military on telecom firms in the country; this weighs on KDDI's governance assessment.

SAIBU GAS HOLDINGS has been upgraded to 'A' from 'BB'. The removal of the key metrics derived from accounting ratios (Asset-Liability Valuation) in the Governance assessment is a key contributor to the company's upgrade due to its relatively low accounting risk compared to global and home market peers. Further, on corporate behavior, we found evidence of improved disclosures on policies against corruption and bribery. Saibu Gas is above average relative to peers in mitigating carbon emissions.As a natural gas distributor, Saibu Gas has moderate exposure to risks related to evolving carbon regulations compared with fossil fuel generators. In line with Japan's emission reduction target of 46% by 2030 (vs. 2013 levels), the company plans to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050 with efforts to transition to carbon-free fuels such as methane and hydrogen.Operations in Japan, where historical data indicates low incidence of workplace accidents, suggest low exposure to risks of operational disruptions. Like leading peers, Saibu Gas's health and safety initiatives include a groupwide safety policy; also, it has mandated a risk officer to oversee its strategy and performance. While the company has set targets to reduce accidents, it seems to lack certification on internationally recognized standards, such as OHSAS 18001.

ESG_HEADLINE: Strong performance across ESG Key Issues
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Teijin has been upgraded to 'AAA' from 'AA'. The inclusion of the Corporate Behavior Theme in the company's Governance assessment is a key contributor to the upgrade due to the company's strong business ethics policies and practices relative to peers. Teijin adopts a formal anti-corruption policy and has ethics trainings for all its employees. Further, the company leads home-market peers on corporate governance practices. Teijin's chairman is independent--a feature noted in only 4% of companies in our Japan coverage.With 41% of its FY 2020 operations in Japan--a country that targets to be carbon neutral by 2050--Teijin is exposed to risks of potential compliance costs. The company strengthened its carbon mitigation measures, with a new target to reduce CO2 emissions by 20% by 2030 (vs. 2018 levels). Its GHG intensity (181 tCO2e/USD million) remained lower than the average of 919 for Commodity Chemicals sub-industry (constituents of MSCI ACWI Index), as of February 2022.Teijin's presence in markets with stringent chemical regulations, such as Japan and the US (70% of FY 2020 revenue), exposes it to potential reformulation costs. Its chemical management practices, which include lifecycle assessment of its synthetic fiber products, seem robust.The inclusion of regional groundwater availability in our evaluation of water stress in Japan and the US resulted in a lower risk assessment for Teijin. Its water management is supervised at the executive level--an industry best practice. Also, the withdrawal intensity declined at 3.8% (CAGR, FY 2017-20).

Axis REIT's rating is unchanged at 'B'. Axis REIT's corporate governance practices are average relative to those of global peers. The board may still be considered entrenched, with 5 of 9 directors having had tenures of more than 15 years (2022 AGM); this may negatively impact management oversight. On the upside, following the appointment of two new directors, its board has an independent majority. Further, we note improvements in the company's executive pay disclosures; this may align with investor interests.Real estate investment trusts typically rely on a skilled workforce, and could, thus, face recruitment and retention challenges. The company relies on its fund manager, Axis REIT Managers Berhad, for its human capital requirements. While the fund manager offers staff benefits, and undertakes performance appraisals, it appears to lack employee management programs such as annual engagement surveys and stock options.The company is focused on warehouses (FY 2021: 92.4% of operations); this provides it with relatively low green investment opportunities, as these properties are not as energy intensive as office and retail properties. Nevertheless, the company's sustainability initiatives are average relative to those of peers, and include upgrading air conditioning and plumbing systems, and leasing of roof spaces to tenants for solar panel installation. However, it appears to lack green building certifications for a majority of its portfolio, thus trailing peers.

Healius' rating is unchanged at 'AA'. Methodology enhancements to the Corporate Behavior Theme resulted in greater emphasis on business ethics practices and on exposure to corruption-related risks. Healius operates in Australia, where incidence of corruption is perceived to be low. Healius is on par with peers in ethics practices: it has a detailed anti-corruption policy and whistleblower protection. It is also on par with global and home market peers in corporate governance. Plus, we note improvements in its data security programs.As a diagnostic service provider, Healius collects patient data. The company could thus face risks associated with potential data breach or misuse. Its data security programs lead those of peers. Our research found ISO 27001 certification and privacy provisions related to user rights on personal data.Healius' operations may present risks related to service quality issues. The company's programs to mitigate such risks appear on par with those of peers: evidence indicates it monitors quality performance through customer engagement measures. We note no regulatory warning in the last three years, as of October 2021.ILO data suggests likelihood of labor unrest is high in Australia (100% revenues; FY 2020). However, Healius' labor management programs lag those of leading peers. While we note 90% of its workforce is covered by trade unions, its training and career development programs appear available to select employees only.

RInfra has been upgraded to 'B' from 'CCC'. We note improvements in RInfra's corporate governance. The company underwent a recent change in board composition that replaced a flagged director (Mr. Anil Ambani). As of April 2022, its board was no longer flagged as entrenched and was assessed as having an independent majority; these could improve management oversight. These led to the upgrade. Yet, RInfra still lags global peers in accounting practices. Its external auditor has provided a qualified opinion for the last three financial years.Exclusive operations in India could expose RInfra to water availability risks, as water stress in the region is high (Source: WRI Aqueduct). A significant portion of RInfra's operations is in electric transmission and distribution (T&D: 31%), where water use is less critical than for peers heavily relying on cooling water for their thermal energy generation. That said, in line with industry best practices, a board committee oversees RInfra's water management practices.Unlike pureplay fossil fuel-based power generation companies, RInfra's operations in electric T&D reduces the company's exposure to regulatory risks tied to toxic emissions. Nevertheless, its operations are certified to ISO 14001 standards.As is common in the utilities industry, RInfra relies on a skilled workforce for its operations, exposing it to talent-related challenges. Yet, it lags peers in human capital management. We found limited evidence of practices such as performance appraisals and incentive pay offerings to bolster employee productivity.

ESG_HEADLINE: Strong service quality management and governance performance
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Ramsay's rating is unchanged at 'AA'. We have revised our evaluation of exposure to service quality risks by removing a company-specific component which was based on the size of operations. This has resulted in a decrease in Ramsay's overall risk exposure. It leads peers in quality management: it has Joint Commission International certification for select facilities, and initiatives to collect customer feedback. We note no regulatory warnings in the three years through May 2022. It is on par with peers on governance performance.Around 58% of Ramsay's operations were in Europe in FY 2021 where frequency of corruption is perceived to be low. Its business ethics framework is on par with that of global peers and features whistleblower protection. Likewise, its pay practices lead those of global peers and appear in line with shareholders' interest.As a provider of healthcare services, Ramsay handles sensitive information of patients. We note practices such as internal audits of data security systems and employee training on data security for its European operations. However, Ramsay's data security system appears to lag that of better-performing peers. The company disclosed 50 notifiable breaches of patient privacy in 2020 and 2021.Healthcare facilities' operations are typically labor-intensive. Thus, like peers, Ramsay may be exposed to potential work disruptions in case of labor unrest. Its labor management is on par with that of peers, with most employees covered by collective bargaining agreements.

Ridley's rating is unchanged at 'A'. Ridley continues to lead global peers in governance practices. However, we do note some shareholder dissatisfaction with the former CEO on board at the 2021 AGM. The company's health and safety (H&S) management systems and performance is above average relative to industry peers. Ridley, however, appears to have limited initiatives to promote water sustainability across its value chain. This may expose it to higher input costs, given that cereal grains require substantial water.Nevertheless, our research indicates Ridley's board and key committees have the requisite independence to provide oversight aligned with the best interests of shareholders. The company also has a detailed policy against corruption and bribery. However, it appears to lack compliance mechanisms such as periodic audits and employee training on ethical standards.Like leading peers, Ridley has a group-wide H&S policy reinforced with regular performance audits. In addition, its total recordable injury rate has remained lower than that of peers (5.5 per million hours in 2021 vs. industry median of 16 as of August 2021). Nevertheless, we note it has yet to certify operations to widely recognized H&S standards, such as OHSAS 18001.Evidence suggests Ridley lacks water use reduction targets and efficiency measures, especially in its supply chain, where the bulk of its water footprint lies. This may limit its ability to mitigate risks of increased input costs in case of water shortage along its value chain.

Sigma Healthcare has been upgraded to 'AAA' from 'AA'. Sigma Healthcare leads most global peers in governance practices with notable improvement in its board and pay structures. Its board has an independent majority with separate CEO and chair roles. Further, Sigma Healthcare's board no longer includes overboarded directors as of August 2022; this may help bolster management oversight. Recent changes in the company's executive pay policies may help allay shareholder concerns surrounding its pay practices.Our research found that the company leads most peers in business ethics practices. Given the nature of its business operations which may involve multiple touchpoints with the government for approvals, Sigma Healthcare could face corruption-related risk. We found robust measures to mitigate these risks such as whistleblower protection and detailed policies against bribery and corruption.As a distributor of pharmaceutical and other healthcare products intended for human use, the company faces moderate exposure to product recalls in case of product quality issues. Yet, we did not find evidence of regulatory recalls and warnings in the three years through October 2022. We found no evidence of regulatory recalls and warnings as of October 2022. However, we note that unlike leading peers, the company appears to lack product safety-related best practices such as dedicated policies and employee trainings on responsible marketing practices.

Ramelius' rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. Ramelius continues to lead global and Australian peers on corporate governance, particularly board and ownership structure. Further, its business ethics policies and practices appear relatively strong compared to those of its peers. However, our research indicates the company lags peers in adopting a strong strategy to mitigate potential adverse impacts of its gold mining operations on the environment.Ramelius' ownership structure appears to support parity in voting rights across all investors. Besides, it has a majority independent board and fully independent key committees (nomination, audit, risk, pay); this may help bolster management oversight. Additionally, the company's business ethics framework is supported by a detailed policy against bribery and corruption, and by legal protection for whistleblowers.Ramelius may face risk of incurring environmental liabilities linked to toxic emissions and waste byproducts. Yet, we found no evidence of an ISO 14001-certified environmental management system. The lack of disclosure on its emissions data also impedes comparison with peers.The extractive nature of Ramelius' business could pose regulatory risks in case of public opposition if its operations cause disturbance to local communities. Yet, unlike with better-performing peers, we found no evidence of community impact assessments and formal grievance channels--measures that could help manage risks related to community conflict.

Regis Resources' rating is unchanged at 'BB'. The company continues to lag peers in mitigating environmental risks tied to its gold mining and development operations, particularly on water and waste management.
