Our research shows it leads peers in adopting strong water efficiency technologies, as evidenced by its low freshwater withdrawal intensity of 5,575 m3/USD million sales (22,193 industry average, as of January 2022).Rengo benefits from relatively low exposure to risks related to labor unrest, owing to its presence in Japan (FY 2020: 88% of assets), where ILO data indicates incidence of strikes is low. Nonetheless, Rengo offers welfare benefits and stock option plans, which could help boost job satisfaction.Rengo lags global peers on corporate governance. The recent appointment of a female director could support gender diversity on the board. However, we note its board remains potentially entrenched due to the presence of three long-tenured members and six directors that are aged over 70 years, as of March 2022; these could impede its ability to provide objective management oversight.

Kanto Denka has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'B'. The upgrade reflects improvements in Kanto Denka's programs and strategies to help manage water scarcity-related risks through employment of water recycling measures and water risk assessment. Its freshwater withdrawal intensity of 3,202 m3/USD million in FY 2020 was lower than the average (9,216) for peers in the MSCI ACWI Index Specialty Chemicals sub-industry as of May 2022. Further, improvements in disclosures on the company's toxic emissions performance data also contributed to the upgrade.As a manufacturer of industrial chemicals, Kanto Denka has high exposure to risk of environmental liabilities tied to toxic emissions and waste. Its NOx (0.02 t/USD million) and SOx (0.001 t/USD million) emission intensities were below the average (NOx:0.09; SOx:0.05) for Specialty Chemicals sub-industry peers (constituents of the MSCI ACWI Index, May 2022).With 79% operations in Japan, where chemical safety regulations are stringent, Kanto Denka may face reformulation costs. While the company's chemical safety management practices include provisions to conduct hazard assessments, we found no evidence of a formal plan to phase out hazardous chemicals, unlike with leading peers.Like Japanese peers, Kanto Denka lacks an independent majority board. This, along with the presence of multiple executives on the board, may result in strong management influence on the board. Further, the company appears to lack a formal policy against corruption and provisions for regular audits of ethics standards.

Sumitomo Bakelite's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. Our broadened assessment suggests the company maintains robust programs to mitigate risks associated with carbon and toxic emissions, and waste. Its NOx and SOx emission intensities declined at a CAGR of 17.6% and 3.9%, respectively, in FY 2017-2020. Sumitomo Bakelite trails industry peers in chemical management practices, with no formal plans to phase out hazardous chemicals from operations. We note weaknesses in the company's governance practices relative to global peers.With 57% of its FY 2020 operations in Japan, which targets achieving carbon neutrality by 2050, Sumitomo Bakelite faces risks of incurring costs tied to stringent carbon regulations. The company targets to reduce CO2 emissions by 46% by 2030 (vs. 2013 levels) through energy conservation measures and alternative energy sourcing.Production of plastics is water-intensive compared to that of other industrial chemicals; this exposes Sumitomo Bakelite to water-scarcity related risks. The company leads peers on water withdrawal: the intensity in FY 2020 (2,690 m3/USD million) was lower than the average (8,478) for specialty chemicals sub-industry (constituents of MSCI ACWI Index), as of February 2022.Like most Japanese peers, Sumitomo Bakelite's board lacks an independent majority, and there are seven serving executives; this could potentially increase management influence over the board. We found no evidence of a formal anti-corruption policy. Its ethics training programs for employees also appear limited.

Central Glass' rating is unchanged at 'BB'. The company continues to lag global peers on corporate governance, notably board structure and pay practices. Central Glass trails industry peers in adopting robust programs to help manage potential toxic emissions and wastes from its operations. It is on par with industry peers on efforts to mitigate potential labor challenges and corruption-related risks. Its business ethics framework features market-common practices such as whistleblower protection and regular audits of ethics standards.Like most Japanese peers, Central Glass lacks an independent majority board. Also, significant votes against all directors at the 2021 AGM may indicate shareholder dissatisfaction. Further, we flag the company for involvement in a series of cross-shareholdings, despite the call to reduce such arrangements under Japan's governance code. We found no disclosures on its executive pay.The company's operations pose risks of liabilities tied to potential toxic emissions and waste. While Central Glass has environmental protection programs, it lags industry peers in setting robust toxic emission targets and securing the ISO 14001 certification for all its operations.The labor-intensive nature of glass and chemical manufacturing may pose risks of operational disruptions in case of labor unrest. However, a small workforce (6,053 in 2020 vs. industry average of 34,220 as of March 2022) could reduce Central Glass' exposure to labor complexities. It offers a broad range of benefits and leadership training; this could improve productivity.

Osaka Soda's rating is unchanged at 'B'. The rating is underpinned by weaknesses in the company's environmental and chemical safety management practices. Production of synthetic resins typically generates large amount of VOC emissions, thereby exposing Osaka Soda to the risk of incurring associated environmental liabilities. While our research indicates that the company has certified 75% of its facilities (FY 2020) to ISO 14001 standards, we found no disclosure on its VOC emission figures, impeding peer comparison.As Osaka Soda derived 77% of FY 2020 revenue from Japan and the EU, where chemical regulations are stringent, the company is exposed to potential reformulation costs. We note it conducts hazard assessments for new products. However, unlike better-performing peers, it appears to lack formal plans to phase out hazardous chemicals from its operations.The water-intensive nature of plastics and industrial chemicals exposes Osaka Soda to risks related to potential water scarcity. However, unlike with better-performing peers, we found no disclosures on the company's water withdrawal figures or quantitative targets to reduce water use, impeding peer comparison.Osaka Soda's governance practices appear to trail those of global peers. Its board lacks an independent majority. This, along with the presence of multiple executives--including the CEO--on the board, may result in strong management influence. Meanwhile, its business ethics practices appear to have board-level oversight and a whistleblower system.

SmarTone has been upgraded to 'BBB' from 'BB'. Enhancements in SmarTone's governance structure, particularly board practices, drive the upgrade. Concerns related to the overboarding of a non-executive director and audit committee member appear to have been allayed (as of June 2021). This, combined with an independent-majority board, may help facilitate independent management oversight. In addition, SmarTone's initiatives on communications accessibility for the elderly and children contribute to the upgrade.SmarTone is on par with peers on labor management. The company has moderate exposure to labor-related risks due to its small workforce (1,665 in FY 2021 vs. industry average of 38,042 as of August 2021). In addition, it operates in Hong Kong and Macau, where ILO data indicates the likelihood of labor unrest is moderate. Nevertheless, SmarTone offers industry-typical benefits such as employee stock ownership and skill training.Given their reliance on regulatory approvals for operating licenses, telecom operators have high exposure to risks related to public-sector corruption. As part of its business ethics programs, which are in line with global peers, SmarTone has policies against corruption and bribery, and a whistleblower reporting system.SmarTone handles large volumes of customer data and, thus, is exposed to privacy-related risks. However, the company lags industry peers on data security management. We found no evidence of best practices such as regular system audits and data breach response measures.

ESG_HEADLINE: Trails peers on carbon mitigation measures; strong water management programs relative to peers
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: SPC's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. The company continues to trail peers in carbon mitigation practices. As a manufacturer of petroleum and plastic products, SPC may incur compliance costs linked to carbon regulations. However, the company appears to lack strong carbon management programs relative to peers: we found no evidence of targets to reduce GHG emissions. Meanwhile, SPC's water management initiatives lead those of peers.SPC's operations may pose risks of environmental liabilities associated with toxic emissions and waste. The company's FY 2021 NOx and SOx emission intensities of 0.08 and 0.01 t/USD million sales were lower than the industry averages of 0.39 and 0.10 as of November 2022. However, SPC appears to lack quantitative targets to reduce NOx/SOx emissions from its operations.Having derived 91% of FY 2021 revenue from China, where chemical safety regulations are stringent, the company may face reformulation costs. We note SPC has provisions to conduct hazard assessments for new products. Yet, unlike better-performing peers, the company appears to lack plans to phase out hazardous chemicals.Production of industrial chemicals is water intensive and may expose SPC to risks related to potential water scarcity. We note the company's water recycling rate was 98% in FY 2021. SPC's three-year (2019-21) average freshwater withdrawal intensity of 4,106 m3/million USD sales was below the industry peer average of 13,140 (as of November 2022).

Shanghai Industrial Holdings (SIHL)'s rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. The national policy to expand China's green building footprint presents opportunities for SIHL (2020: 56% of revenue from property development). Our research indicates about 9% of the company's portfolio had certifications to green standards, such as the Two-star Green Building Design Label, as of December 2020. We also note the integration of energy-saving elements in project design. On the downside, SIHL appears to lag global peers on governance structures.SIHL has a small workforce (18,344 employees in 2020 vs. industry average of 89,813 as of January 2022); this may reduce labor management complexities. Evidence indicates its employee management programs are industry-typical, but exceed statutory requirements, with welfare benefits and stock option plans.State-owned Shanghai Industrial Investment (Holdings) Co and its subsidiaries held 62.5% of voting power at SIHL as of May 2021. Also, the board lacks an independent majority and is potentially entrenched (25% of directors have tenures of over 25 years and another 25% are aged over 72, as of June 2021). These structures could pose the risk of subordination of minority shareholder interests.Like other Chinese state-owned firms, SIHL may also face increased regulatory scrutiny on its business conduct. Evidence indicates a commitment to observe anti-corruption standards. However, the company appears to lack business ethics best practices, such as whistleblower protection or regular ethics audits across the supply chain.

Riken Vitamin's rating is unchanged at 'B'. Riken Vitamin lags most global peers on corporate governance practices. That said, we note that no director received significant votes opposing their re-election at the 2021 AGM. Additionally, despite stringent regulations on packaging in Japan, the firm's efforts toward sustainable packaging seem limited. On the upside, Riken Vitamin has an in-house product quality testing capacity, with some of its facilities certified to recognized standards such as FSSC 22000 and ISO 9001.Riken Vitamin's corporate governance practices do not appear to be well-aligned with shareholder interests: the firm does not have an independent board majority, and continues to be involved in a series of cross-shareholdings. Further, the firm provides limited disclosure on executive pay practices. Its accounting practices, as of March 2022, also appear to have weaknesses.Riken Vitamin's reliance on single-use packaging translates into a high volume of post-consumption waste. Further, despite increasingly stringent regulations on packaging in Japan (79% of FY 2020 sales), the company's related efforts (such as lightweighting, product recovery) appear to be in their initial stages.Riken Vitamin may face risks of public and NGO scrutiny due to its reliance on environmentally intensive raw materials such as palm oil and seafood. Yet, only 8.5% of palm oil sourced is RSPO-certified, and we found no evidence of procuring sustainable seafood.

ResortTrust has been upgraded to 'AA' from 'A'. The removal of the key metrics derived from accounting ratios in the Governance assessment is a key contributor to the company's upgrade due to its relatively low accounting risk compared to home peers. Overall, its governance practices are average relative to global peers. Updated exposure data based on review of latest regulations in Japan on data privacy and data protection has resulted in a lower risk assessment for the company, also contributing to the upgrade.ResortTrust's hotel and resort operations entail collection of customer data. Like leading peers, it has a strong data protection framework that includes firm-wide privacy policy and data breach incident management plan; this may help mitigate regulatory risks linked with data breaches.The company's exposure to labor-related risks is low given its operations are in in Japan, where incidence of labor unrest is low, and its small workforce (8,123 in FY 2020 vs 47,184 industry average, as of January 2022). It leads peers in labor management, with select non-pay benefits, including share-based payments. Also, it has collective agreements which provide engagement channels with management.The water-intensive nature of the hotel business may expose the company to operational risk in case of water shortages. While the company tracks its water consumption, it lags peers in adopting robust water conservation techniques or reduction targets.

Sanyo Special Steel's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. The company leads most global peers on business ethics practices. Its anti-corruption framework is overseen at the board level, and includes robust compliance mechanisms such as regular audits and ethics trainings. Sanyo Special Steel lags most global peers on corporate governance practices. Its board lacks an independent majority and split CEO and chair roles; this may limit management oversight. Its pay committee is not fully independent, and we found limited disclosures on its executive pay.Steel manufacturers face the risk of environmental liabilities tied to air pollutants and wastes from smelting operations. While the company conducts regular environmental audits across all operations, only 15% of its facilities were certified to the ISO 14001 standard as of FY 2021. Also, it lags peers in setting waste reduction targets.Operations in Japan and Sweden (FY 2020: 89% assets) where data indicates low incidence of workplace accidents may reduce the company's exposure to the risk of operational disruptions tied to potential employee injuries. Unlike with leading peers, we found no evidence of a safety management system certified to external standards such as ISO 45001 or of safety targets.The carbon-intensive nature of steel manufacturing operations may expose the company to the risk of incurring costs linked to stringent carbon regulations. Although the company utilizes low-emission electric arc furnaces and has energy conservation programs, it lags peers in adopting carbon capture technologies and clean energy.

Takasago's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. The company trails global and local peers on governance. Takasago has cross-shareholdings with Meito Sangyo, despite regulatory calls to reduce such arrangements under Japan's revised corporate governance code. Further, we found no evidence of a detailed anti-corruption policy or audits of its ethics standards; this could limit the company's ability to mitigate corruption risks. Meanwhile, Takasago's chemical management programs are on par with those of peers.Takasago derived 57% of its FY 2020 revenue from the US and Japan where stringent chemical safety regulations apply. This exposes the company to potential reformulation costs. While we note the company develops alternatives to hazardous chemicals and conducts hazard assessments, it appears to lack a formal plan to phase out hazardous chemicals from operations.The production of flavoring agents and other industrial chemicals is water-intensive and could expose Takasago to risks of operational disruptions in case of water shortage. The company targets to reduce its water withdrawal by 10% by 2030 (vs. 2020 levels). However, it lags peers in utilizing alternative water sources.The production of fragrances and flavoring agents is less carbon intensive than that of other industrial chemicals, which lowers Takasago's exposure to carbon emissions regulatory risks. The company leads peers in carbon management practices. It commits to reduce Scope 1 and 2 GHG emissions by 27.5% by 2030 (vs. 2019 levels) through renewable energy sourcing.

FANCL has been upgraded to 'BBB' from 'BB'. Improvements in FANCL's palm oil sourcing practices drive the upgrade. As of FY 2021, ~97% of the palm oil used in the company's products was certified to widely known standards such as the RSPO certification (typically Book & Claim and Mass Balance standards). However, it lags leading peers that procure certified palm oil that is traceable up to the mill level. Further, we note improvements in the company's governance practices which contributed to the rating upgrade.FANCL derives revenues predominantly from Japan where stringent packaging waste management prevails; this may expose the company's waste management practices to regulatory scrutiny. While FANCL has targets to reduce the use of plastic from its packaging (~43% reduction in FY 2022 vs. 100% by FY 2031), it lags peers in packaging recovery programs.Personal care products (~57% of FANCL's 2021 total revenues) may contain harmful chemicals such as parabens and sulfates. This exposes FANCL to potential regulatory risks, as it operates in Japan which has stringent chemical regulations. The company trails industry peers that have formal plans to phase out harmful chemicals.Involvement in food products and dietary supplements business may expose FANCL (~43% revenues; FY 2021) to potential product safety-related risks linked to consumer health. While the company states it has obtained FSSC 22000 certification--a globally recognized food safety certification--for its manufacturing facilities, the scope is limited to some operations.

JCU's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. The company derived 93% of its FY 2020 revenue from Japan, South Korea, and China, where chemical regulations are stringent; this exposes JCU to potential reformulation costs. However, the company appears to lag better-performing peers in instituting a formal plan to phase out hazardous chemicals. Meanwhile, we note improvements in the company's corporate governance practices.Based on the recent disclosure surrounding non-audit fees paid to external auditor, we no longer flag the company for issues related to auditor independence. However, like most Japanese peers, JCU lacks an independent majority board. This, along with the presence of multiple executives--including the CEO--on the board, may result in strong management influence on the board.The production of paints is less carbon intensive than that of industrial chemicals; thus, JCU's exposure to regulatory risks related to carbon emissions is low. However, we found no evidence on its carbon emission figures or quantitative reduction targets--this may impede peer comparison.The VOC-emission intensive nature of paints production may expose JCU to the risk of incurring potential environmental liabilities associated with toxic emissions and waste. While we note that some of its facilities are certified to ISO standards, we found no evidence on its VOC emission figures, impeding peer comparison.

Rohto has been downgraded to 'BB' from 'BBB'. Rohto, like its peers in the household and personal products industry, is exposed to regulatory risks due to the apparent use of single-use plastic. The company trails its peers in implementing packaging waste management efforts. Further, we note weaknesses in its efforts in reducing the carbon footprint of its products; we found no evidence of lifecycle assessments nor disclosure on the downstream and upstream carbon emissions, which also contribute to the rating downgrade.Rohto primarily operates in Japan, a country with stringent regulations on managing packaging waste. Yet, the company appears to lack sustainable packaging programs, such as lightweighting and increased use of eco-friendly alternatives, such as recycled plastics in its packaging mix.Skincare and cosmetic products (~63% of Rohto's FY 2020 revenue) use various chemicals, some of which might be harmful to consumers. This exposes the company to potential reformulation costs linked to the use of these chemicals. Rohto's chemical management strategies, however, appear to lack strong chemical phase-out plans and green design principles.As of 2020, Rohto derived about 36% of revenues from the food and medicine product segment; this exposes it to regulatory and financial risks related to potential product quality issues. To address these, the company conducts supplier audits and states that some of its pharmaceutical manufacturing facilities have received certifications to global quality standards such as ISO 9001/13485.

Sosei Group has been downgraded to 'BB' from 'BBB'. Our revised evaluation of product safety risks (removal of a company-specific component based on operations) has resulted in an increase in Sosei Group's overall risk exposure, contributing to the downgrade. Further, it lags peers in product quality assurance: for instance, it appears to lack programs such as certification to widely accepted standards (e.g., ISO 9001). However, we note the company leads home market peers on corporate governance.Sosei Group leads home market peers in board structure: the board is fully independent and has separate CEO and chair roles (as of August 24, 2022). We note ~85% Japanese peers lack majority board independence. Likewise, its ownership structure leads those of home market peers and appears well-aligned with shareholders' interest.The company lags most global and home market peers on its business ethics framework and appears to lack ethics measures such as a detailed anti-corruption policy, or ethics audit or a whistleblower protection mechanism.Like pharma peers, Sosei Group is exposed to employee-centered risks due to reliance on a highly skilled workforce. Yet, the company lags peers in implementing robust talent management initiatives. We found no evidence of programs such as career development and staff engagement measures to help attract and retain talent.

Duskin has been downgraded to 'AA' from 'AAA'. While the company mainly leases cleaning equipment, the food franchise business contributed 24% to its FY 2020 revenue; this may expose it to risks related to food safety. The downgrade factors in Duskin's limited quality and safety programs. While it tests raw materials and ingredients and trains employees on quality standards, we found limited evidence of supplier training and in-house product testing. Duskin continues to outperform peers in staff management efforts and ethics practices.Duskin's small workforce (3,819 in 2020 vs. 28,260 industry average, as of December 2020) makes it easier to address labor management complexities compared to peers. Our research indicates the company offers a broad range of non-compensatory benefits, professional development programs and conducts annual employee engagement surveys, which could aid in talent retention.Duskin outperforms global peers on practices to mitigate corruption risks. In particular, it has instituted a robust business ethics framework, with board-level oversight, a formal bribery and anti-corruption policy, legal protection for whistleblowers and employee training on its code of conduct.Dukin's corporate governance practices appear to lag those of global and home market peers. The company's ownership structure is highly dispersed, limiting the ability of investors to influence management behavior. Moreover, the company has not provided a detailed disclosure on its executive pay; this may impede performance comparison with peers.

Aeon has been downgraded to 'BBB' from 'A'. Methodology enhancements to the Consumer Financial Protection Key Issue resulted in a reassessment of initiatives to help preempt potential unethical lending. However, we note Aeon appears to lack fair advertising practices and product related reviews--measures that may help protect consumer interests. Moreover, it lags global peers in establishing a strong corporate governance framework, particularly on board and pay practices.Aeon's performance on the Corporate Behavior Theme--which focuses on the company's efforts to prevent unethical behavior--has improved since the last rating action. Please refer to the ESG Rating Drill Down and dedicated Corporate Behavior sections of the report for more details.Aeon continues to lead industry peers on Privacy and Data Security, which focuses on the company's exposure to evolving privacy regulations and on its ability to safeguard sensitive data. Please refer to the ESG Rating Drill Down and dedicated Privacy and Data Security section of the report for more details.Aeon continues to lag industry peers on Human Capital Development, which focuses on the company's reliance on a skilled workforce and on its ability to attract and retain talent. Please refer to the ESG Rating Drill Down and dedicated Human Capital Development sections of the report for more details.

Perenti has been upgraded to 'AA' from 'A'. Perenti's rating upgrade is driven by improvements in programs to manage risk of community opposition tied to its mining services operations. It has policies to support indigenous people and local hiring, and has introduced initiatives to monitor performance of its human rights policy. Our research indicates developments in its labor-management policies that complement its broad range of welfare benefits. Also, in 2021, it adopted annual engagement surveys to monitor employee satisfaction.Perenti leads most global peers in its governance framework. It has a fully independent board and independent key committees (audit and pay) which may help provide strong management oversight. Unlike in the previous year, the company established improved auditor independence in 2021. Further, its business ethics programs feature executive oversight and a detailed formal policy against corruption and bribery.Mining services companies typically have high exposure to risks of operational disruptions and liabilities tied to potential workplace incidents. Perenti has a centralized health and safety management system that is certified to international standards, such as ISO 45001. Further, the system is backed by a groupwide policy, enforced by regular audits.The water-intensive mining operations of Perenti could pose risks of operational disruptions in case of water shortages. Yet, the company continues to trail peers in adopting strong water management programs and setting water reduction targets.

ESG_HEADLINE: Sustained strong governance structures
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Spark NZ's rating is unchanged at 'AA'. Spark NZ continues to lead global and home market peers on corporate governance. It maintains a board that is majority independent of management and fully independent of other interests: this bolsters its management oversight. Further, it has a single equity class structure, which could align shareholders' economic exposure and voting power. We also note it has low exposure to labor-related complexity due to a relatively small workforce (5,144 in FY 2022 vs 41,574: June 2022 industry average).Spark NZ operates solely in New Zealand, where per our model, exposure to risks of labor discord is moderate. Like most peers, it offers non-pay benefits and conducts employee engagement initiatives.Our model indicates telecom operators are exposed to corruption risks, notably since they rely on regulatory approvals for licenses. Spark NZ's business ethics practices are average relative to those of global peers; its anti-corruption framework features firmwide employee trainings on ethics standards and provisions that protect whistleblowers from retaliation.Spark NZ derives revenues solely from New Zealand, where privacy laws are stringent; this may expose the company to regulatory scrutiny in case of a breach. However, the telecom operator appears to lag peers in data security management. While it provides firmwide cybersecurity training, we found limited evidence of best practices such as a board-level oversight and robust data collection minimization. Also, the scope of its third-party certification (ISO 27001) seems limited.

CLEANAWAY WASTE MANAGEMENT LIMITED (Cleanaway)'s rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. Cleanaway continues to lead global peers on corporate governance practices. Also, its policies to monitor ethical conduct lead those of global peers. While our research indicates on par health and safety practices, the company trails peers on measures to help mitigate risks of environmental liabilities linked to toxic emissions and waste.Cleanaway's board has an independent majority and split CEO and chair roles. Further, it has independent key committees, that may help bolster management oversight. The company leads global peers on corporate behavior with strong business ethics measures such as whistleblower protection and board oversight of ethics issues.Cleanaway's waste management operations are labor intensive and it operates in Australia, where labor discord incidents have been high as per ILO data. Like industry peers, Cleanaway offers non-statutory benefits that may increase employee satisfaction. Yet, it remains linked to a controversy related to alleged workplace harassment in 2020.Based on our model, we note the company faces risks related to potential toxic emissions from its industrial waste and leachate management activities. We found no evidence of quantitative targets to reduce emissions. Also, in June 2020, regulators in Australia inspected 27 of the company's facilities following chemical spills which reportedly affected waterways.

ESG_HEADLINE: Strong performance in corporate governance, but lag peers in business ethics programs
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: We initiate coverage of Fudan-Zhangjiang at 'BB'. . While the company appears to have instituted robust corporate governance practices relative to China market peers, weaknesses in business ethics practices weigh on its performance in governance, compared to industry peers. Fudan-Zhangjiang's talent management programs also appear limited. The company's product quality management measures compare favorably with those of peers.The company's board has independent majority and fully independent key committees (as of June 2021)--a structure associated with strong management oversight. However, it appears to lack a detailed anti-corruption policy and robust ethics compliance programs, such as regular ethics audits and whistleblower protection.With its business focused on developing anti-tumor and venereal disease treatment, the company is required to meet certain product quality standards. It has adopted programs such as regular quality oversight. We found no recalls and warning records in the last three years (as of May 2021).Similar to healthcare companies relying on research and innovation, Fudan-Zhangjiang faces high exposure to employee management challenges. While evidence suggests the company has adopted employee engagement programs, we found no evidence of programs to track employee satisfaction and turnover rate. Further, the company lags industry peers in providing robust training opportunities.

ESG_HEADLINE: Above average on management of environment and product quality
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: CSPC's rating is unchanged at 'A'. CSPC leads most home market peers in business ethics risk control framework, with whistleblower protection and a detailed anti-corruption policy. Its talent management programs appear average relative to those of peers. It has formal talent development programs, and stock incentives and skills training to attract and retain employees. This may help support staff retention amid potential integration challenges due to acquisitions, such as Recomgen Biotech and JMT Bio.We have revised our evaluation of exposure to product safety and quality risks by removing a company-specific component based on the size of operations. This has resulted in an increase in the company's overall risk exposure. CSPC appears to have all operations certified to GMP and ISO 9001 standards. It faced no recalls in the three years through September 2022.We found CSPC leads most peers in toxic management, with environmental management system (ISO 14001) covering all manufacturing sites. Also, it targets to reduce hazardous waste, and water and energy consumption intensity by 25%, and 27% and 47%, respectively, by 2025 versus 2017.CSPC's corporate governance practices are average relative to home market peers. It does not have a special capital structure. However, its board lacks majority independence from management. We also note significant shareholder vote against the re-election of its chair, Mr. Cai Dongchen, as an executive director at the 2022 AGM, indicating potential dissatisfaction with his performance.

Tadano has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'B'. We note improvements in Tadano's governance practices relative to peers, driving the upgrade. Its board now has an independent majority, which could improve the board's management oversight. Further, a previous scoring deduction related to its audit has been resolved and is, therefore, less likely to present a risk to the firm's financial performance and reputation. On the downside, Tadano continues to trail peers in monetizing opportunities from clean technologies compared to industry peers.Tadano mostly operates in Japan, where incidence of corruption is perceived to be low. Nonetheless, we note the presence of industry-standard practices such as executive committee-level oversight of its ethical standards and a whistleblower protection program to preempt risks of potential unethical conduct.Manufacturing of construction machinery equipment is perceived to be labor intensive; this may expose Tadano to challenges related to labor management. However, we found limited evidence of robust employee engagement initiatives.Tadano's operations in manufacturing lifting equipment expose it to risks of environmental liabilities associated with potential toxic emissions and waste. The company has ISO 14001 certification for some of its manufacturing bases (coverage of other sites is unclear). However, we found no evidence of emissions and waste data, and reduction targets; this may impede its assessment relative to peers.

Pinnacle Investment has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'B'. Inclusion of the Corporate Behavior theme in our Governance assessment is a key contributor to the upgrade. Pinnacle Investment's comprehensive anti-corruption framework includes industry-best measures such as internal audits and board-level oversight of business ethics policies and practices. The company also provides training to employees on ethical standards and has a whistleblower protection mechanism.The company lags peers in its capacity to mitigate regulatory risks in the event of potential data theft and leakages. It does not provide clarity on digital rights customers. Also, we found no evidence of periodic audits that could help gauge the strength of its IT infrastructure and security policies.Pinnacle Investment appears to lack responsible investment initiatives to manage its indirect exposure to ESG risks and opportunities in its business. We did not find evidence of integration of ESG principles into investment activities.Efforts to attract and retain talent include professional training and equity-linked compensation structures that may help align employee and shareholder interests. However, Pinnacle Investment lags industry-leading peers in conducting staff surveys which help gauge employee morale.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improved labor management and corporate governance practices
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Daifuku has been upgraded to 'AA' from 'A'. Improvements in Daifuku's labor management and corporate governance drive the upgrade. We found evidence of strong remuneration practices, including stock option plans, which could aid in talent retention. Daifuku's score has been adjusted on the Executive Pay Disclosure key metric in cases where pay is disclosed--as for the CEO--but not for other executives. Yet, governance risks remain particularly related to votes against two directors (2021 AGM), indicating possible shareholder dissent.The company manufactures material-handling equipment; thus, its operations are labor intensive and may pose risks of work disruptions and reduced staff productivity. Daifuku's small workforce (11,697 vs. industry average of 20,097 as of January 2022) may reduce labor management complexity. Relative to peers, the company has strong programs, such as monitoring of job satisfaction through annual engagement surveys.Daifuku's operations may pose moderate risks of related environmental liabilities and compliance costs associated with toxic releases. The company maintains ISO 14001 certification for its environmental management system and conducts environmental impact audits--best practices adopted by leading peers.The company operates in regions such as Japan and the US, where incidence of corruption is perceived to be less. While Daifuku's anti-corruption framework includes provisions for whistleblower protection and executive oversight, we found limited evidence of compliance controls such as audits of ethics standards.

Whitehaven Coal's rating is unchanged at 'A'. The company leads global peers in governance practices. Whitehaven Coal has detailed policies against corruption, with board-level oversight of ethics performance. We note evidence of employee trainings and provisions to protect whistleblowers from retaliation. However, it continues to trail peers in efforts to mitigate risks associated with toxic and GHG emissions and potential adverse impact on biodiversity and surrounding community tied to its coal mining operations.Whitehaven Coal has an independent majority board an independent chair, and fully independent audit and pay committees; structures that bolster management oversight. It follows the 'one share one vote' principle, which aligns shareholders' economic exposure and voting rights. Further, its executive pay practices appear aligned with shareholder interests.Companies that undertake coal mining could face the risk of operational disruptions in the event of workplace accidents. The company leads industry peers with safety best practices such as a group-wide health and safety policy extended to contractors and executive pay linked to safety performance. Further, its average TRIR (FYs 2020-22) of 5.13 per million hours was lower than the industry average of 6.08 as of Q3 2022.Whitehaven Coal could face the risks of liabilities tied to potential adverse biodiversity impacts due to coal mining activities. Also, we note several ongoing controversies, indicating potential gaps in implementing strategies to protect natural ecosystems.

Max has been downgraded to 'B' from 'BB'. Weaknesses in Max's corporate governance drive the downgrade. Like most Japanese firms, the company lacks an independent majority board and independent chair, thus lagging global peers. It has adopted a shareholder rights plan or 'poison pill', which can be deployed by management to prevent hostile takeover and limit the ability of investors to accept what they consider an attractive acquisition bid. Further, the company remains flagged for being involved in a series of cross-shareholdings.The company's presence in Japan (82% FY 2020 assets), where perceived incidence of corruption is low per Transparency International data, results in low exposure to related risks. Our assessment indicates Max has whistleblower protection programs, like peers. However, we found no evidence of detailed anti-corruption policy or ethics trainings--practices that may help mitigate the risks.As a manufacturer of office equipment and industrial tools for construction and agriculture, Max may benefit from the growing demand for energy saving products. However, it appears to have limited strategies focused on developing cleantech products, unlike better-performing peers.Max's manufacturing operations may pose moderate risks related to environmental liabilities from potential toxic releases. The company is on par with peers on environmental management initiatives. As of 2020, it was certified to ISO 14001 for all its domestic manufacturing sites and overseas factories, indicating efforts to manage the environmental impact of its operations.

Meidensha's rating is unchanged at 'A'. Meidensha leads peers in workforce management, notably related to skill development opportunities and in monitoring staff satisfaction levels through annual engagement surveys. It also offers varied non-pay benefits such as nursing care leave systems. These may help mitigate risk of operational disruptions tied to potential labor discord in its labor-intensive industrial operations. However, it seems to lag global peers on corporate governance.Meidensha's product portfolio includes electric power systems, wastewater treatment, and power control and monitoring systems for railways and smart grids. Through these, the company appears well-positioned to capitalize on these opportunities. Yet, we found no evidence of new investment targets--adopted by leading peers--for development of clean technology.The company's operations have moderate exposure to the risk of liabilities and compliance costs associated with toxic releases, as per our model. Like leading peers, it has ISO 14001 certification and monitors its waste annually. However, it has yet to achieve its target VOC levels of 80 tons or below (141.10 t in FY 2020).Meidensha's business ethics practices are average relative to those of global peers. We found evidence of measures such as whistleblower protection and training on ethics standards for permanent employees. On corporate governance, we note significant votes against two directors at the 2022 AGM, possibly indicating shareholder dissatisfaction.

Vital has been upgraded to 'BBB' from 'B'. The removal of the key metrics derived from accounting ratios (Revenue Recognition and Asset-Liability Valuation) in the Governance assessment is a key contributor to the upgrade due to Vital's low accounting risk compared with home-market peers. The addition of a female board member in FY 2021 led to an improvement in board diversity. Further, we no longer flag Vital for significant votes against directors (2021 AGM); this may indicate improved shareholder satisfaction with board performance.The company's business ethics practices are average compared with those of global peers. Vital has a dedicated risk officer for oversight of business ethics programs and a detailed policy against corruption, which includes whistleblower protection. However, it appears to lack industry best practices such as regular audits of ethics standards.Operations in New Zealand and Australia (2021: 100% of revenues)--where the demand for green buildings is high--and focus on energy-intensive healthcare assets present Vital with green investment opportunities. While Vital utilizes green leases to help improve portfolio sustainability, we found limited disclosure on the proportion of portfolio certified to green building standards; this impedes peer comparison.Real estate investment trusts compete for skilled talent. Vital relies on its external manager for its human capital needs. Yet, unlike the case with leading peers, we found no evidence of a formal talent pipeline strategy or performance appraisal programs to support talent retention.

Nissin Electric's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. Nissin Electric's programs to manage toxic emissions and wastes appear above-par, relative to peers. However, we note weaknesses in its corporate governance: it is a controlled company (Sumitomo Electric Industries held 51.45% of the voting rights as of December 2021) and the chair previously served as the CEO. Also, the board lacks an independent majority, and has multiple serving executives; this may increase management's influence within the boardroom.Nissin Electric has relatively low exposure to labor unrest risks due to its small workforce (5236 in FY 2020 vs. industry average of 32,727, as of January 2022). That said, it offers non-statutory benefits and training programs, which could help sustain workforce productivity. It also conducts regular engagement surveys to monitor job satisfaction.The electrical equipment business is generally considered to be prone to corruption and may expose Nissin Electric to such risks. This risk may be mitigated by the presence of its business primarily in Japan, where corruption risks are perceived to be low. However, its business ethics framework includes market-standard practices such as executive-level oversight and whistleblower program to preempt the risks.Although the company has initiatives for renewable energy and smart power systems, it currently appears to trail industry peers in monetizing opportunities from clean technology markets. It derived an estimated ~7% revenues in FY 2020 from core cleantech applications.

JM Financial's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. JM Financial relies on skilled staff for its operations, but lags peers in adopting industry-best practices such as grievance reporting channels. However, its corporate governance is average relative to global peers. Following changes in board composition (July 2022), the board is no longer entrenched; this may aid management oversight. Further, a previous deduction related to its audit has been concluded; this may lower the risk to its financial performance and reputation.Inclusion of the Corporate Behavior Theme in JM Financial's Governance assessment resulted in a greater emphasis on business ethics practices. The company's business ethics framework, like that of global peers, includes whistleblower protection; this may help mitigate potential unethical conduct.JM Financial's responsible investment initiatives lag those of industry peers. We found no evidence of a dedicated team to assess ESG risks in its investment activities. Further, the company does not appear to be a signatory to globally recognized initiatives such as UN-supported Principles for Responsible Investment--a measure which could help mitigate long-term ESG risks in the portfolio.JM Financial collects sensitive personal data of customers as part of its retail brokerage activities which may expose it to privacy-related risks. However, the company lags industry peers in adopting data protection practices such as conducting regular IT system audits to help prevent potential security incidents.

ESG_HEADLINE: Leads peers in safety management; average on corporate governance
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: China Resources Gas' rating is unchanged at 'A'. While the company's operations focus on gas distribution, which has low exposure to risk of accidents, it maintains strong initiatives in occupational safety. We also note a decrease of ~50% in China Resources Gas' carbon emissions intensity (FY 2021: 14.52 tons CO2e/USD million sales vs. FY 2020: 28.07). The company's corporate governance, notably pay practice, is average relative to global peers, but leads that of most home market peers.The company's safety framework features increased recognized external certifications (FY 2021: 28.6% vs. FY 2020: 18.2%, estimated) and inclusion of contractors in safety performance. It has also disclosed lost time incident rate (for FY 2021). This may help in peer comparisons.Gas distribution represented ~97% of China Resources Gas' FY 2021 operations. Thus, it has a lower exposure to risks tied to carbon-related costs than peers generating power from fossil fuels. To help curb carbon emissions, it adopts methane escape control in transmission and distribution, and at the user end. However, unlike leading peers, it appears to lack medium- or long-term climate targets. The company's carbon emission reduction strategies appear limited to annual intensity targets set on a rolling basis.The company discloses details on executive pay, which may help in peer comparisons. However, its board lacks an independent majority and fully independent audit and nominations committees; this may hinder management oversight.

Wacom's rating is unchanged at 'B'. Wacom's e-waste management programs trail those of industry peers. Our research found limited practices to manage risks related to waste caused by its end-of-life products. Also, Wacom's talent management practices trail those of peers. We found no evidence of strong employee engagement initiatives such as grievance and feedback channels, which may help gauge staff morale. Wacom's governance practices are on par with those of global peers.Wacom relies on a skilled workforce to maintain and improve its proprietary technologies. We found limited evidence of employee upskilling and development programs that may help retain talent.Our research indicates, as of FY 2021, the majority of Wacom's product manufacturing was outsourced to China. This may expose the company to risks of operational disruptions in case of labor unrest in its supply chain. The company, however, lags industry peers in implementing strong audit mechanisms to help monitor labor conditions in its supply chain.Wacom leads most home market peers in corporate governance practices. We note the company's board has an independent majority and a fully independent audit committee that could support the board's management oversight. However, we continue to note limited disclosures around executive pay; this may impede comparison with global peers.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improved governance practices; maintains robust e-waste management system
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Panasonic's rating is unchanged at 'AA'. Panasonic maintains leading e-waste management practices. It has e-waste take-back programs in multiple locations. Further, it collaborates with Toshiba Corporation to manage a recycling network within Japan, where it derived 43% of its revenues in FY 2021. We note improved business ethics practices. Evidence indicates Panasonic has executive oversight of its ethics standards. Yet, it trails most global peers on corporate behavior: it appears to lack external audits of its ethics standards.Panasonic's diversified product mix leads to lower exposure to regulatory risks tied to chemical management, compared to peers that specialize in products with many substances of concern (e.g., computers). It requires suppliers to disclose safety data sheets for chemicals used and has proactively phased out PVC, thus leading peers.Electronic products typically contain 3TGs, which may be sourced from conflict regions. Like leading peers, Panasonic undertakes due diligence: in 2022, 80% of SORs were either RMAP-certified or undergoing audit. It relies on cobalt for lithium-ion batteries and has extended its due diligence to this mineral.Panasonic may be exposed to consumer scrutiny over working standards in its supply chain, as most of its products are manufactured in developing countries such as China, where our model indicates high incidence of labor right violations. While related audits extend to tier 2 and 3 suppliers, Panasonic continues to face allegations over the use of forced labor in its supply chain in China.

Nihon Kohden's rating is unchanged at 'A'. As a maker of electronic health devices such as CO2 sensors, AEDs, and pulse oximeters , among others, Nihon Kohden may be exposed to reputational risks in case of product safety and quality issues. Its quality management measures are on par with those of peers, and feature ISO9001 and ISO13485 certifications, and commitment to responsible marketing. We note it faced at least three Class II product recalls in three years through February 2022. The company lags leading peers on governance.Like peer medical device manufacturers, Nihon Kohden is exposed to corruption risks due to multiple touchpoints with government for approvals. We note it has a policy against bribery and corruption, and whistleblower protection programs. However, it lags industry peers in business ethics framework and appears to lack audits of ethics standards. Its board structure is on par with that of peers. However, the board lacks an independent majority, and does not have separate CEO and chair roles. While these features are common in the Japanese market, these may limit management oversight.Nihon Kohden relies on a highly-skilled workforce to support its R&D operations, and, thus, like peers, may face challenges in attracting and retaining talent. While we note the company's talent development programs for certification and leadership, its talent management lags that of leading peers. Our research found limited evidence of talent pipeline strategies that may help maintain a steady pool of workforce for hiring.

ESG_HEADLINE: Subpar initiatives across ESG Key Issues
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Wangfujing Group's rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. The rating reflects weaknesses in the company's programs related to the ESG Key Issues associated with department and general merchandise store retailers. Wangfujing Group's governance practices trail those of its global peers. Further, our research indicates its labor management initiatives lag those of industry peers.As a state-owned entity in China where there is an ongoing anti-corruption campaign, Wangfujing Group may face high regulatory scrutiny on its business practices. We found limited evidence of ethics compliance mechanisms, such as staff training and regular audits. We also flag its board for leadership concerns, as a former CEO serves as chairman. His previous ties to the management and the company's controlled structure could limit the board's capacity for independent oversight of management and pose risk of subordination of minority shareholder interests.Wangfujing Group operates in China, where data privacy and security regulations are stringent. This exposes it to regulatory risks in case of a data breach. Yet, it lags peers in conducting regular data system audits and staff training on cybersecurity.The company, like its retail peers, could face risks of labor unrest or low productivity that are common to the sector. We found limited evidence of robust training and engagement programs which could help mitigate the risks.

ESG_HEADLINE: Consumer complaints decreased; employee attrition remains low in relative to peers
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: BoCom has been upgraded to 'A' from 'BBB'. BoCom's improved performance of consumer protection and talent retention, along with increased efforts in green finance and inclusive finance, drive this upgrade. The bank's consumer protection practices are average relative to peers. We note a reduction in total complaints in 2021. Following China's mandate of inclusive finance to support the private segment, the Y-o-Y growth of its loans to inclusive small and micro business (CBIRC definition) reached 49.2% in 2021, leading those of peers.Lending business has high exposure to credit risks tied to potential adverse environmental impact. BoCom became a TCFD supporter in 2021 and adopted industry-specific credit policies and preliminary climate impact test. However, it lags peers in green bond investment and in escalation measures for these risks.The bank leads peers on talent management performance: its three-year average employee turnover stands at 3.3% in 2022, lower than the industry-average of 10.3%, as of September 2022.BoCom lags global peers in governance practices. Methodology enhancements to the Governance theme resulted in a greater emphasis on the additional governance risks to investors posed by directors with other outside interests. Although its board has an independent majority, it does not separate the CEO-chair roles; this could hinder management oversight. BoCom lags global peers in business ethics mechanism: the regulator (CBIRC) imposed a penalty on the bank in March 2022 over its alleged reporting deficiencies.

ESG_HEADLINE: Lags peers in managing risks across ESG Key Issues
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Shenghe Resources' rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. Shenghe Resources continues to lag peers in measures to mitigate ESG risks linked to its mining activities. We found limited evidence of policies to reduce ecosystem disturbance and preserve local biodiversity. The company appears to have limited policies for protecting indigenous communities and local procurement, and in implementing strong community engagement initiatives; these could help mitigate risks tied to community unrest. Also, the company trails global peers in governance practices.The company has high exposure to risk of environmental liabilities linked to pollutants and tailings due to its metal extraction operations. However, unlike in leading peers, we found no evidence of ISO 14001 standard certification or of performance data and reduction targets.With total mining operations in China (FY 2021), where ILO data indicates high frequency of occupational accidents, it has high exposure to risk of operational disruptions linked to workplace incidents. Yet, we found no evidence of disclosures on safety performance or on linking it to executive pay; these impede comparison with peers.Shenghe Resources is a state-owned entity, and its chair is a government representative. This may raise concerns regarding state intervention in management activities and also not align with minority shareholder interests. Although, its board has an independent majority, we note potential risks associated with related party transactions. However, in business ethics, it conducts audits and trainings with board-level oversight.

ESG_HEADLINE: Robust talent management performance; lagging consumer protection and business ethics practices
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: China Minsheng Bank's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. China Minsheng Bank leads peers on talent management performance: its employee attrition rate was 6.2% in 2021, lower than the industry average of 9.6% as of November 2022. We also note its enhanced green finance framework for integrating ESG risks into industry-specific credit policies, and climate risk stress tests in 2021. Yet, it lags peers in practices to mitigate data breach risks (i.e., regular external IT audits), and business ethics controversies continue to weigh on its rating.The bank leads global peers on corporate governance (i.e., independent board majority, independent audit committee). The removal of the key metrics derived from accounting ratios in the Governance assessment also contributed to the improved score due to low accounting risk relative to global peers. Yet, related-party transactions amounted to ~9.2% of total assets in 2021. Moreover, the bank trails peers in business ethics practices--it was fined CNY 4.9 million by CBIRC for alleged deficiencies in mandatory data reporting in March 2022.The bank lags peers in practices to protect consumers' financial interests. While it has adopted certain complaint management measures, we note limited evidence of product safety review, and rapid rise in complaints (i.e., over 10% YoY to 63,643 cases) in 2021.The bank exhibits strong focus in channeling funds to typically underserved communities. As of 2021, ~7.8% of loan portfolio was concentrated in China's rural segment; small and micro enterprise loans accounted for ~12.5% of loan portfolio.

ESG_HEADLINE: Food safety measures on par with peers; lags on corporate governance
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: CP All Public has been upgraded to 'A' from 'BBB'. We have revised our evaluation of exposure to product safety and quality risks by removing a company-specific component which was based on the size of operations. This has resulted in a decrease in CP All Public's overall risk exposure, leading to the upgrade. Moreover, like those of leading peers, its operations are certified to widely recognized standards, such as HACCP and ISO 22000. These standards entail periodic audits and testing, which may help preempt food safety issues.CP All Public faces low labor-related risks due to a small workforce (63,414 vs. industry average: 158,542 as of Jan' 2022) and operations in Thailand, where labor unrest incidence is low as per ILO. Like leading peers, the company has engagement surveys to monitor workforce satisfaction, and development opportunities to retain employees.CP All Public's online and in-store retail transactions entail handling customer data, exposing it to risk of  data breach or misuse. Like leading peers, its operations are certified to ISO 27001 that requires system audits to identify vulnerabilities, and employee training on cybersecurity.We note CP All Public's related-party transactions with its controlling owner declined (9.7% of expenses in 2021 vs. 13.2% in 2020). However, its corporate governance practices continue to lag those of global peers. The company has an entrenched board (10 of 16 members have served for >15 years) that lacks an independent majority. This may limit its ability to provide strong management oversight.

JW Pharmaceutical's rating is unchanged at 'B'. JW Pharmaceutical undertakes R&D of a wide array of pharmaceutical products, and thus relies on highly skilled professionals. Yet, it lags peers on talent management: we found limited evidence of robust staff engagement and skills development programs--practices considered helpful in attracting and retaining key talent. The company also trails global and domestic peers on corporate governance. On the upside, its business ethics practices appear robust.The company has detailed business ethics policies with executive oversight; this may help address risk of unethical behavior posed by its multiple touchpoints with the government for marketing approvals. However, on corporate governance, multiple equity classes with disparate voting rights, along with related-party transactions (33.8%; FY 2020 expenses) with the controlling family (43.4% voting right), pose risks of subordination of minority shareholders' interests.The company could face liabilities in case of product quality issues. It has industry-typical quality management practices such as supplier monitoring and employee training. We found no regulatory warnings in the three years through January 2022.The company's products for cardiovascular disorders and cancer--major global health problems (as per WHO data)--may provide opportunities to address the unmet medical needs, especially in emerging markets. Yet, we found no evidence of detailed plans and programs to improve access-to-healthcare.

Daesang's rating is unchanged at 'B'. Daesang launched its inaugural sustainability report in 2021, which could indicate a stronger focus on ESG practices. The disclosure suggests the company assesses GHG emissions and water-related risks in its own operations and undertakes packaging lightweighting to help minimize its climate impact. Despite this, Daesang still lags industry peers in implementing broad measures to tackle climate risks in the agricultural supply chain, representing the bulk of its carbon and water footprint.As a manufacturer of sauces, seasonings, and food ingredients that are dependent on water-intensive agricultural raw materials such as vegetables and corn, Daesang is exposed to risks of rising input costs in case of water shortages. Despite this, it still seems to lack robust water resilience initiatives such as promoting water-efficient irrigation systems or drought-tolerant varieties upstream.Daesang's portfolio of food products suggests dependence on palm oil--an agricultural commodity typically linked to deforestation and wildlife loss, thus exposing it to reputational and regulatory risks. However, Daesang appears to lack broad initiatives on responsible sourcing, such as procuring RSPO-certified palm oil, and thus, lags peers.The company appears on par with peers on measures to mitigate food safety-related risks. We note some of Daesang's facilities are certified to the GFSI-benchmarked FSSC 22000 standards. Moreover, we found no evidence of major product recalls during the last 12 months.

Ichikoh's rating is unchanged at 'A'. The company continues to lead industry peers on labor management and product quality assurance. A relatively small workforce (FY 2021: 3,519 vs. industry average of 100,711, as of June 2022) and focus on Japan (FY 2021: 81% of operations), where incidence of labor discord is low (as per ILO data) limit the company's exposure to risks of labor unrest. Moreover, we note strong practices such as equity grants for employees. Ichikoh continues to trail global peers on corporate governance.As per our model, makers of automotive lighting face lower risks related to product quality, than makers of safety-critical parts, such as braking systems, that are exposed to high physical stress. Ichikoh has strong quality performance: its three-year (FY 2019-2021) average warranty payouts/sales ratio of 0.48% was lower than industry average of 0.63% (as of June 2022).The company's offerings include LED lighting systems, which are more energy efficient than conventional halogen lamps, and may thus help extend driving range in electric vehicles. Ichikoh may thus benefit from the increasing adoption of electric vehicles and energy-efficient technologies.The company is involved in related-party transactions with its controlling owner, Valeo. Moreover, executives of Valeo serve in Ichikoh's board alongside the executive chair and CEO. Such structures may not be in alignment with, or in favor of minority investor interests. The board also lacks an independent majority, which could limit independent management oversight.

ESG_HEADLINE: Relatively low exposure to risks of corruption; sub-par clean mobility initiatives
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Mazda's rating is unchanged at 'A'. The company's operations are based mostly in Japan, North America, and Europe (90% assets in FY 2021), where our model suggests corruption risks are low. Mazda leads most global peers on business ethics; we note employee ethics training to further mitigate such risks. The company remains average relative to global peers on corporate governance. Nevertheless, limited disclosures on executive pay, and the presence of the CEO and executive chair in the pay committee, may pose risks.In February 2022, a local union in Mexico protested the alleged dismissal of 280 workers following employees raising grievance. This may indicate gaps in implementation of labor policies. However, Mazda is average relative to industry peers in addressing labor-related challenges: we note industry-typical initiatives such as annual employee engagement surveys to monitor job satisfaction.Mazda remains average relative to industry peers in product quality assurance. We note initiatives such as supplier audits and certification of own operations to ISO 9001. Moreover, its recalls per unit sales averaged 37.8% over FY 2019-2021 (33.9% industry average, as of November 2022).Mazda continues to trail industry peers in mitigating risks related to tailpipe GHG emissions. It has so far launched just one electric vehicle (EV)--a 100-mile range car launched primarily in regions such as Europe and California where regulations force automakers to sell EVs. This may also limit its ability to capitalize on growth opportunities in clean mobility.

Kumagai Gumi Co.,Ltd. (Kumagai Gumi) has been upgraded to 'A' from 'BBB'. The Whistleblower Protection Key Metric under the Business Ethics Key Issue was modified. The company disclosed a policy that provides whistleblowers with protection from retaliation, which contributed to the upgrade. The company's safety management also remains on par with that of most leading peers. Our research notes improvements in the company's governance practices. Post its 2021 AGM, we no longer flag the company for significant votes against directors.Kumagai Gumi's diverse operations in heavy and general construction services may expose it to risks tied to occupational hazards. It has adopted practices to mitigate related risks, including COHSMS certification and a centralized management system. Total recordable injury rate for FY2020 was 0.32 per million hours, lower than industry average (3.19 Q2 2022)Its capabilities in heavy construction presents opportunities to adopt clean technologies. In addition to solar and hydroelectric plant construction, Kumagai Gumi has adopted policies to develop clean technologies, particularly in waste management and recycling. Yet, these only constitute 2.8% of revenues n FY2020, below the industry average of 12.82% (Q2 2022)The heavy construction industry typically involves large-scale contracts and bidding processes which may expose the company to corruption and bribery risks. It has adopted a business ethics framework which includes whistleblower protection and staff training on ethics standards, which may help mitigate related risks

ESG_HEADLINE: Improvements on responsible minerals sourcing initiatives and talent management programs
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: LITE-ON has been upgraded to 'AA' from 'A'. Our recent assessment found new evidence of conflict mineral tracing and talent management programs by the company; this drives the upgrade. LITE-ON's vast range of electronic products may contain minerals such as tin, tungsten, tantalum, and gold (3TG), which may pose regulatory risk if sourced from conflict regions. Like leading peers, LITE-ON has a conflict minerals policy and supply chain due diligence measures such as smelter-level monitoring and origin tracing.LITE-ON relies on highly skilled talent to support its R&D projects, and may thus face talent attraction and retention challenges. The company leads peers in talent management programs. In FY 2021, LITE-ON introduced an employee shareholding scheme, along with its current suite of non-compensatory benefits, to help attract talent. We also found evidence of talent pipeline development programs and formal grievance mechanisms that may help mitigate talent retention risks.The company has moderate opportunities to capitalize on clean technology, per our model. LITE-ON has detailed quantitative targets on its R&D investments focused on a number of industry cleantech trends in 5G, AI, IoT, and energy-efficient power supply products.LITE-ON's corporate governance practices are average compared with those of global and home-market peers. While the board has an independent majority, it is potentially entrenched with two members having served the board for more than 15 years (as of May 2022); this may hinder management oversight.

PT MNC's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. Our research found PT MNC has policies on anti-retaliation protection for whistleblowers. However, it still lags global peers in business ethics management; we found no evidence of measures such as ethics audits and staff training. Also, it trails global peers in corporate governance, primarily owing to weaknesses in its board and ownership structure. PT MNC also lags industry peers in data security management. On the upside, it has above average labor management performance relative to peers.As of August 2022, PT MNC's supervisory board lacked majority independence and was undersized. Further, it is led by a chair, who previously served as the company's CEO. This--coupled with the presence of a controlling shareholder (PT Global: 52.7% voting power, as of August 2022)--may limit management oversight and lead to subordination of minority shareholders' interests. Moreover, its limited disclosures on executive pay impede peer comparison.Its broadcasting services face limited cybersecurity risks owing to low exposure to consumer-sensitive data--unlike pure-play streaming players. That said, we note no breach mitigation measures in its data privacy framework or evidence of external data security certifications which warrant IT system audits.As a TV and radio broadcaster based in Indonesia--where incidence of labor discord is low (per our model), PT MNC's exposure to labor-related challenges is limited. Yet, we note robust employee incentivization plans--featuring stock benefits--and upskilling programs in its framework.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improved talent management initiatives and ESG integration into lending activities
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Hua Nan Financial has been upgraded to 'AA' from 'A'. Improvements in ESG practices to mitigate environmental risks in lending activities largely contributed to the upgrade. Further, while commercial loans accounted for 60% of Hua Nan Financial's (HNF's) loan portfolio (FY 2021), it has moderate exposure to environmentally intensive industries. Also, its bank subsidiary is now an Equator Principles signatory (June 2022). We also note improvements in its talent management initiatives and efforts towards financial inclusion of underserved markets.HNF offers internships to college students and provides development opportunities to staff. These may help mitigate potential challenges in recruitment and retention, given its reliance on skilled workforce.Inclusion of the Corporate Behavior Theme in our Governance assessment led to a greater emphasis on HNF's business ethics practices, which lead those of home market peers. It has a detailed anti-corruption policy backed by whistleblower protection to help prevent potential unethical business conduct. Its corporate governance practices are average relative to global peers; its executive pay disclosures appear aligned with shareholder interests.HNF continues to lead industry peers on Consumer Financial Protection which focuses on efforts to preempt potential mis-selling of financial products. While it adopts certain industry-best practices such as product reviews, it seems to lack a debt collection policy. Refer to the ESG Rating Drill Down and dedicated Consumer Financials Protection sections of the report for more details.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improvements in workforce management programs
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Mega Financial has been upgraded to 'AA' from 'A'. The upgrade is driven by improvements in Mega Financials' (MF) staff management programs such as talent development and grievance handling. Its three-year average employee turnover of ~4.7% (2019-2021) was lower than the industry average of 10%. Commercial loans comprised 74% of MF's loan portfolio in FY2021; it adopts ESG due diligence in its lending activities. Further, the company became a signatory of the Equator Principles in FY 2021 and invested ~USD 300 million in green bonds.MF's corporate governance is average compared to global peers. While it has an independent majority board, it lacks disclosures on executive pay which may not align with investors' long-term interests. The inclusion of the Corporate Behavior Theme in the Governance assessment resulted in a greater emphasis on its business ethics practices. MF appears to lag global peers in conducting audits of its ethics standards.Methodology enhancements to the Consumer Financial Protection Key Issue resulted in reassessment of MF's initiatives to preempt potential unethical lending of financial products. Though it has transparent lending policies and a hotline for handling complaints, we found limited evidence of debt collection policies, which may help protect consumer interests.MF's performance on Privacy and Data Security (PDS)--which focuses on its ability to safeguard sensitive data--has improved since the last rating action and leads industry peers. Refer to the ESG Rating Drill Down and dedicated PDS sections of the report for more details.

TS Tech has been upgraded to 'BBB' from 'B'. Improved warranty performance drives the upgrade. TS Tech's warranty expenses to sales ratio for FY 2020 was 0.03% (vs. industry average of 0.81%, as of February 2022) compared to a prior three-year (FY 2016-2019) average of 0.50%. Further, the company's product quality assurance framework is on par with that of leading industry peers. Also, TS Tech has strong labor initiatives; however, it trails most global peers on corporate governance.TS Tech's operations are based in Japan and the US, where ILO data indicates low-to-moderate incidence of labor discord. It thus faces lower risks of operational disruptions from labor unrest. We also note initiatives such as engagement surveys and equity grants for employees to further mitigate such risks.We note related-party transactions with the largest shareholder, in absence of a fully independent audit committee. This may raise concerns for other investors. Further, limited disclosures on executive pay, in absence of a fully independent pay committee, may warrant investor scrutiny on pay practices. TS Tech is on par with global peers on ethics practices; notable initiatives include board-level oversight.TS Tech manufactures seats and interior trims. It thus has fewer clean technology opportunities relative to makers of electric vehicle-specific parts. Besides, a three-year (FY 2018-20) average R&D/sales ratio of 3.38% (industry average of 4.24% as of February 2022) may indicate limited capacity for innovation.

Sinochem has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'B'. The upgrade reflects improvements in Sinochem's corporate governance, which is average relative to global peers. Reported related-party transactions with the controlling owner appear to have decreased between FY 2020 and FY 2021. Further, Sinochem's business ethics framework is supported by ethics training for employees and a policy to protect whistleblowers from retaliation. We also note a strong water withdrawal performance relative to peers.Sinochem's production of industrial organic chemicals may pose the risk of increased input costs and operational disruption in the event of water shortage. We note the company reported a water recycling rate of 92% in FY 2021. Moreover, its freshwater withdrawal intensity of 2,462 m3/million USD sales was well below the average (12,159) for the Diversified Chemicals industry (constituents of the MSCI ACWI Index) as of October 2022.The company's operations are generally carbon intensive and could expose Sinochem to potential compliance costs.
