While the company has measures to enhance its operational energy efficiency, we found limited information on its use of clean energy for its operations.With stringent chemical regulations in China (57% of FY 2021 revenue), Sinochem has high exposure to potential reformulation costs. Yet, it lags peers in instituting strong chemical safety management practices; we found no evidence of plans to phase out all potential hazardous chemicals.

ESG_HEADLINE: Governance continues to trail those of global peers; limited efforts to manage social risks
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Fiberhome's rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. The company continues to trail global peers in corporate governance. Further, it lags most industry peers on talent management initiatives. Fiberhome relies on skilled talent to stay apace with rapid technological advancements in the telecommunications equipment field. However, we found no evidence of robust upskilling programs aimed at developing talent or engagement initiatives that could gauge employee wellbeing and satisfaction. Also, the company trails peers on mineral tracing initiatives.Based on our model, China's increased reliance on imports of metals classified as conflict minerals (tin, tungsten, tantalum, and gold) may expose Fiberhome to reputational risks if such materials are sourced from conflict areas. However, our research found no evidence of mineral tracing programs to mitigate such risks.We note an increase in related-party transactions (FY 2020: 6.63% vs. FY 2021: 7.81% of expenses) with its controlling shareholder (Chinese government: 42.2% of voting rights as of May 2022); this, combined with the lack of an independent audit committee, may pose governance risks for minority investors. Further, limited disclosures on its executive pay practices may impede peer comparison.As a state-owned entity and communications equipment manufacturer that typically engages with mobile and broadband operators, the company has high exposure to corruption-related risks per our model. Yet, it appears to lack industry best practices such as regular training and audits on its business ethics framework.

Sinbon's rating is unchanged at 'A'. Our model suggests manufacturing connectors and cables is labor-intensive, exposing Sinbon to work disruption risks in case of labor unrest. Yet, it continues to lead peers in labor management. We found disclosures on engagement survey results that may aid in improving employee satisfaction. Also, its corporate governance practices are average relative to those of global and home-market peers. Its board is majority independent which may bolster oversight, though 5 of 11 directors are entrenched.Sinbon develops connection cables used in solar panels and wind power equipment and chargers for e-vehicles. Moreover, like leading peers, it has investment targets for its green energy business line. It appears to have dedicated 3.32% of FY 2021 revenue to research and development, with a focus on products supporting e-bikes.Cables and connectors may contain conflict minerals; this may lead to regulatory action or adverse impact on reputation for Sinbon if such minerals are traced to conflict-afflicted areas. It has industry-typical conflict mineral management programs. Its formal policy against conflict minerals is supported by efforts to survey suppliers.Sinbon derived all FY 2021 revenue from markets such as Taiwan, the US, and China, where strict regulations on chemical safety apply. This may present risks of product redesign costs. Despite this, Sinbon lags most peers in chemical safety practices. It appears to lack phase-out plans for potentially hazardous chemicals and we found no disclosures on product formulations.

ESG_HEADLINE: Overall improvement in ESG performance relative to peers drives the upgrade
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Sinopac Financial Holdings has been upgraded to 'AA' from 'A'. Sinopac's majority independent board and split CEO-chair roles may bolster management oversight. Its business ethics practices include whistleblower protection and policies against corruption and money laundering. Sinopac's loan book has low exposure to environmentally intensive industries (9% of FY 2021 loans). Further, its ESG due diligence mechanisms may help mitigate environmental risks. Moreover, Sinopac leads most peers in talent management practices.Sinopac's performances on Corporate Behavior and Corporate Governance--which focus on its efforts to prevent unethical behavior, and on its Ownership and Control Structure, Board Composition, Pay Practices, and Accounting Standards, respectively--have improved since the last assessment. Please refer to the ESG Rating Drill Down and dedicated Corporate Behavior and Corporate Governance sections for more details.Its performance on Human Capital Development--which focuses on its reliance on skilled workforce and on its ability to attract and retain talent--has improved since the last assessment. Please refer to the ESG Rating Drill Down and dedicated Human Capital Development sections for more details.Sinopac's performance on Financing Environmental Impact--which assesses the environmental risks of lending activities based on credit exposure to environmentally intensive industries--has improved since the last assessment. Please refer to the ESG Rating Drill Down and dedicated Financing Environmental Impact sections for more details.

Gamuda's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. Gamuda primarily operates in Malaysia and is involved in heavy construction activities where there are high incidences of fatalities and industrial injuries. The company has adopted practices that may help manage health and safety (H&S) risks such as ISO45001 certification and contractor oversight. However, it lags leading peers in linking H&S performance to executive pay. We also note limited evidence of consolidated, groupwide H&S data in reporting, which impedes comparison with peersGamuda's diversified operations, including water and highway concessions, presents limited opportunities to adopt clean technologies, compared to construction-focused peers. While the company is involved in the construction of wastewater treatment plants and of buildings certified to green building standards, we note limited evidence of targets to increase investments in and development of clean technologies.Gamuda's corporate governance practices lag those of global peers. Its board lacks an independent majority and has three potentially entrenched directors who have served more than 29 years. This may limit the board's ability to provide independent management oversight.The heavy construction industry typically involves large-scale contracts and bidding processes which may pose bribery and corruption risks. We note the company has adopted a strong business ethics framework through board-level oversight of ethics standards, and regular audits.

The Gunma Bank has been downgraded to 'BB' from 'BBB'. The Gunma Bank's downgrade is driven by lagging data protection practices relative to industry peers. It generated 100% revenue in FY 2021 from Japan, where privacy laws are stringent. However, in our reassessment, we found no evidence of IT system audits which may help prevent potential security incidents. Further, the bank's commercial loans constituted ~57% of loans in FY 2021; however, it lags industry peers in adopting ESG practices that may help mitigate environmental risks in its lending.Like its banking peers, the Gunma Bank relies on skilled staff and may, thus, face risks of attrition. However, it lags peers in workforce management practices--in our reassessment, we found no evidence of grievance reporting procedures for employees which may help mitigate potential workplace issues.Retail loans constituted ~43% of the bank's total loans in FY 2021; this may expose the bank to risks tied to potential mis-selling of financial products. While the bank adopts certain industry-best practices for financial protection of consumers, we found no evidence of transparent lending policies which may help protect consumer interests.The bank lags most global peers on corporate governance, notably ownership. We found limited disclosures on executive pay which impedes peer comparison. Further, its business ethics practices are average relative to global peers, and include offer of whistleblower protection.

ESG_HEADLINE: Lags peers in environmental and chemical safety management practices
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: TKG Huchems' rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. The company's chemical safety management practices continue to trail those of peers. It derived 82% of its FY 2021 revenue from South Korea, where chemical safety regulations are stringent; this exposes the company to potential reformulation costs. Yet, unlike with better-performing peers, we found no evidence of a formal strategy to phase out potentially hazardous chemicals. Further, the company's practices to mitigate environmental risks continue to lag those of its peers.Production of nitrogenous chemicals exposes companies such as TKG Huchems to the risk of incurring environmental liabilities tied to toxic emissions and waste. While we note the company has provisions for regular environmental audits, TKG Huchems, unlike leading peers, appears to lack quantitative targets to reduce key air pollutants (NOx/SOx) from its operations.The water-intensive nature of nitrogenous chemicals production exposes TKG Huchems to risks related to water scarcity. However, its water management practices appear limited. We found no evidence of water risk assessment schemes and use of alternative water sources, practices common to leading peers.TKG Huchems is controlled by the Park family (holding 29.3% of voting power) via a stock pyramid structure, and has reported related-party transactions involving the controlling shareholder. The company's board also lacks an independent majority and leadership; this may pose concerns regarding the potential subordination of the interests of minority investors.

Hanall has been downgraded to 'B' from 'BB'. Like pharma peers, Hanall is exposed to employee-centered risks due to its reliance on a highly skilled workforce. Our expanded assessment of its talent management initiatives indicates the company lags most peers in implementing robust staff management programs such as employee engagement channels and adopting a grievance redressal mechanism--practices that may help mitigate talent retention challenges. Further, Hanall lags global peers on corporate governance.Hanall's board lacks an independent director majority and has multiple executives; while typical of Korean firms, this may hinder its ability to provide independent management oversight. Further, related-party transactions (13% of expenses, FY 2019 to 17%, FY 2020) with the controlling owner may increase risks for minority shareholders. On the upside, Hanall's business ethics practices, which include certification to the ISO 37001 standard, lead those of most domestic peers.As a manufacturer of drugs for human use, Hanall is exposed to reputational risks from potential product quality lapses. Its quality framework is on par with that of peers, and features supplier monitoring and in-house testing. However, we found evidence of five minor (Class III) and three moderate (Class II) product recalls from January 2019 to April 2022.Presence in Korea (99% revenue, FY 2020) positions Hanall to capitalize on growth opportunities in emerging markets. Yet, it lags peers in adopting programs to help improve access to healthcare in the region.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improvements in community relations while weaknesses in governance practices still persist
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Western Mining has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'B'. Western Mining has adopted policies to support indigenous people, and human rights, and is actively involved in local community development through promotion of infrastructure and local hiring. Further, improvements in its business ethics, such as evidence of anti-corruption measures and a no-corruption policy for suppliers, together have driven the rating upgrade. However, we found limited evidence of its efforts in biodiversity management and ecosystem restoration programs.Though the company's corporate governance practices are average compared to those of global peers, we found weaknesses in its board structure and pay practices. Its board lacks an independent majority and an independent chair. Further, we note related-party transactions with the state, which holds 30% of voting rights (Oct' 2021).With all operations in China (FY 2021), where ILO data indicates high frequency of occupational accidents, the company has high exposure to risk of workplace incidents and related operational disruptions. Although it has a group-wide safety policy, and certification to the ISO 18001 standard, it trails peers in having safety targets and linking its performance to executive pay.The company has high exposure to risk of environmental liabilities linked to mine wastes due to its metal extraction operations. However, it outperforms industry peers with certification to environmental management standards such as ISO 14001 and programs to monitor environmental performance and related reduction targets.

We initiate coverage of Shanxi Coal International at 'B'. Shanxi Coal International is a coal mining and trading company in China. Due to its significant mineral trading segment (FY 2021: 49% of revenue), our model indicates the company's exposure to environmental risks, particularly related to carbon and toxic emissions, is lower than that of pureplay coal producers. Nevertheless, Shanxi Coal trails its peers on initiatives to mitigate such risks. In addition, its governance structures also appear to lag those of its global and home market peers.As a subsidiary of state-owned Shanxi Coal Import & Export Group (FY 2021: 60% voting rights), the company may be subject to increased scrutiny on business ethics practices. However, we found limited evidence of anti-corruption policies and compliance measures. Further, the presence of multiple government representatives on the board, and related-party transactions with its owner amid the lack of a fully independent audit committee could pose risks of subordination of minority shareholder interests.Companies that undertake coal mining may face the risk of operational disruptions in the event of accidents. Unlike with leading peers, we found no evidence of the company implementing incident reduction targets or of certification to recognized health and safety standards such as ISO 45001.Shanxi Coal International has an environmental management system with initiatives such as waste treatment and recycling to reduce its discharges. However, we found no disclosures on its performance data for NOx/SOx; this impedes peer comparison.

Riken Keiki has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'B'. We note improvements in the company's chemical safety controls that drive its on-par performance in chemical safety, thus contributing to the upgrade. Our research indicates efforts to monitor the use of chemicals in its products and inform customers of the same. However, the company lags global peers on corporate governance. Like most of its peers in Japan, the company's board lacks an independent majority and a fully independent audit committee for management oversight.Select device offerings from the company's product line may find applications in pollution monitoring. However, these do not appear to comprise its core offerings. Our research indicates the company trails peers in clean technology (cleantech) initiatives. We also found no dedicated strategy that targets expanding into cleantech-focused product lines.Measurement and detection devices contain minerals that may have been sourced from conflict regions. Riken Keiki lags industry peers in programs to trace the origins of minerals used in its products. Unlike leading industry peers, it appears to lack strong supplier due diligence and smelter monitoring efforts.Riken Keiki's exposure to labor management complexity is moderate due to a small workforce (FY 2020: 1,196 vs. ~32,000 industry average, as of June 2022) and majority operations in Japan, where labor unrest has been historically low. Like industry peers, it offers non-monetary benefits, including stock options and skills development opportunities.

VT HOLDINGS has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'B'. The upgrade reflects the reassessment in VT Holdings' labor management practices. Notably, the company offers training programs and severance pay to its employees. Also, improvements in its corporate governance practices such as the appointment of one female director at the 2021 AGM underpins the upgrade. However, despite these improvements, it lags most global peers on corporate governance.VT Holdings' board is entrenched: four of eight directors had tenures of over 15 years as of June 2021. This may impact the board's ability to provide effective oversight of management. Further, we found no evidence of anti-corruption policy and compliance measures such as regular audits and employee training on ethical standards.As an automotive retailer, VT Holdings manages many transactions and personal data, exposing it to regulatory and reputational risks tied to potential incidents of data breach or misuse. Unlike with better-performing peers, the company appears to lack proactive mitigating measures such as vulnerability assessments and penetration testing of its security systems.VT Holdings operates in Japan, where labor unrest cases are relatively low per ILO data. Further, its small workforce (3,667 vs. industry average of 81,204 as of Apr 2022) entails lower labor complexity. While it offers non-pay benefits and training to retain staff, these do not seem to be extended to the entire workforce.

Heiwado's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. As a food retailer, Heiwado may face regulatory and reputational risks in case of food safety lapses. The company's quality assurance measures are average relative to those of peers, and include periodic supplier and raw material audits, and certification to HACCP standards for some operations. Although Heiwado's corporate governance practices are average relative to those of global peers, we note weaknesses in its board composition.Heiwado has low exposure to labor-related risks, given its small workforce (5,324 in FY 2021 vs. 158,542 industry average as of January 2022) and operations in Japan, where our model indicates low incidence of work stoppages. The company's labor management programs are in line with peers, and include non-statutory benefits and training programs to help boost productivity.Online and in-store transactions entail the collection of customers' personal information; this exposes the company to risks tied to potential data breaches. Heiwado's privacy framework is average relative to that of peers. While the company has a privacy policy that grants customers full digital control over their data, it appears to lack strong data protection measures, such as periodic system audits.While common in the Japanese market, the company's lack of a majority independent board may limit oversight of management. Also, despite calls to increase gender diversity in boards of companies in Japan, Heiwado had not appointed a female director as of May 2022.

ESG_HEADLINE: Continues to trail peers across ESG Key Issues
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Shenergy has been downgraded to 'CCC' from 'B'. While China has tightened norms on toxic releases in its 14th five-year plan, temporary power shortage and restrictions on electricity use in some regions in 2021 and 2022 may add complexities in managing priorities. Shenergy (53% owned by Shanghai municipality) lags peers in toxic releases management. We note a breach of NOx release cap set by the government at one of Shenergy's thermal plants to ensure power supply to the city (it supplied one-third of Shanghai's electricity in 2021).Despite China's targets of carbon peak by 2030 and carbon neutrality by 2060, Shenergy's carbon emissions management measures seem limited. We found no evidence of quantitative target, unlike with leading peers. Also, no disclosure of GHG emissions impedes peer comparison.Shenergy continues to lag global peers on corporate governance. Its former CEO (May 2017-Mar 2022) remains on the board as non-executive deputy chair. His previous ties to management may adversely impact board independence. We also note relatively high related-party transactions with the controlling owner: these accounted for 20.5% of FY 2021 revenue. Further, absence of disclosures on pay details hinders peer comparison.Thermal and nuclear power generation (~74% of FY 2021 total installed capacity) may rely on water for cooling. This could pose the risk of operational disruptions in case of water shortages. Shenergy lags peers on water use management. Unlike with leading peers, we found no disclosures on quantitative targets or water use programs.

ESG_HEADLINE: Trails peers in preparedness to address most potential ESG challenges
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: We initiate coverage of Intops at 'CCC'. As a manufacturer of mobile parts and plastic products, Intops processes a range of materials and plastics in its complex manufacturing process; this exposes it to unique ESG risks in the Technology Hardware industry. Generation of toxic byproducts may adversely impact health and property, and may expose Intops to related regulatory risks. Also, though handling mechanical, electrical, and heat solutions may expose Intops to safety hazards, its risk mitigation measures seem limited.Intops trails most global peers on corporate governance due to weakness in its board structure--it lacks an independent majority. We note the presence of several executives, and a family firm director is the CEO-chair. This, along with the absence of key committees (pay and audit), may impede management oversight. Further, limited pay disclosures may hinder peer comparison on pay performance. Also, Intops trails peers on corporate behavior: it seems to lack an overarching business ethics framework to mitigate corruption risks.As a developer of mobile cases and plastic molds, Intops' reliance on skilled talent is lower than that of technology hardware peers involved in developing advanced computing machines. The company's workforce management initiatives are average compared to those of peers. It offers a strong suite of benefits including insurance, childcare, and performance-based incentive programs. However, its upskilling opportunities and engagement initiatives appear limited relative to those of peers.

Izumi's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. A small workforce (4,399 in FY 2021 vs. industry average of 87,619 as of October 2022) and operations in Japan (100% revenue in FY 2021)--where the likelihood of labor unrest is low, as per our model--suggest its exposure to risk of operational disruptions due to potential labor complexities, common to the retail sector, is lower for Izumi than for peers. The company's corporate and business ethics practices trail those of global and home-market peers.Izumi's labor management practices are above average relative to those of industry peers. The company offers non-statutory benefits to all employees and conducts training programs and engagement surveys--measures that may help retain talent, enhance productivity, and monitor satisfaction, respectively.As a retailer operating solely in Japan, where privacy and data security regulations are stringent per our model, Izumi could face regulatory and reputational risks in case of a data breach. While the company trains employees on data handling, its information security management systems do not appear to have certification to globally accepted standards, such as ISO 27001, unlike those of leading peers.Izumi's board is potentially entrenched, with two directors serving for more than 15 years (as of September 2022). This may limit its ability to support management oversight. On business ethics, while the company has a policy on whistleblower protection against retaliation, we found no evidence of regular audits of ethics standards.

JAC Recruitment (JAC) has been upgraded to 'A' from 'BBB'. Improvements in JAC's corporate governance practices drove the upgrade. The addition of four new independent directors and establishment of a fully independent pay committee in 2022 may bolster oversight of management and executive pay practices. However, the family-owned firm has a co-founder and a former CEO serving as directors on the board; this may present leadership concerns. JAC's corporate governance practices are average relative to those of global peers.While JAC's staffing solutions involve collecting jobseekers' sensitive data, it operates in regions (e.g., Japan, Europe), where data privacy laws are stringent. Its privacy policy provides full digital rights, including deletion of data, to customers. JAC has industry-typical information security systems that are certified to PrivacyMark standards that mandate regular data system audits and staff training on cybersecurity.JAC's corporate behavior policies consist of whistleblower protection mechanisms. However, unlike with peers, we found no evidence of robust programs such as a formal anti-corruption policy or regular audits of ethics standards.Although JAC lags peers in workforce programs, its exposure to staff management complexity is low; this is because its operations are less labor-intensive, and in countries where incidence of labor unrest is low as per our model.  While we note JAC has performance incentivization mechanisms, we found no evidence of engagement initiatives to monitor employee satisfaction.

BIPROGY's rating is unchanged at 'AA'. Biprogy leads home market peers on corporate governance, notably on ownership and board structures. The board now has an independent majority with the addition of a director in June 2022. Its workforce management efforts also lead those of industry peers. Further, Biprogy's data security framework is average relative to those of industry peers, notably with its transmission encryption protocols and access control techniques. However, it lags home-market peers in business ethics practices.Biprogy has a mix of IT offerings--it provides digital transformation services, consulting, software solutions, hardware devices, and IT support services. It has relatively less custody of personal data than other data processing peers, and thus has a moderate exposure to privacy-related risks (per our model). Nevertheless, we note strong security measures such as executive oversight and staff training on cybersecurity; this could preempt potential data breaches and misuse.Strong competition for skilled talent in the software and consulting industry, exposes Biprogy to potential talent management issues. We note evidence of strong workforce management practices such as engagement channels and upskilling programs.The presence of split CEO and chair roles may enhance management oversight. The company follows the 'one share one vote' principle that helps align economic exposure and voting power of shareholders. However, we found no evidence of industry-best business ethics measures such as executive oversight or external audits.

DJK Group's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. We continue to note limited evidence of programs for employee safety and strategies to capitalize on the clean technology (cleantech) market. DJK Group's overall governance practices are on par with those of its home market peers. Yet, it appears to lack strong business ethics compliance controls such as groupwide audits and ethics training as adopted by leading global peers. Further, its board does not have an independent majority; this may limit effective management oversight.According to US OSHA, workplace safety-related risks are relatively low for machinery trading companies such as DJK Group, unlike companies with manufacturing capacities. The company is bound by local safety laws and standards in Japan. However, evidence suggests, DJK Group, unlike leading peers, lacks programs to monitor lost time injury and fatality rates, making it challenging to evaluate its safety performance versus peers.Our research indicates companies engaged in the industrial products trading business have limited opportunities to benefit from the growing demand for clean technologies. While DJK Group has been expanding its renewable energy generation systems (e.g., biomass, solar), fuel cell systems, and industrial automation technology offerings, our research found limited evidence of targets to expand its cleantech portfolio.

AEON DELIGHT's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. Aeon Delight lags global peers in corporate governance. The board lacks independent majority and has combined a CEO-chair; this may limit management oversight. Related-party transactions (42% of revenue as of Feb 2022) with the controlling shareholder who held 55% of voting power (in Oct 2022) may warrant minority stakeholder scrutiny. Its business ethics practices are average relative to global peers. While it offers whistleblower protection, we found no evidence of an anti-corruption policy.The company operates in Japan, where our model suggests incidence of labor unrest is low. However, as a facilities management services company, Aeon Delight's operations are labor-intensive. This may pose labor management-related risks. Unlike with leading peers, we found no evidence of performance-based incentives--a measure that may help retain talent.Our model indicates facilities management companies typically have low exposure to risks of operational disruptions tied to workplace accidents. Aeon Delight's health and safety (H&S) practices have risk officer oversight, and it has a groupwide H&S policy. However, it lags peers in adopting strong practices such as providing detailed disclosures on H&S data and adopting international certifications such as ISO 45001.

ESG_HEADLINE: Subpar toxic emissions and health and safety performance
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: ACC's rating is unchanged at 'B'. The rating reflects ACC's relatively limited measures to mitigate key ESG risks relative to peers. In particular, the company's toxic emissions reduction and health and safety performance trail those of industry peers. It also lags better-performing peers in adopting strong labor management programs such as performance bonuses. Further, weaknesses in ACC's corporate governance, particularly in its board and ownership structures, continue to weigh on its governance score.ACC's cement manufacturing operations may pose risks of liabilities and compliance costs related to toxic releases. While the company has ISO 14001 certification, its NOx (6.0 t/USD million) and SOx (1.4 t/USD million) intensities in FY 2021 were higher than the averages (NOx: 4.4; SOx: 0.8) for the construction materials industry (constituents of MSCI ACWI index), as of December 2021.ACC has adopted groupwide safety policies that include contractors and has acquired OHSAS 18000 certification for some of its operations. However, as a cement producer, the company's exposure to risk of worksite accidents remains high with operations in India, where our research indicates occupational incidents have been historically high.ACC is controlled by LafargeHolcim Ltd (54.5% voting rights, July 2022). Moreover, we note related-party transactions (RPTs) with its controlling owner. This, along with the absence of a fully independent audit committee, may limit oversight on RPTs and pose risk of subordination of minority investor interests.

Royal Holdings' rating is unchanged at 'BB'. Royal Holdings' restaurant operations offer take-out and delivery services, which typically use single-use packaging and cutlery. Yet, despite stringent packaging waste regulations in Japan, it lags peers in adopting sustainable packaging initiatives. The water-intensive nature of hotel operations (FY 2020: 32% of total assets) may pose operational risks to Royal Holdings. Yet, unlike leading peers, it appears to lack robust water management programs and quantitative reduction targets.Royal Holdings lags global peers in governance practices. It appears to lack a detailed business ethics policy. We also note it was involved in cross-shareholdings with related parties in FY 2020; this could potentially undermine minority shareholders' interests. Yet, it now has a majority independent board following the appointment of three new directors at the 2022 AGM.Our reassessment of Royal Holdings' food safety measures indicates it has relatively strong quality assurance measures to address associated risks for its restaurant operations and food business (83% of total revenues in FY 2020). It provides food handling and hygiene management training for staff and conducts routine supplier audit.The company has relatively low exposure to labor unrest risks as it operates solely in Japan (FY 2020), where the likelihood of labor unrest is low as per ILO data. Its efforts to address such risks lead those of peers. It offers non-statutory benefits and conducts engagement survey to retain staff and monitor workplace satisfaction.

Megaworld's rating is unchanged at 'B'. The company continues to lag global peers on governance practices. Possible board entrenchment, as 3 of its 7 directors have served for over 20 years, may create the potential for a management friendly board. Moreover, we found poor disclosure on executive pay. We also note unequal voting rights due to multiple share classes. These factors could pose the risk of potential subordination of minority shareholders' interests. Further, Megaworld's green investment programs lag those of most peers.Methodology enhancements to the Corporate Behavior Theme resulted in a greater emphasis on business ethics practices and on exposure to risks related to corruption. Megaworld has high exposure to these risks, based on historical trends for property developers. Yet, its anti-corruption measures lag those of peers; we found no evidence of audits or employee training to strengthen adherence to ethics standards.Despite the inherent risk of operational disruptions related to work-related accidents in the property development industry, Megaworld appears to lack mechanisms to enhance occupational safety. Unlike most peers, it appears to lack a robust health and safety framework to mitigate workplace hazards.Megaworld appears on par with peers in adopting initiatives to enhance its build quality. Though the company appears to lack supplier certification and employee training programs on quality assurance, evidence suggests that its property development and marketing operations are certified to the ISO 9001 quality standard.

ESG_HEADLINE: Strong ESG integration in financing activities; but continues to face controversies.
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Nomura's rating is unchanged at 'AA'. Nomura continues to lead peers in ESG risk integration in its financing activities. Its screening and due diligence processes include position statements aimed at assessing risks for environmentally sensitive sectors, including energy, oil and gas, mining, and agriculture. While its governance practices are on par with peers, recurring controversies related to business ethics and anti-competitive practices may indicate potential gaps in its policies and oversight.Although Nomura has an independent board majority, we note a director received negative votes in excess of 10% at its 2022 AGM. Nomura's internal audit function conducts assessments on its internal control of anti-bribery and corruption. However, it has faced regulatory investigations over actions related to the sell-off of Archegos Capital Management in 2021, as well as alleged bond manipulation and currency manipulations in 2020; these may suggest potential gaps in implementation of its ethics framework.Nomura continues to lead peers in responsible investment initiatives. Its asset management arm is signatory to the UN Principles for Responsible Investment, and integrates ESG risk management in its investing activities through active ownership-engagement, proxy voting, and external manager selection.Nomura relies on highly skilled talent with its investment banking operations. Nevertheless, its continued focus on hiring strategies and training and development programs may help mitigate talent management risks.

We initiate coverage of Nippon Parking at 'BB'. Our research indicates the company's performance on key ESG parameters lags that of industry peers. Nippon Parking's business line-- of managing parking facilities (60% FY 2020 revenue), and ski resorts and theme parks (37% FY 2020 revenue) exposes it to a moderate level of risks related to employee management and workplace safety. However, its policies to address these risks appear limited, with no best practices identified. Further, its governance performance trails those of global peers.Nippon Parking is a founder firm, with the controlling shareholder (founder- Mr. Kazuhisa Tatsumi) holding around 35% voting rights. We note recurring related-party transactions with the controlling shareholder, which, in the absence of independent oversight mechanisms, may warrant investor scrutiny. Further, its efforts to monitor business conduct appear to be limited compared to industry peers. We did not find evidence of a detailed anti-corruption policy or staff training on business conduct.Nippon Parking relies on a seasonal workforce for its parking facility operations. With the company's plans to expand its geographical footprint outside of Japan, it may face challenges in complying with labor policies in multiple locations. The company's performance on staff management programs lags peers. While it provides robust compensation schemes including employee stock purchase plans and non-pay benefits-the scope of these provisions is unknown.

ESG_HEADLINE: Adopted new GHG reduction targets; trails peers in corporate governance practices.
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: PTT's rating is unchanged at 'A'. PTT leads industry peers in demonstrating strong performance metrics in GHG emissions intensity, fatalities, and injury rate. In FY 2021, PTT set a new target of absolute scope 1 and 2 GHG reduction by 15% by FY 2030 over FY 2020 levels. The company also aims to be carbon neutral by FY 2040 and achieve net zero GHG emissions by FY 2050, which is an ambitious target compared to the national target of Thailand. On the governance front, PTT trails global market peers.As an integrated oil and gas operator, PTT is exposed to the risk of incurring liabilities linked to toxic air pollutants and waste. Its three-year average SOx and NOx emissions intensity was significantly lower at 0.1 t/USD million and 0.2t/USD million, respectively (vs industry average of 0.66 and 0.89 t/USD million, as of June 2022).With ~45% of FY 2020 operations in refining and service station business, PTT appears moderately exposed to risks of ecosystem and community disturbances. It conducts environment impact assessments prior to commencing new operations; however, ongoing controversies, such as the Rayong oil spill, may indicate potential implementation gaps.In FY 2021, PTT was involved in related-party transactions (RPTs) with the government of Thailand (51% voting rights as of FY 2021). The absence of a fully independent audit committee may increase the potential risk tied to RPTs for minority investors. PTT lags most global peers in executive pay practices, with no detailed disclosures on executive pay.

Quality Houses has been downgraded to 'B' from 'BB'. A recent industry reassessment indicated a lower ESG performance score for Quality Houses, relative to its ESG industry peers, contributing to a downgrade (as of June 2022). Residential property development activities (92% of Quality Houses' FY 2021 revenue) generally entail risks of warranty costs in case of lapses in construction quality. The company appears to lack detailed quality assurance practices, such as third-party certification and training; this further contributes to the downgrade.Quality Houses continues to lag global peers on corporate governance. The company's board is not majority independent; this may impede management oversight. Further, the lack of a fully independent audit committee amid the presence of related-party transactions may pose associated governance risks for investors. Also, having a non-independent pay committee may increase risks tied to limited executive pay disclosures.The company demonstrates efforts to reduce waste and natural resource consumption in its property construction operations. However, it continues to trail industry peers in investing in green building certifications, which could aid in climate change mitigation and adaptation.Real estate developers may face operational disruptions and liabilities in case of work-related safety incidents. While Quality Houses has adopted a safety committee, we continue to find limited details on its worksite safety policies and programs.

Supalai has been downgraded to 'BB' from 'BBB'. A recent industry reassessment indicated a lower ESG performance score for Supalai, relative to those of its ESG industry peers, contributing to the downgrade (as of Sep 2022). The company lags industry peers in product safety and quality practices. It also trails in responsible marketing initiatives, such as providing related training to marketers and conducting a yearly audit. These factors have also contributed to the downgrade.Residential property developers may face warranty claims in the event of lapses in construction quality. Our assessment indicates Supalai lags its peers in implementing strong measures related to responsible marketing and disclosing its warranty payment information.Residential properties, which are generally less energy-intensive than office or retail assets, present limited opportunities to capitalize on the demand for green building. While we found evidence of Supalai undertaking initiatives to promote zero waste and reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 25% by 2024, the company lags its peers in level of green building certification in its portfolio.Supalai lags most global peers on corporate governance, as the board appears to be entrenched due to long-serving directors (60% as of FY 2021), which may not align with shareholder interests. Also, the board lacks an independent majority and an independent chair; this may limit management oversight.

ESG_HEADLINE: Overall ESG performance lags that of industry peers
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Sam Chun Dang Pharm has been downgraded to 'CCC' from 'B'. We have revised our evaluation of exposure to product safety and quality risks by removing a company-specific component which was based on the size of operations. This has resulted in an increase in the company's overall risk exposure, leading to the downgrade. It lags global peers in quality management and appears to lack commitment to responsible marketing. Yet, we note no recalls or regulatory warnings in the three years through July 2022. It lags global peers in governance practices.Sam Chun Dang Pharm has an undersized board with three of four directors as executives. Such a structure, in the absence of a pay committee, could impede oversight of management and executive pay. Further, the company's recurring involvement in related-party transactions (FY 2021: 5.6 % of revenue), without an audit committee to oversee such transactions, could pose governance risks for investors. Its ethics framework trails those of global peers and appears to lack robust mechanisms, such as regular audits of ethics standards.Like pharma peers, the firm relies on a highly skilled staff to support its R&D operations. Yet, unlike leading peers, it appears to lack performance appraisals and grievance channels--this could limit its ability to attract and retain a talented workforce.The firm's R&D portfolio consists of products for diseases such as diabetes--with unmet needs in emerging markets. Yet, we found limited evidence of efforts in instituting access to healthcare initiatives in underserved regions.

ESG_HEADLINE: Subpar water management programs and corporate governance practices relative to peers
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: We re-initiate coverage of Tingyi at 'BB'. Tingyi was reclassified in September 2022 from Packaged Foods & Meats to Soft Drinks industry. It derived 60% of its 2021 revenue from the sale of beverages such as tea and juice. As the production of these drinks, including agricultural inputs upstream, is water-intensive, Tingyi may face operational risks in case of water shortages. Yet, it lags peers in promoting water resilience in its operations, and its agricultural supply chain, which accounts for the bulk of its water footprint.Tingyi lags most global peers on corporate governance. Its board lacks independent majority and includes both executive chair and CEO. These factors, along with the company's controlled structure, may subordinate the interests of minority shareholders. We also note recurring related-party transactions with the controlling owner 12% and 10% of expenses in 2020 and 2021, respectively.Tingyi may face lower risk exposure to packaging waste as it operates fully in China (2021), where packaging regulation is perceived to be low as per our model.  While evidence suggests Tingyi uses environmentally-friendly packaging materials--an industry-typical practice--it appears to lack a robust strategy in tackling post-consumer packaging waste.Tingyi derived 38% of 2021 revenue from packaged food and could face regulatory and reputational risks tied to potential food safety lapses. Like leading peers, the company conducts supplier training and audits on food safety, and we found no major product recalls during the past year, as of August 2022.

ESG_HEADLINE: Corporate governance on par, trails peers in toxic emission management or setting reduction targets
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Shree Cement's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. The company remains on par with home market and global peers in corporate governance practices. We note the presence of a majority independent board and fully independent audit and pay committees that could aid in independent management oversight. However, 50% of the board is potentially entrenched, with long-serving members. This may impede the directors' independence in board deliberations. Further, it continues to lag peers on worksite safety management and pollution reduction programs.Cement manufacturing activities typically expose workforce to the risk of workplace accidents. Our assessment indicates Shree Cement, unlike leading peers, does not appear to have employee safety performance as a key performance indicator in deciding executive pay. Further, it reported two fatalities in FY 2020, which may indicate potential gaps in its safety mechanisms.Like peers, Shree Cement faces high risks of incurring costs and fines related to carbon and toxic emissions from its cement manufacturing operations. The company continues to focus on waste heat recovery and renewable power generation to reduce dependence on conventional energy sources. However, it continues to trail most peers in disclosing its total toxic emissions or setting robust toxic emission reduction targets.Shree Cement's labor management practices remain on par with those of its peers. We note its labor policies appear generally aligned to ILO conventions. Further, it provides non-monetary benefits to all employees, including contractors.

ESG_HEADLINE: Exposure to data privacy and security risks; strong talent-centered initiatives
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: TCS has been downgraded to 'A' from 'AA'. Our reassessment of TCS suggests higher exposure (per our model) to data privacy risks tied to its IT consulting and digital transformation services, which may involve handling sensitive client data. The company appears to lag leading peers in adopting industry best practices to mitigate the risk--driving the downgrade. On the upside, it leads most peers in talent-centered initiatives which may help attract and retain key employees amidst stiff competition for talent in the industry.TCS trails global and home peers in corporate governance due to a weakness in board structure that may undermine minority shareholder interest. With Tata Sons Ltd and Tata group of companies and trusts having control on ~72.3% voting rights in the company, minority shareholders will have limited influence on company decisions. Further, five of the nine board members have management ties which may limit board's independence.TCS has industry-typical measures to protect data such as access controls and encryption. However, it lags industry leaders in adopting best practices, such as an overarching data cybersecurity training that covers contractors and audit processes to check data security compliance of third-party partners that may mitigate data privacy risks.Like industry leaders, TCS appears to have strong talent pipeline development initiatives to support internal upward mobility and help meet its needs for qualified employees. Further, it conducts annual satisfaction surveys--an industry best practice.

Zee has been downgraded to 'B' from 'BB'. Our assessment of Zee's governance indicates potential weaknesses, driving the downgrade. The external auditor, Deloitte Haskins & Sells, issued a qualified opinion for the consolidated accounts for FYs 2020 and 2021 because of a put option agreement concluded by a Zee subsidiary, ATL Media. The auditor said the put option was subject to ongoing (FY 2021) legal proceedings and that it was unable to determine whether any related adjustment to the financial statements was required.Zee's management faced shareholder dissatisfaction over the merger with Sony Pictures Network India (December 2021). While our updated assessment indicates the company's business ethics practices are overseen by an executive committee and include staff trainings, Zee is being investigated by India's tax department for alleged non-payment of taxes as of January 2021.Zee operates primarily in India, where ILO data suggests risk of labor discord is high. Yet, we found limited evidence of engagement initiatives which could help monitor worker satisfaction and manage labor relations. Further, unlike the case of leading peers, Zee's compensation structures appear to lack non-pay and variable pay plans--measures that may help boost productivity.The company operates streaming services to leverage its digital content; the handling of customer data may pose risks related to data breach. Zee appears to lack measures such as periodic audits of information management systems and staff trainings, thus lagging industry leading peers.

ESG_HEADLINE: Average clean technology efforts relative to peers; lags most home peers on corporate governance
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: VIS has been downgraded to 'BB' from 'BBB'. Semiconductor companies such as VIS typically have moderate potential to capitalize on clean technology opportunities. The company's cleantech initiatives are average relative to those of industry peers. Unlike that of leading peers, VIS' strategic focus on cleantech markets seems limited, driving the downgrade. We found no evidence of a clear investment plan by the company to expand into specific cleantech markets. VIS lags most home-market peers on corporate governance.We note VIS has a combined CEO-chair role; this may impede management oversight. Also, the board is potentially entrenched: 3 (of 8) directors have held tenures of more than 15 years. This, along with the presence of one overboarded non-executive director, may limit the board's oversight capabilities. Further, the board lacks female director representation and a nomination committee.VIS' fabrication facilities are in Taiwan and Singapore, where water stress risks are perceived to be high. The company adopts quantitative targets and water use recycling programs. However, its water withdrawal intensity of 5,050 m3/USD million sales was higher than the industry average of 2,553 over FY 2019-21.Chips may contain minerals such as tin, tungsten, tantalum, and gold (3TG), which, if sourced from conflict regions, could expose VIS to reputational or regulatory risks. While the company requires suppliers to use RMAP-audited 3TG smelters or refiners, disclosures on related investigations seem to lack clarity, unlike those of leading peers.

SBS Group's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. SBS Group's exposure to labor management complexities may be low as it operates in Japan, where labor unrest has been historically low as per ILO data. It offers benefits such as educational subsidy. However, we found no disclosures on engagement efforts or performance-based incentives that may help boost employee satisfaction and productivity--unlike the case with leading peers. The company's business ethics framework, overseen by a board committee, is on par with that of global peers.SBS Group continues to lead peers in emission reduction amid stringent regulations in Japan. Its three-year GHG emissions averaged 42 tCO2/USD million sales (FY 2018-2020)--remaining below the industry average of 60, as of July 2022.Companies with ground logistics operations may face risk of work disruptions in the event of safety incidents. The company lags peers in adopting safety practices, such as contractor oversight and ISO 45001 certification. We also found no disclosures on lost time incident rates; this impedes performance comparison with peers.SBS Group continues to lag global peers in corporate governance, mainly on accounting practices. The company is flagged for potential issues related to auditor independence, considering the level of non-audit services provided by the external auditor and its tenure (over 20 years); this may limit their ability to provide independent opinion of financial reporting practices.

Malaysia Building Society has been upgraded to 'A' from 'BBB'. Improvement in corporate governance practices drove the upgrade--Malaysia Building Society (MBSB) leads global peers in board structure.  Unlike in our prior assessment, the bank has an independent pay committee (June 2022) and discloses executive pay practices which seem well aligned with shareholder interest. Improvement in talent management practices also supported the upgrade--its three-year average staff turnover was ~6.3% (2019-2021) vs. the industry average of 10% in the same period.Commercial loans constituted ~25% of MBSB's total loans in FY 2021, of which ~1% is exposed to environmentally intensive industries such as utilities. However, it lags industry peers in adopting sector-specific credit policies to assess ESG risks in its financing activities.MBSB's retail lending accounts for ~75% of total loans (FY 2021) which may expose the bank to risks of product mis-selling. While we found some evidence of transparent lending practices, it lags industry peers in undertaking robust initiatives such as product reviews, which may help protect consumer interests. Further, we noted an increase in consumer complaints by more than ~60% YoY in FY 2021.MBSB continues to lag global peers on the Corporate Behavior Theme, which focuses on the bank's efforts to prevent unethical behavior. We found no evidence of regular audits which may enable adherence to ethics standards. Please refer to ESG Rating Drill Down and the Corporate Behavior section of the report for details.

ESG_HEADLINE: Weak governance practices relative to peers
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: WCG's rating is unchanged at 'B'. The company's governance practices trail those of global peers. The controlling shareholder held 41.72% of voting power of WCG as of FY 2021. Combined with the lack of an independent majority board, this may result in subordination of interests of other shareholders. While WCG has adopted business ethics management practices such as whistleblower protection schemes and executive oversight of corporate conduct, we found no evidence of a detailed anti-corruption policy.As WCG derived 51% of its FY 2021 revenue from China, where stringent chemical safety regulations apply, the company faces exposure to potential reformulation costs. The company identifies all chemicals in its operations by means of safety data sheets and incorporates health and safety standards into product design. However, unlike leading peers, it appears to lack a formal plan to phase out potential hazardous chemicals.With operations in China, which aims for carbon neutrality by 2060, WCG is exposed to regulatory costs tied to carbon pricing. While we note the company has a target to reduce carbon emissions by 20% by 2025, we found limited evidence on provisions for use of renewable sources and measures to increase energy efficiency, unlike with leading peers.The company's water-intensive operations expose it to risks related to water scarcity. Like industry leaders, WCG's water management program features executive oversight. Further, it has a target to reduce water withdrawal intensity by 20% by 2025 (vs. 2016).

ESG_HEADLINE: Weakness perceived in corporate governance structure
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Zenrin has been downgraded to 'B' from 'BB'. As of June 2022, the board was considered entrenched, with 4 of 11 directors having had tenures of over 15 years with Zenrin. This along with typical home market characteristics--lack of independent majority board and executive pay disclosures--may not align well with shareholder interests. Further, we note no evidence of a nomination committee in its board--a structure that could aid in recruitment and succession planning for board and key executive roles. These contributed to the downgrade.To offer an extensive set of maps, Zenrin relies on technical and geospatial experts; it may thus face talent-related challenges. While we note evidence of incentivization schemes and upskilling support in its framework, these do not seem to cover all personnel. Also, for managing its talent recruitment, we found no evidence of talent pipeline development strategies.Zenrin collects and manages geospatial data to enable use cases of autonomous driving or developing platforms for EV solutions. Operations in Japan, where strict data laws apply, could expose it to regulatory risks in case of a data breach. It appears to have measures such as employee training and access control mechanisms in its cybersecurity framework; however, unlike leading peers, its IT systems seem to lack third-party certifications.Zenrin operates in Japan, where corruption levels are perceived to be low, based on our model; this drives its average Corporate Behavior score relative to global peers. Like peers, it seems to adopt ethics training programs.

Tohoku Electric's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. Revised methodology has resulted in a higher carbon emission exposure score for natural gas power generation (~22% of FY 2020 operations) and electric transmission and distribution segments (~40% of operations); this continues to expose Tohoku Electric to regulatory risks as Japan strengthens its target to reduce emissions by 46-50% below 2013 levels and obtain 36-38% renewable energy (RE) in the energy mix by 2030. The company lags peers on emissions management and renewable capacity.In FY 2020, Tohoku Electric generated ~86% of energy from fossil fuel sources and had a carbon emission intensity of 0.58 tCO2e/MWh (above the industry average of 0.42). The company aims to reduce its Scope 1 emissions by 50% by 2030 (vs. 2013 levels) by restarting its nuclear power generation. However, in May 2021, Tohoku Electric faced a lawsuit from a local community against restarting a nuclear power plant at Onagawa due to alleged lack of emergency evacuation plans.With ~69% of FY 2020 operations in electric power generation, Tohoku Electric has the potential to capitalize on opportunities in the RE market in Japan. However, its renewable capacity was only ~17% of the total capacity (2019-2021), notably lower than the industry average of 39%, as of September 2020. The company plans to add 2 GW of RE to the existing 2.6 GW by 2030.

Systena's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. As a software systems and solutions provider for varied purposes such as server virtualization and autonomous driving, Systena relies on skilled tech talent. This could expose the company to talent-related challenges. Further, operations in Japan--where strict data regulations apply--could expose Systena to regulatory and reputational risks in case of a breach. The company continues to trail peers on talent- and cybersecurity-related risk management.Relative to industry peers, Systena appears to have limited programs to support talent pool development. Its professional upskilling programs and employee benefits, which may help improve retention, lag those of industry leaders.Software solution providers typically handle limited end-user data relative to data processing peers; this may reduce Systena's exposure to cybersecurity risks. Relative to industry peers, the company appears to lack robust measures to help mitigate data privacy risks. We found no evidence of incident response plans or data access mechanisms.Systena lags global and home market peers on corporate governance, especially board structure. The board lacks majority independence and gender diversity; this could limit its independence and the diversity of views considered in deliberations. We found limited disclosures on its executive pay; this impedes peer comparison. On corporate behavior, it is on par with peers on efforts to mitigate corruption risks, with executive-level oversight and whistleblower provision.

We initiate coverage of Takaful Malaysia at 'BB'. The company has adopted strong policies and programs for managing the privacy and security of customer data; however, governance practices fall short of peers.Being an insurance company, Takaful Malaysia handles large volumes of customer data, exposing it to potential data security and privacy-related risks. The company exhibits robust data protection mechanisms aimed at safeguarding itself from data theft or breaches.Takaful Malaysia is highly reliant on a skilled workforce, thus elevating its talent attraction and retention challenges. The company has implemented strong channels to assess and enhance employee engagement such as leadership training and development as well as programs to improve workforce diversity.Takaful Malaysia's governance practices have been flagged for lack of executive compensation disclosures and controlling shareholder concerns. The company is controlled by the BIMB Holdings Berhad (holds 59.4% of the voting rights as of April 2020) that raises concerns of subordination of minority shareholder interests.

Security Bank has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'B'. Improvements in Security Bank's (SECB's) governance drive the upgrade. Our analysis of accounting practices in the Governance assessment no longer includes key metrics derived from accounting ratios and indicates limited risks compared with global peers. While we note its board is no longer potentially entrenched after changes in composition in FY 2021, the bank continues to lag global peers in corporate governance. A YoY decline of 31% in customer complaints in 2021 also supported the upgrade.The bank handles large volumes of sensitive personal data and is thus exposed to privacy-related risks. While we found no evidence of regular IT audits, unlike with leading peers, SECB conducts vulnerability assessments and uses encryption techniques that may help protect sensitive data.Commercial loans constituted ~77% of SECB's total loans in FY 2021, of which ~18% had high exposure to environmentally intensive industries such as utilities, as per our model. Yet, the bank lags peers in adopting ESG practices to help mitigate environmental risks in its lending activities.SECB's performance on Human Capital Development (HCD)--which focuses on the bank's reliance on a skilled workforce and its ability to attract and retain talent--has weakened since the last rating action. Unlike with industry peers, we found no evidence of leadership development programs for employees to help retain talent. Please refer to the ESG Rating Drill Down and dedicated HCD sections of the report for more details.

ESG_HEADLINE: Strong focus on green finance; increased consumer complaints
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Ping An Bank has been upgraded to 'BBB' from 'BB'. Ping An Bank demonstrated increased focus on green finance and has formulated a groupwide risk management system that incorporates regular assessment and field audit of environmental and social risks related to its commercial lending portfolio, along with the specified ESG risk assessment procedures. We also note the president's strategic oversight of the ESG risk management practices. This, combined with its marginally improved talent management practices, drove the upgrade.The bank adopts industry-standard efforts to channel funding to typically underserved groups. We note its inclusive small and enterprises lending (CBIRC definition) accounted for 12.5% of loan portfolio in 2021, and service agencies expanded in China's rural areas.The bank lags global peers in its governance practices. Its board lacks a majority independent of both management and other interests, or fully independent key committees; this may hinder management oversight. Despite having some business ethics policies (i.e., whistleblower protection), we note the bank's involvement in 15 alleged regulatory violations (of reporting inaccurate financial data) in March 2022.Although retail banking accounted for 62% of its operations in FY 2021, the bank lags peers in mitigating potential reputational and regulatory risks linked to consumer protection. While we note marginal improvement in board-level product review and consumer protection training to sales staff, complaints against the bank remained high in 2021.

ESG_HEADLINE: Weaknesses in corporate governance, notably board structure and accounting practices
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Walsin Lihwa has been downgraded to 'B' from 'BB'. Walsin Lihwa lags global peers on corporate governance. Methodology enhancements to the Governance Theme resulted in a greater emphasis on the additional governance risks posed by limited board independence. Its board is not majority independent of both management and other interests, and has no nomination committee; these have driven the downgrade. Also, non-audit fees paid to its external auditor exceeded audit-related fees in 2021; this may raise issues over auditor independence.Our reassessment of the company's operations indicates higher exposure to risks of environmental liabilities linked to potential toxic emissions. However, while we note it is on par with peers, we found limited evidence of facilities certified to ISO 14001 and robust emissions target to manage key pollutant streams.Based on our model, metal manufacturing may pose corruption-related risks. While we note the absence of board-level oversight of its ethics practices, Walsin Lihwa remains on par with global peers: its ethics framework is backed by regular audits and a detailed anti-corruption policy; this may help preempt unethical business transactions.A small workforce (6,995 employees in FY 2021 vs. industry average of 28,754 as of May 2022) limits the company's exposure to labor unrest risks and potential productivity challenges. Its labor management programs are on par with those of industry peers. It offers performance incentives and provides engagement channels to its staff; these may help sustain workforce satisfaction.

ESG_HEADLINE: Lags global peers in customer protection practices and talent management programs
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: MCB Bank has been downgraded to 'BBB' from 'A'. Methodology enhancements to the Consumer Financial Protection (formerly Financial Product Safety) Key Issue resulted in a reassessment of MCB Bank's (MCB's) management practices to preempt unethical lending and mis-selling of financial products to customers. Customer complaints increased 35% YoY in FY 2020 (>150,000), which may suggest gaps in policies addressing sales practices.  Nonetheless, we found evidence of a complaint resolution mechanism which may help protect consumer interests.Factoring in a more granular breakdown of MCB's loan portfolio, which has high exposure to environmentally sensitive industries (35.5% of total commercial loans, FY 2020) such as mining, tobacco, and chemicals, led to a decline in the bank's Financing Environmental Impact Key Issue Score. Further, the bank appears to lag peers in establishing an ESG due diligence framework to mitigate potential operational risks from its portfolio.MCB relies on a highly skilled workforce for its operations. The bank appears to trail global peers in talent management programs. We found limited evidence of initiatives such as non-pay benefits and support for professional certifications, to mitigate potential staff management risks.MCB has a majority independent board and a fully independent audit committee; this could aid in strong management oversight. Further, its executive pay practices appear well-aligned with sustainable shareholder interests. MCB's policies against bribery and corruption are generally in line with those of industry peers.

ESG_HEADLINE: Leads industry peers in governance framework and product quality management
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Livzon has been upgraded to 'AA' from 'BBB'. Drug manufacturing may present risks related to toxic byproducts. We found Livzon leads most peers in toxic management, with environmental management system (ISO 14001) covering all manufacturing sites. It also set up five-year targets (2021-2025) to reduce toxic emission and waste intensity. In addition, a recent industry reassessment indicated a higher ESG performance score for Livzon, relative to its industry peers, contributing to the upgrade (as of July 2022).Livzon leads home market peers on governance practices. The company has majority independent board. We found evidence of recurring related-party transactions with its controlling shareholder; however, the presence of a fully independent audit committee could help mitigate this risk. We found the company has established a business ethics risk control framework, with whistleblower protection and an anti-corruption policy.Drug manufacturing may pose product safety risks. Livzon leads peers in supplier quality risk management, and implemented practices such as quality trainings for key suppliers and regular supplier audits. Our research found no evidence of product recalls in the three years through June 2022.Livzon's talent management programs appear on par with those of peers. It has programs, such as stock incentives and employee engagement surveys, that may help attract and retain talent. However, we noticed the company's staff turnover rate (19.95% in FY21) was higher than that of most industry peers.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improved oversight of ESG risks drives upgrade, but continues to lag peers in governance
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Guoyuan Securities has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'CCC'. Guoyuan Securities' (Guoyuan's) upgrade is largely driven by its overall improvement in ESG performance relative to peers. It became a signatory to the UN Principles for Responsible Investment in 2021. The company aims to promote the integration of ESG investment concepts into all aspects of its operations and practices. However, we did not find evidence of investment mandates for integrating ESG principles into its portfolio. We also note improvements in its workforce management practices.Guoyuan relies on skilled professionals to manage its investment portfolio. We note the presence of training and development programs across different levels in the firm. However, it lags peers in adopting regular engagement surveys which could help it stay ahead of human capital challenges.Guoyuan continues to lag peers in corporate governance, particularly in ownership structure. The presence of related-party transactions with the controlling shareholder (35% of voting power as of 2021) presents governance risks. Further, limited disclosures on executive pay practices may not align with investor interests.While the company has set up an ESG management committee for overseeing relevant risks in its lending operations, we found no evidence that it integrates these principles into its due diligence processes. Further, the company trails peers in implementing credit policies for environmentally sensitive sectors; this exposes it to ESG risks in its lending portfolio.

Douzon Bizon's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. Douzone Bizon lags most global peers on corporate governance. While we note that its board is no longer undersized, the absence of an independent majority board and an independent chair and presence of several executives on the board may limit management oversight. Douzone Bizon's overall workforce management initiatives lag those of industry peers. Further, it appears to have a strong data security framework, compared to industry peers.While Douzone Bizon offers whistleblower protection, a measure that could help preempt potential unethical business practices, its overall business ethics policies and practices lag those of global peers. We found no evidence of monitoring mechanisms such as audits of ethics framework and compliance training for employees.With operations in a talent-intensive industry, the company may face challenges in recruitment and retention of skilled talent. Its career progression and talent development initiatives appear limited. Unlike with leading peers, we found no evidence of engagement initiatives such as formal communication channels and surveys to gauge employee satisfaction.With 100% operations (FY 2021) in regions with stringent privacy regulations such as South Korea, Douzone Bizon may face regulatory and reputational risks in case of data breach/misuse. Like better-performing peers, its data security programs include certification of its information security management system to ISO 27001 and cybersecurity training for employees.

ESG_HEADLINE: Weakness in corporate governance and business ethics practices compared to global peers
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: S1's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. S1 continues to trail global peers on corporate governance practices. S1's board is not majority independent of other interests as well as from its management. We also note related-party transactions with the non-controlling owner amounted to 24% of FY 2021 revenue; this may pose governance risks to other minority shareholders. Further, S1 lacks a nomination committee, which is responsible for recruitment and succession planning for board and key executive roles.S1 has limited business ethics practices relative to global peers. It appears to lack a policy to protect whistleblowers from retaliation. Also, ethics training does not seem to extend to all non-permanent employees and contractors.Security system technology providers such as S1 may face lower risks of workplace incidents than pure play security man-power service peers. It has industry standard safety programs such as ISO 45001, and conducts regular audits of its safety practices. Also, S1 reported a decreasing trend in its LTIR (2019: 0.08, 2021: 0.06). However, unlike leading peers, it seems to lack a quantitative target to improve its safety performance.S1 is exposed to labor-related risks as it operates in South Korea, where ILO data indicates high occurrence of strikes. The company's labor management practices are marginally above those of peers. Collective bargaining agreements appear to be in place, which could help mitigate labor discord. Moreover, S1 conducts engagement surveys, which may help gauge employee satisfaction.

PCCW's rating is unchanged at 'A'. PCCW's governance practices are average compared to global peers. We note no significant dissent (over 10% negative votes) to director elections in AGM 2022, unlike at AGM 2021 (two directors); this may suggest shareholder satisfaction with board performance. As of July 2022, the board had 36% female members; this may enhance diversity of views in board deliberations. Also, PCCW adopts robust ethics practices such as whistleblower protection against retaliation and audits of ethics standards.Telecom services operations are typically labor-intensive and could pose risks of work stoppages in case of labor unrest. Nonetheless, PCCW has industry-typical labor management programs, notably with measures such as variable pay components and skill development programs.Though its board is majority independent, two of its 11 directors serve on boards of several companies; this could limit their ability to focus on PCCW's board. Further, the founder of the company (holding ~30.9% voting power: FY 2021) chairs the board, which also includes the CEO; this may not align well with minority shareholder interests.PCCW served over 4.7 million mobile and 8.4 million OTT subscribers in FY 2021. This entails handling sensitive consumer data and may thus pose regulatory risks in case of a data breach. While we note it has provisions for IT system audits and breach preparedness in its privacy policy, it appears to trail industry peers in deploying cybersecurity risk management measures such as penetration testing.

ESG_HEADLINE: Leading business ethics practices, consumer protection initiatives, and talent development programs
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: BCA has been upgraded to 'AA' from 'A'. BCA leads home market peers in business ethics practices with its anti-fraud and anti-corruption initiatives having executive oversight. The bank also has a policy to protect whistleblowers against potential retaliation. A slight decline (~1.34%) in customer complaints in FY 2021 vis-a-vis 2020, further contributed to the upgrade. BCA has robust data protection and talent development programs, but it lags most global peers in corporate governance practices such as board structure.BCA's performance on Privacy and Data Security, which focuses on the company's exposure to evolving privacy regulations and on its ability to safeguard sensitive data, has improved since the last rating action. Please refer to the ESG Rating Drill Down and dedicated Privacy and Data Security sections of the report for more details.The bank's performance on Financing Environmental Impact, which assesses the environmental risks of lending and underwriting activities based on credit exposure to environmentally sensitive industries and management of associated risks, has weakened since the last rating action. Please refer to the ESG Rating Drill Down and dedicated Financing Environmental Impact sections of the report for more details.A data update to reflect the latest geographic exposure for access to finance has contributed to a lower Key Issue score. Yet, BCA continues to lead industry peers on financial inclusion initiatives such as providing banking services to nonurban areas through agents.

ESG_HEADLINE: Governance practices remain subpar.
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Bangkok Bank's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. The bank has robust data security practices with ISO 27001:2013 certification and a privacy policy governing all business lines. However, its board lacks an independent majority and its chairman is not independent. These factors may limit the board's ability to provide independent oversight of management. Additionally, five of its 19 directors are entrenched.
