On the downside, the company appears to lag peers in demonstrating robust programs to reduce its water and energy footprint and in investing in third-party green building certifications.Operations in real estate development may entail risks related to workplace accidents. To mitigate the risks, PT Ciputra has adopted a health and safety policy. However, we did not find evidence of targets to reduce workplace fatalities or injuries.

ESG_HEADLINE: Leads peers in customer protection framework; lags in environmental due diligence practices
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: HDFC Bank's rating is unchanged at 'AA'. HDFC Bank continues to lead industry peers on consumer protection initiatives. The bank has a robust complaint-handling mechanism and conducts reviews of existing and new products; these measures may help safeguard consumer interests. We note a reduction in consumer complaints by more than 20% YoY in FY 2021. However, weaknesses in data protection policies weigh on the rating. We found no evidence of advanced access control and encryption techniques, which may help prevent security incidents.Commercial loans constituted ~75% of the bank's total FY 2021 loan book, ~22% of which has a high exposure to environmentally intensive industries. However, we found limited evidence of ESG due diligence in its financing operations, which may help mitigate potential losses arising from related environmental risks.We note improvements in HDFC Bank's human capital initiatives, which include annual engagement surveys to gauge staff morale and diversity initiatives to help retain talent, given their reliance on skilled bankers and professionals. The bank has set targets to increase the representation of women in workforce to 25% by FY 2025 (FY 2021: 21%)HDFC Bank continues to lead global peers on corporate governance. At the latest AGM (July 2022), there was no significant shareholder dissent to the re-election of directors, unlike in our previous assessment; this may indicate shareholder satisfaction regarding board composition.

MRL has been upgraded to 'AA' from 'A'. The company's strong business ethics framework and policies drive the upgrade. While MRL operates in Australia, where corruption risk is perceived to be low, the company has robust policies and control mechanisms such as audits on ethics standards and whistleblower protection. In line with leading peers, these are overseen at the board level. We also note improved efforts that may help manage risks related to adverse impacts on biodiversity.As a mining services provider, MRL could be exposed to environmental liabilities associated with impacts of activities such as blasting and excavations. It has adopted conservation programs and practices concurrent rehabilitation. Like leading peers, it conducts biodiversity impact assessments in multiple phases of its projects.Mining activities could entail risks of liabilities in the event of workplace accidents. MRL leads peers on safety management, supported by a groupwide policy that extends to its contractors. We also found evidence of reduction targets and safety performance linked to executive compensation. MRL has not experienced any fatal incidents through the last four years (as of FY 2021).MRL's mining activities are water-intensive, thereby posing risks of operational disruptions associated with potential water shortage. While the company has made some efforts to utilize rainwater as an alternative source, it lags leading peers in adopting robust conservation programs and setting quantitative reduction targets.

TOCALO's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. Our research indicates weaknesses in the company's overall governance structure. Tocalo appears to lack best practices in business ethics management and compliance controls: we found no evidence of a detailed anti-corruption policy or of extensive ethics trainings and audits. Further, as is typical in the Japanese market, Tocalo lacks an independent majority board and executive pay disclosure.Tocalo's small workforce (1,121 vs. industry average of 20,097 as of January 2022) may lessen labor management complexity. Evidence suggests the company trails peers in implementing strong labor management programs such as monitoring job satisfaction levels through engagement surveys and in incentivization measures.The company may face high exposure to the risks of environmental liabilities and potential compliance costs linked to toxic discharges from its thermal spray process and coatings. Although Tocalo's environmental management system is certified to an international standard, it appears to lag better-performing peers in setting pollution reduction targets and in linking executive pay with the company's environmental performance.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improved community engagement and safety practices; trails peers in managing carbon and water risks
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Pilbara Minerals has been upgraded to 'AA' from 'A'. The upgrade is driven by improved community engagement practices and employee safety programs, that could mitigate risks of public unrest and occupational hazards. Evidence suggests strong initiatives such as support for local procurement, community impact assessments, and availability of formal grievance channels. The company's safety performance is linked to executive pay and it recorded zero fatalities over 2019-21. It also leads most global peers on corporate governance.Pilbara Minerals has a majority independent board and fully independent audit and pay committees; these may bolster strong management oversight. It follows the 'one share one vote' principle, that aligns shareholders' economic interests with voting power. Also, it has a formal anti-corruption policy with whistleblowers' protection and board oversight of ethics.Mining companies are highly exposed to risks of operational disruptions tied to workplace incidents. Although we found no evidence of ISO 45001 certified health and safety systems, the company leads peers in implementing a group-wide health and safety policy extended to its contractors and overseen at the board level. We also note employee trainings and regular audits of safety performance.With 100% operations in Australia where stringent emission regulations are in force, the company could face risk of increased regulatory costs. Unlike leading peers, it appears to lack robust decarbonization practices, such as the use of renewable energy or carbon capture technology.

NORITZ's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. NORITZ has disclosed a policy that provides whistleblowers with protection from retaliation, as a feature of its business ethics framework. Moreover, the company appears to have introduced performance-based incentives, albeit for a limited number of employees; this could increase workforce productivity. However, we found the company continues to trail most global and home market peers on its corporate governance practices.NORITZ, a manufacturer of water heaters, has less carbon-intensive operations relative to industry peers. Yet, we found the company has adopted a robust carbon mitigation strategy. This includes the use of alternative energy sources, investing in operational efficiencies, and setting quantified carbon emission reduction targets.NORITZ has relatively moderate exposure to risks tied to labor unrest. The company leads industry peers on labor management practices, which appear aligned with ILO guidelines. It provides leadership development programs and stock options, albeit for a limited number of employees; these could help workforce retention and productivity.The company lacks a majority independent board (only 33.3% independent directors), and has a combined CEO and board chairperson; these practices could limit management oversight. Moreover, the company has a series of cross-shareholdings with other companies, though Japan's revised corporate governance code calls for policies to assess and reduce cross-shareholdings.

Berjaya Sports rating is unchanged at 'A'. Berjaya Sports derived ~55.4% of its FY 2020 revenue from the gaming segment; its exposure to regulatory and reputational risks linked to gambling addiction among customers may thus be lower than that of full-time casino and betting operators. Nevertheless, the company's risk mitigation measures appear on par with those of peers. Berjaya Sports' business ethics practices are also on par with those of global peers. However, we note its board practices may present potential conflicts of interest.We flag Berjaya Sports' board for leadership concerns following the appointment (June 2021) of Mr. Yeong Ching (Robin) Tan as the executive chairman. He is a former CEO and a representative of the controlling family (December 2021: 49.8% owned). Further, we note related-party transactions with the controlling shareholder; this may present potential conflicts of interest.Berjaya Sports' responsible gaming measures include self-assessment tools for customers, and training for permanent staff and retail agents. It has established a team to oversee responsible gaming issues. However, we found no evidence of industry-common control tools such as self-exclusion.Berjaya Sports' small workforce of 1,367 in FY 2020 relative to the industry average of 16,657 employees as of January 2022 exposes it to lower operational risks tied to labor unrest than industry peers. Evidence suggests it is on par with peers in mitigating related risks. It offers a suite of benefits, such as educational reimbursements, and skill development opportunities.

Skycity has been upgraded to 'A' from 'BBB'. Our research indicates improvements in SkyCity's corporate governance, which now leads those of most global peers. The board was no longer classified as undersized, as of June 2022. Also, following the retirement of its former chair in January 2022, we no longer flag any director for overboarding. Moreover, all board directors are independent of management and other interests. These structures may bolster management oversight. We also note strong performance on carbon emissions management.Based on our model, casinos are perceived to have high exposure to risks related to corruption and money laundering. SkyCity's business ethics practices are average compared to those of global peers. However, it faced regulatory investigations (2021 and 2022) over allegations of non-compliance to Australian laws against money laundering.SkyCity adopts industry-typical measures in mitigating regulatory and reputational risks tied to gambling addiction. We found evidence of control tools, including self-limitation and exclusion. It also has player monitoring systems in place to help identify at-risk players. This, however, is limited to customers with loyalty cards.SkyCity's operational focus on New Zealand and Australia--regions with moderate to high likelihood of labor unrest, based on our model--exposes it to labor-related risks. It lags peers in mitigating the risks. There were reports of labor strikes (2019, 2022) demanding wage hikes.

OKUMA has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'B'. We note no significant votes against board members at the 2021 AGM; this may indicate improved shareholder satisfaction. Further, three new independent directors, including one female director, have joined the board, resulting in an increase in independent director representation from 18% to 33%. These factors have contributed to the upgrade. However, we found limited disclosures on executive pay. Further, the company has a combined CEO-chairperson role, as is typical in the Japanese market.Okuma manufactures metal cutting machine tools; thus, its operations are labor intensive and may pose risks of work disruptions and reduced staff productivity. The company's small workforce (3,802 vs. 20,097 industry average as of January 2022) may reduce labor management complexities. Evidence suggests the company trails peers in implementing programs such as engagement surveys and incentivization measures.Through its focus on the development of automation systems for improvements in factory conditions, Okuma has opportunities to tap the increasing demand for energy-efficiency solutions. Yet, low R&D investments, at 2.89% of sales (2018-20) compared with the industry average of 3.67% (as of January 2022), could limit innovation capacity.Okuma operates in regions such as Japan and Europe, where the incidence of corruption is perceived to be low. Evidence indicates the company has instituted an anti-corruption framework, underpinned by industry-typical compliance measures, including whistleblower protection.

SHIBAURA MACHINE has been downgraded to 'BBB' from 'A'. The downgrade reflects weaknesses in the company's corporate governance relative to global peers. Although Shibaura Machine's board is majority independent, it has an executive chair serving alongside the CEO, and multiple executives. While such board structures are typical in Japan, this may limit strong management oversight. Further, the re-election of two directors received more than 10% negative votes at the 2021 AGM, possibly indicating shareholder dissatisfaction.Although industrial operations are generally labor intensive, Shibaura Machine may have moderate exposure to risks related to labor unrest owing to its operational focus in Japan (FY 2020: 88%), where strikes have been historically less frequent per ILO data. Like most peers, the company offers non-pay benefits such as insurance and childcare leave system and stock option plans, which may help retain talent.The company's manufacturing operations may pose moderate exposure to the risk of liabilities and compliance costs associated with toxic releases. To mitigate these risks, it conducts environmental impact audits of operations, like peers. Shibaura Machine also targets to reduce its waste discharge by 40% (2017 baseline) by 2030.With 71% of FY 2020 revenue derived from molding machines, Shibaura Machine has limited opportunities in the cleantech space. Its average R&D sales ratio of 2.00% over FY 2018-20 was below the industry average of 3.67% as of May 2022; this may suggest limited innovation capacity compared to peers.

ESG_HEADLINE: Strong e-waste and human capital development programs; weaknesses in governance persist
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Asustek's rating is unchanged at 'A'. The company continues to lead peers in ESG risk mitigation measures on social key issues, particularly on mineral tracing initiatives. Asustek may face reputational risks if 3TG minerals found in its products are sourced from conflict areas. It continues to undertake supply chain due diligence and origin-tracing efforts to facilitate conflict-free sourcing. However, its ethical framework appears to lack strong measures such as regular audits and a detailed anti-corruption policy.Asustek relies on a highly skilled workforce for product innovation and exploring emerging technologies such as AIoT. Like leading peers, it has partnered with universities to develop and maintain a steady R&D talent pool; it also offers professional development programs aimed at upward mobility.Asustek derived 100% of FY 2021 revenues from products subject to e-waste regulations, this exposes it to producer responsibility on end-of-life products. Like leading peers, its robust take-back program extends to multiple brands and provides credits on new purchases to encourage the recycling of its old products.Despite having fully independent audit and pay committees, the company's board lacks independent majority, and its chair, deputy chair and CEO are all executives; this may impede their independence in leading the board. Further, a non-executive director serves on the board of more than three other listed companies; this may hinder his ability to provide objective leadership.

PCT's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. Our detailed assessment indicates that PCT's initiatives on sustainable property investments and workplace safety management are comparable with those of its industry peers. However, despite real estate investment trusts' reliance on and competition for a skilled workforce, we note weaknesses in PCT's programs to attract and secure a steady talent pipeline. Further, the limited information on staff turnover may impede comparison of performance with peers.The company has high growth opportunities in green building investments, given its focus on office properties which are more energy intensive than residential assets. Besides, PCT operates in New Zealand, a country with a Zero-Carbon law. PCT targets sustainable certifications for its new and existing properties, with 33.3% of its portfolio (by number of buildings) certified as of June 2021, vs. the 2020 Office REITs sub-industry average of 37.8%.Occupational hazards are common in property development (20% of FY 2020 assets), which expose PCT to operational challenges in case of safety incidents. Its safety management strategy includes internal audits and annual third-party reviews of its safety processes.PCT trails home market peers on governance. Related-party transactions with its manager increased from 22% of expenses in FY 2020 to 181% in FY 2021; this may raise concerns of potential conflict of interests. Moreover, the company appears to lack strong business ethics controls such as audits and firm-wide training on ethics.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improved board structure and community engagement practices; increased fatality numbers
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: China Shenhua has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'B'. The upgrade is driven by improvements in the company's governance practices. After some changes in the board composition in 2021, concerns over the lack of an independent majority and lack of female directors have been allayed. Further, we found evidence of practices focused on local community engagement and provision of human rights training to employees; these practices could help manage the risks of potential community conflicts caused by the company's mining activities.Coal mining operations involve water-intensive processes that expose companies to potential added input costs or operational disruptions in case of water scarcity. Nonetheless, like leading peers, the company has board-level oversight on water management and uses alternative water sources such as seawater and mine water.The company operates open pit and underground coal mines, posing risks of operational disruptions in the event of workplace incidents. Like most peers, some of the company's enterprises are certified to the ISO 45001 standard. Yet, fatalities increased YoY from 1 in 2020 to 5 in 2021.Like coal mining peers, Chin Shenhua is exposed to potential regulatory costs in line with China's goal to achieve carbon neutrality by 2060. While the company has projects such as carbon capture and utilization, and investment in renewable energy, its 2020 carbon emissions intensity remained above that of industry peers (3,782 t CO2e/USD million sales vs. 959 industry average as of Q2 2022).

ESG_HEADLINE: Appears to lack notable programs across all ESG Key Issues
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: PT Gudang Garam's rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. Exposure to product safety and quality risks was revised to capture the inherent negative health impact associated with the use of tobacco; this adversely impacted the company's score. PT Gudang Garam continues to demonstrate limited commitment toward the responsible marketing of its cigarette products. Further, the company trails industry peers in adopting strong programs to mitigate other ESG risks assessed for the tobacco industry.While PT Gudang Garam has a general commitment to the responsible marketing of its cigarette products, we found no evidence of auditing systems to monitor compliance with its marketing commitments or of employee training, unlike the case with leading industry peers.Dependence on the water-intensive tobacco crop suggests high exposure to risks related to potential water shortages for PT Gudang Garam. The company trails peers on water management practices: it appears to lack conservation measures to manage water use in the supply chain. Further, we found no evidence of group-wide water consumption figures or targets to reduce consumption.We note concerns related to the company's corporate governance practices. In particular, based on our model, its board is undersized, comprising only four members, and is potentially entrenched, with two directors having served more than 15 years. Moreover, we found limited executive pay disclosures; this impedes benchmarking of pay practices with those of peers.

Tokai Tokyo has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'B'. Improvements in Tokai Tokyo's corporate governance structure, which leads those of most global peers, led to the upgrade. The company disclosed executive pay details for FY 2021. Also, the removal of the poison pill provision--a management-friendly takeover defense mechanism--may help investors accept acquisition bids. Inclusion of the Corporate Behavior Theme in the Governance assessment resulted in greater emphasis on business ethics, on which Tokai Tokyo trails most global and home market peersAs a consumer-facing brokerage firm, Tokai Tokyo handles substantial customer data and operates in Japan, where privacy laws are stringent. However, the company lags peers in implementing industry-best practices such as regular audits of IT systems to help prevent potential security incidents.Tokai Tokyo's responsible investment initiatives trail those of industry peers. Our reassessment of the company's total investment assets indicates higher ESG risk exposure than in our prior assessment. Further, we found no evidence of a ESG-focused due diligence process or a dedicated team to assess ESG risks in its portfolio--measures that may help mitigate related risks in its portfolio.Tokai Tokyo's performance on Human Capital Development (HCD)--which focuses on its reliance on a skilled workforce, and on its ability to attract and retain talent--has weakened since the last rating action. Please refer to the ESG Rating Drill Down and dedicated HCD sections of the report for more details.

Webjet has been upgraded to 'AA' from 'A'. The company leads most global peers on corporate governance. Our analysis of accounting practices in the Governance assessment no longer includes key metrics derived from accounting ratios. Our latest analysis indicates limited risks related to Webjet's accounting practices compared to global peers, which is a key contributor to the upgrade. Unlike in the previous year, at the 2022 AGM, there was no significant shareholder dissent on the company's pay policies and practices.Our model suggests online travel companies are typically perceived to have high exposure to corruption risks. Webjet's business ethics practices lead those of most global peers. The company's policy against corruption is reinforced with whistleblower protection from retaliation.Webjet collects substantial sensitive customer data; this exposes the company to risks related to cybersecurity, more so as it derives ~80% of its revenue from regions (New Zealand, Australia, the UK, and Northern Ireland) with strict data privacy laws. The company has strong practices relative to peers to mitigate related risks. It undertakes cyber-threat monitoring and data encryption techniques to manage potential data breach incidents.Online travel companies have high exposure to operational risk in case of labor unrest, per our model. However, the company lags peers in mitigating these risks. Webjet appears to lack labor unions and collective agreements that may help protect workforce interests.

Western Areas' rating is unchanged at 'A'. Western Areas demonstrates strong governance practices compared to its global peers. It also leads peers in health and safety management initiatives to mitigate potential safety risks associated with underground mining activities. In December 2021, Western Areas was acquired by IGO, with expected completion by April 2022; M&A activities could pose labor integration challenges. The company's workforce management programs appear comparable to those of its peers, which could help allay such risks.Like better-performing peers, Western Areas provides staff non-pay benefits, training programs, and stock options to employees; these measures could help bolster retention. However, engagement surveys for monitoring employee morale appear to be missing.The company is engaged in nickel ore mining, operations of which could pose disturbance to local ecosystems. Like leading peers, Western Areas has policies for minimizing its environmental footprint and conducts environmental impact assessments. Further, it implements programs for concurrent rehabilitation and flora and fauna preservation.With mining operations being water-intensive, Western Areas is exposed to the risk of incurring costs in case of water shortages. The company lags peers in water conservation efforts, such as setting targets to reduce freshwater use and utilizing alternative water sources.

GMT's rating is unchanged at 'A'. GMT remains average compared to global peers on corporate governance and business ethics practices. The company has industry-typical initiatives to mitigate talent recruitment and retention risks inherent to the real estate investment trust industry. Further, despite low exposure to green building opportunities due to the less resource-intensive nature of logistics properties relative to retail or office assets, GMT has relatively strong practices to raise the sustainability of its properties.GMT's board is majority independent and its executive pay policies appear generally in line with shareholder interests. However, the board is potentially entrenched as three of seven directors were long-tenured, as of November 2022. Entrenched boards are atypical of New Zealand peers (only 6% flagged) and may impede management oversight.Real estate investment trusts rely on skilled talent for portfolio management and could thus face talent-related challenges. GMT offers discretionary bonuses and stock ownership schemes--benefits known to help foster retention. However, it lags leading peers with leadership development programs and support for professional certifications for all employees.GMT's practices to enhance its portfolio's energy efficiency include investing in renewable energy sources and targeting a 5 Green Star rating (a type of green building certification) for all new properties. However, limited disclosure on the proportion of its portfolio that has achieved certification impedes comparison with peers.

Goldcrest's rating is unchanged at 'B'. Goldcrest lags peers in initiatives to manage its ESG-related risks. Its corporate governance practices trail those of its home market peers. The company's board, comprising of four members, is undersized, and it has a combined CEO and chairman role. These factors could adversely impact the board's decision-making capacity. Additionally, one of its directors received over 30% dissenting votes in the 2021 AGM, indicating potential shareholder dissatisfaction with his service.Goldcrest operates in Japan, a country which actively promotes green development. However, the company lags its peers in monetizing green investment opportunities--it does not appear to have major initiatives to improve its properties' sustainability profile. In addition, unlike local industry peers, Goldcrest's properties appear to lack green building certifications such as DBJ and CASBEE.Our research indicates Goldcrest lags its industry peers in adopting strong safety programs at its construction sites. It does not disclose its employee safety data or appear to set improvement targets, which may make peer comparison challenging.Goldcrest's property development portfolio is focused on residential buildings. This exposes it to quality-related risks of high warranty payouts in case of subpar build quality and maintenance of properties. While the company has some initiatives to maintain a quality standard for the properties it builds, it lags peers in having strong supplier and raw materials quality oversight.

Tokai Rika's rating is unchanged at 'B'. The company's governance structures and product quality assurance programs continue to trail those of peers. As its product portfolio includes critical safety equipment such as seatbelts, Tokai Rika may be exposed to regulatory and financial risks in the event of lapses in product quality. However, we found limited evidence of measures to implement standard quality management practices in the company's supply chain, such as quality audits and supplier training on quality management.Our research indicates weaknesses in Tokai Rika's governance structures. The combined CEO-chairperson role and the lack of an independent majority board may raise concerns related to excessive management influence on the board. Further, the lack of a fully independent pay committee, together with limited disclosures on executive pay, may not align with investor interests.We found limited evidence of clean technology offerings in Tokai Rika's product line. However, a relatively high three-year (FY 2018-2020) average R&D investments/revenue ratio of 5.6% (vs industry average of 4.24%, as of September 2021) may help the company improve its capacity for cleantech innovation.As per our estimates, 48% of the company's FY 2020 operations were based in Japan, where likelihood of labor unrest is low (as per ILO data). This, together with a relatively small workforce of 19,888 employees (vs. industry average of 100,711, as of September 2021) for FY 2020, results in relatively low exposure to labor management complexities.

ESG_HEADLINE: Continued strong focus in ESG integration; talent attrition increased
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Cathay FHC's rating is unchanged at 'AA'. Cathay FHC continued to exhibit strong efforts to incorporate ESG factors into its investment and company engagement processes. It deployed ~13% of assets (USD 47.6 billion) in sustainable finance in 2021, including USD 7.5 billion dedicated to climate change. However, we noted its three-year average employee turnover rose to 10.8% as of 2021 (9.0%: 2020); this may signal potential talent retention challenges. This, combined with weaknesses in its corporate governance, sustained the rating.Cathay FHC leads peers in integrating ESG factors into its investment and engagement processes. It assesses the carbon footprint across asset portfolios (listed equity and fixed income) and sectors.Demographic and emerging health trends present potential insurance risks. Cathay FHC leads peers in capturing demand from such trends through product offerings, i.e., insurance plans targeting middle-aged/aging group.Cathay FHC lags global peers in corporate governance. Methodology enhancements to the Governance theme resulted in a greater emphasis on the additional governance risks to investors posed by a board of directors with other outside interests. We revised our evaluation of governance risks to investors to place a greater focus on the nomination committee, which is responsible for recruitment and succession planning for board and senior management roles; its nomination committee chair is not independent of other interests. Cathay FHC leads global peers in business ethics framework (i.e., whistleblower protection).

China Airlines' rating is unchanged at 'A'. China Airlines' product safety and quality management practices are above industry average. The airline's operations management is certified to the IATA Operational Safety Audit Program and it received a 4-star (out of 5) rating form Skytrax in 2020. Also, its on-time performance was above the industry average, at 85% vs. 81.8%, in FY 2020.Airline operators have high exposure to the risk of operational disruptions and litigation in the event of labor management issues. China Airlines appears to offer employees stock options, allowances, and subsidies, and to conduct employee satisfaction surveys. These may help mitigate such risks.The company is exposed to risks related to stringent data protection regulations in the US and Southeast Asia (63% of FY 2020 revenue). Our research indicates China Airlines employs privacy controls such as cybersecurity checks and breach contingency plans. It also certified its information security management system to ISO 27001 in 2020.China Airlines' corporate governance practices trail those of global peers. We note controlling shareholder concerns related to its ownership. This, alongside the absence of an independent board chair, may pose risks to minority shareholder interests. Further, while it has a formal anti-corruption policy, it falls short of business ethics best practices such as ethics audits and whistleblower protection.

ESG_HEADLINE: Weaknesses in corporate governance; lagging staff management practices
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Chiba Bank has been downgraded to 'BBB' from 'A'. Chiba Bank (CHB) lags global peers on corporate governance--it does not have an independent majority board and independent key committees; this may limit management oversight. The bank's business ethics framework is average relative to global peers--we found no evidence of policies against corruption, which may help preempt potential unethical misconduct. While CHB has transparent lending policies, we found no evidence of financial education initiatives, which may help protect customer interests.The bank derives 100% revenues from Japan (FY 2021), where privacy laws are stringent; this could expose the bank to regulatory risks. While we found evidence of systems for preventing cyberattacks which are reinforced through cybersecurity trainings, our recent assessment indicates limited access rights to customers for controlling their personal data.Despite commercial loans accounting for 66% of its loan portfolio (FY 2021), CHB has relatively low exposure towards lending to environmentally sensitive industries. However, we found limited evidence of ESG due diligence programs in its financing activities, which could help mitigate related risks.CHB's performance on Human Capital Development--which focuses on the bank's reliance on a skilled workforce--has improved since the last rating action, but continues to lag industry peers. Please refer to the ESG Rating Drill Down and dedicated Human Capital Development sections of the report for more details.

ESG_HEADLINE: Talent management performance leads peers; controversies over corporate behavior
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: CITIC Securities has been upgraded to 'BBB' from 'BB'. CITIC Securities' enhanced approaches to sustainable finance and responsible investment, along with the robust talent management performance, drove the upgrade. The company engaged in green bond underwritings and incorporated ESG factors into due diligence procedures. The removal of the key metrics derived from accounting ratios in the Governance assessment is another key contributor to the upgrade due to its relatively low accounting risk compared to global peers.CITIC Securities leads global peers in corporate governance practices (i.e., independent board majority). Yet, the board had a government-appointed executive chair serving alongside the CEO; this may hinder its independent leadership. It has industry-typical business ethics practices. However, we noted controversies related to alleged insufficient disclosure and market manipulation of its subsidiaries.The company appears to lead peers in managing talent attraction and retention risks. It undertakes initiatives such as regular performance appraisals and job-specific trainings to facilitate talent pool development. Its employee attrition rate of 8.1% in 2021 was lower than the industry average of 11.8% in 2021.The company adopted some practices to incorporate ESG factors into investment process, and to develop ESG-themed investment products in FY 2021. Yet, we found no evidence of it scaling up stewardships, such as proxy voting or engagement policy, to address ESG issues of its investment portfolio.

ESG_HEADLINE: Sub-par governance structures relative to peers
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Changan Auto's rating is unchanged at 'B'. The company trails global peers on corporate governance and business ethics practices. Changan Auto is state owned, and several directors--including the chair--are state representatives. We also note recurring related-party transactions with other state-owned entities. These, together with the lack of a fully independent audit committee, may pose risks for minority investors. The company's labor management and product quality assurance practices continue to be average relative to industry peers.The labor-intensive nature of car manufacturing operations exposes the company to risks of operational disruptions, as per our model. We note practices such as stock option grants and performance-based incentives for employees; these may help mitigate such risks.Automobile manufacturers are exposed to risks related to potential product quality lapses, which may result in recalls and other financial risks. Changan Auto's three-year (FY 2019-21) averages of recalls per unit sales and warranty payouts per sales of 2.2% and 0.86%, respectively, were lower than the corresponding industry averages of 33.1% and 1.52% as of October 2022.The company's average tailpipe CO2 emissions for China (FY 2021: 93% of sales) decreased to 126g/km in FY 2021 from an average of 140g/km for the prior three years; this may help mitigate risks related to GHG emission norms. However, Changan Auto's target to have electric and hybrid vehicles constitute 60% of sales by 2030 appears modest relative to electrification targets of leading industry peers.

COMSYS Holdings Corporation (COMSYS) has been downgraded to 'BBB' from 'A'. We note weaknesses in COMSYS' corporate governance practices. At the 2021 AGM, we note significant votes against three directors; this could indicate shareholder dissatisfaction with their performance. Further, similar to that of Japanese peers, its board lacks an independent majority, and has a combined CEO and chair; these may limit its ability to provide independent management oversight. Its safety management practices and clean technology strategy are on par with those of most leading peers.As a telecommunications infrastructure developer, COMSYS may be exposed to risks related to potential industrial accidents. The company has robust safety practices relative to peers, these include OHSAS 18001 certification and management-level oversight of its health and safety performance to help mitigate related risks. its reported Total Recordable Incident Rate (TRIR) decreased to 0.05 per million hours in FY2020, from 0.17 in FY2019.The company appears to capitalize on cleantech opportunities. It is involved in the construction of alternative power generation facilities (biomass, solar, and wind). These constituted 14% of its total revenues (FY2020), above the industry average of 12.82% (Q2 2022).COMSYS has adopted strong business ethics practices relative to industry peers. It has board-level oversight of ethics standards and provides employees related training. However, it appears to lack industry best practice like periodic audits.

Koa's rating is unchanged at 'B'. Our research found weaknesses in Koa's corporate governance relative to peers. The company's board, like that of most Japanese peers, lacks an independent majority and is dominated by executive directors. Historical data indicates Koa's principal operating markets (Japan, the US, Europe) are generally low-risk geographies for public sector corruption. That said, the company's business ethics initiatives appear to lack training and audit mechanisms.Koa's products, such as resistors, may contain minerals such as tin that could expose its supply chain to risks associated with conflict minerals sourcing. Unlike leading industry peers, the company appears to lack strong policies addressing raw minerals procurement as well as due diligence programs to monitor upstream supply chain, including smelters.Around 62% of Koa's FY 2020 revenue was derived from markets with stringent chemical regulations (US, Japan, Europe). While Koa has measures to track hazardous chemicals in its products, the company trails industry peers, overall. Evidence suggests limited efforts to phase out chemicals of concern and conduct life cycle assessments of products.With around 82% of operations in Japan, where ILO data indicates low incidence of labor unrest, and a small workforce (3,932 vs 17,500 industry average), the company's exposure to labor-related risks is moderate. It offers industry typical benefits and skills development, and overall, performs on par with peers on labor management.

ESG_HEADLINE: Governance and data security management practices remain strong
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Computershare has been upgraded to 'AAA' from 'AA'. The company continues to lead most global peers on overall governance, with a strong board structure that is further supported by a robust anti-corruption framework. The company processes large volumes of sensitive information and is exposed to privacy-related risks. However, a more granular assessment of business exposure indicates privacy-related risks are lower for data processing companies than for companies directly handling end-user information.To preempt potential cyber-attacks, Computershare has disclosed a resilient data security framework with rigorous internal controls for data access mechanisms; these may help keep pace with the ever-evolving complexity of cybercrimes.The company has strong ownership and control practices, based on our assessment. It follows the 'one share one vote' principle, which aligns shareholders' economic interests with their voting rights. In addition, the company has an independent board majority and a fully independent audit committee, which may bolster management oversight.Computershare offers strong non-pay benefits to attract and retain talented staff. In 2021, it completed the acquisition of Wells Fargo Corporate Trust Services and absorbed 2,000 employees from its workforce. Such corporate events are often associated with employee integration challenges. While the company conducts regular surveys, we found no disclosures on attrition rates, which limits comparisons with peers.

Starts' rating is unchanged at 'BB'. We note weaknesses in Starts' corporate governance, particularly in its board and pay structures, as well as its business ethics practices, resulting in a lower governance score relative to peers. Further, we found no evidence of certification to recognized health and safety standards such as ISO 45001. On the upside, the company appears to lead peers in adopting talent management programs such as professional development opportunities to maintain a steady pipeline.Like most Japanese peers, the company's board lacks an independent majority. Moreover, the board is potentially entrenched (4 of 11 directors have served for 15 years or more) and includes multiple executives; this may limit objective management oversight. Further, the company's ethics framework appears to lag those of peers, as we found limited evidence of strong enforcement mechanisms such as audits.Despite fully operating in Japan, where data privacy laws are stringent, Starts lags peers in data management initiatives. Although we found evidence of privacy-related certifications such as ISO 27001, the company appears to lack robust data protection measures such as systems audits and vulnerability tests.Starts' residential development business exposes it to risks of high warranty payouts in case of lapses in build quality. Like leading peers, the company's construction activities are certified to ISO 9001 standards. However, the limited disclosure on warranty payments may impede comparison of its performance with that of peers.

Dongkuk Steel has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'B'. The upgrade factors in the company's strengthened focus on reducing its emissions in its steel manufacturing operations--in line with South Korea's National GHG emissions targets and net zero goal by 2050. Further, its energy management system is certified to ISO 50001. Dongkuk Steel processes steel scraps in electric furnaces, rather than conventional blast furnaces, bringing its emissions down to 381 tCO2e/USD million sales (1,121 industry average as of December 2021).Dongkuk Steel is exposed to risks of work stoppages, as 98% of its FY 2020 operations are based in South Korea, where incidence of labor unrest is high as per ILO data. While we found employee programs centered on skills development, it lags peers in adopting strong engagement programs to measure staff morale.Steel manufacturers run the risk of environmental liabilities due to toxic air emissions and waste. While all major facilities are certified to the ISO 14001 standard, it appears to lack air emissions and waste reduction targets, unlike leading peers.Dongkuk Steel continues to trail industry peers in managing safety-related risks. In 2021, at least two died in its facilities, indicating possible weaknesses in its safety management programs. While some of the company's facilities are certified to the ISO 45001 standard, Dongkuk Steel appears to lack of information on its safety performance and targets; this impedes comparison with peers.

ESG_HEADLINE: Leads peers in talent management; lags in governance practices
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: DB Insurance has been upgraded to 'A' from 'BBB'. DB insurance is a property & casualty insurer and has high exposure to climate change-related events. We found evidence of integrating climate risks in underwriting and of multiple climate mitigation products; this could help customers mitigate the impact of climate change. Further, DB Insurance has robust talent development programs. The company lags global peers in business ethics practices. Meanwhile, its corporate governance practices are largely average relative to those of global peers.We found no disclosure on whether the company provides whistleblowers protection from retaliation, contributing to a decrease in corporate behavior score. In terms of accounting practices in corporate governance, the external auditor highlighted an emphasis of matter associated with economic uncertainties due to COVID-19 for two consecutive years in the company's financial outlook.As an insurance firm, the company requires highly skilled talent with financial expertise. It continues to lead peers in providing structural training programs to employees, as per roles--these could help retain and attract talents. It also conducts engagement surveys to gauge staff satisfaction. Its employee average turnover ratio (FY 2019-21) was 3.6%, lower than it's the industry average of 9.6% (as of December 2022.)Our model suggests insurers investment portfolios are exposed to ESG risks. Yet, DB Insurance lags peers in responsible investing initiatives. We found no evidence of engagements with investee companies on potential ESG issues.

ESG_HEADLINE: Leads most peers in employee management practices
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Delta Thailand has been upgraded to 'AA' from 'A'. Delta Thailand manufactures electronic parts and equipment, and thus, has high opportunities in the clean technology space. The company leads industry peers in capitalizing on the increasing demand for cleantech solutions. Its components offerings span applications for hybrid vehicles, LED lighting, solar equipment and battery storage. We also found evidence of strategies and R&D investments focusing on cleantech products. These strong practices contributed to the upgrade.Manufacturing diversified electronic components is a labor-intensive business and could pose risks such as work disruptions and reduced staff productivity. In FY 2021, 44% of its operations were in markets like Germany, Slovakia and India, where ILO data indicates high precedence of labor unrest. The company leads industry peers in workforce management initiatives. It discloses strong engagement programs such as formal communication channels to monitor workforce feedback. Based on our assessment, the company also offers paid educational support and a wide array of skills training.Delta Thailand's governance is on par with that of global peers. The company's business conduct measures include a detailed anti-corruption policy, backed by strong employee training and whistleblower reporting programs. Further, its ownership structure is on par with global peers. While Delta Thailand has a controlling shareholder, it follows the one share, one vote principle, aligning economic exposure to voting power of shareholders.

ESG_HEADLINE: Merger may pose employee integration challenge; weaknesses in corporate governance relative to peers
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: MHCC's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. Merger with Hitachi Capital Corporation (April 2021) increased MHCC's workforce from 3,284 to 8,803 as of FY 2021. Such corporate events may involve staff restructuring and pose integration challenges. Thus, MHCC is exposed to risks related to human capital management. While we found no evidence of retention and engagement practices, MHCC adopts certain industry best talent management practices that may help mitigate related risks. The company lags global peers on corporate governance framework.We note improvements in MHCC's corporate governance practices such as disclosures on executive pay and the presence of a pay committee; this may support management oversight. However, we note significant votes against two directors (>15%) at the 2022 AGM; this could indicate shareholder dissatisfaction. The board also includes an executive chair and the CEO.MHCC's corporate behavior practices are average relative to global and home-market peers. Our research indicates the presence of whistleblower protection and an anti-money laundering policy that may help preempt potential unethical business conduct. However, we found no evidence of regular audits of ethics practices.MHHC provides leasing and finance service to a wide range of industries such as infrastructure and mobility. The company operates in over 20 countries as of FY 2021 through its subsidiaries and affiliates. However, its efforts to capitalize on opportunities to improve financial inclusion by penetrating underserved markets appear limited.

ESG_HEADLINE: Strong focus on clean technology development; lags peers in corporate governance
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Delta's rating is unchanged at 'AA'. Delta is a manufacturer of electronic components for the power supply industry, and thus, has opportunities to tap into clean technology. It leads peers in providing energy-efficient solutions, including solar inverters and LED drivers. Further, its large workforce (87,366 vs. 32,000 industry average, as of June 2022) presents higher labor management complexity than peers. Nevertheless, Delta's labor management practices such as robust incentive schemes lead those of industry peers.Delta derived 100% FY 2021 revenues from the US, Taiwan, Thailand, and China--markets with stringent laws on chemical safety--thus exposing the company to risks of reformulation costs. Nevertheless, Delta's above par performance includes broad-based monitoring protocol for chemical identification.Electronic components such as inductors and resistors generally use 3TGs (Tin, Tungsten, Tantalum, or Gold). This exposes Delta to reputational or regulatory risks if conflict minerals are traced in its products or supply chain. Delta's material procurement practices are on par with those of peers. Its efforts to engage with suppliers appear to include monitoring and training programs.Delta lags most home market peers in corporate governance. We note the board lacks an independent majority from the management and remains entrenched (5 of 10 directors have served for over 15 years). Such a structure may impede objectivity in management oversight.

ESG_HEADLINE: On par with leading peers on human capital and product quality management
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Asahi Intecc has been upgraded to 'BBB' from 'BB'. Asahi Intecc's programs to manage key social risks relevant to its medical supplies and device manufacturing operations appear on par with those of leading peers. New evidence indicates its talent management programs include leadership development and performance review--measures known to aid in talent recruitment and retention. We also note its low employee turnover rate (2020: 3% vs. ~10% industry average). However, its business ethics practices still lag those of global and domestic peers.Asahi Intecc develops medical devices and stainless steel technologies for medical use. This could expose the company to product liability risks in the event of safety and quality issues. To help mitigate such risks, it implements in-house product testing, and has its facilities certified to ISO 13485 and 9001 standards. Our research found no evidence of product recalls and regulatory warnings in the three years through February 2022.Asahi Intecc, like many of its Japan market peers, lacks a majority independent board. Further, although the company established a pay committee (as of September 2021), it is not fully independent and includes two executives. This could limit strong oversight of management and executive pay practices.Asahi Intecc relies on government agencies for marketing approvals, and may thus face corruption risks. While we found evidence of business ethics policies to help mitigate such risks, its compliance measures, such as audits and employee training, appear to fall short of industry best practices.

ESG_HEADLINE: Recurring subcontractor safety accidents; pending acquisition poses potential restructuring risks
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: DSME's rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. DSME lags peers in addressing key ESG risks. While DSME's major manufacturing site (Okpo shipyard) is certified to ISO 45001 standards, our research found evidence of three subcontractor fatalities as of October 2022. This may indicate gaps in safety management system. We note Hanwha Group's pending plan to acquire DSME (preliminary contract signed on September 2022) by 2023 could pose restructuring challenges for DSME. The company trails global peers on corporate ethics.Our model indicates DSME is exposed to corruption risks due to its shipbuilding business, which relies on supply contracts. It appears to lack best practices in ethics oversight. As of December 2021, DSME was fined by the Korea Fair Trade Commission for alleged violation of technical data request policies.Shipbuilding entails painting activities which exposes DSME to risks related to toxic releases. While DSME has industry-typical practices such as certification to ISO 14001, we found no disclosure on pollution reduction targets, and VOC emissions unlike with better-performing peers.Our research indicates Hanwha Group plans to sign a main contract with the controlling shareholder to acquire DSME by December 2022; this follows the EU's veto on a merger proposal from HD Hyundai Group in January 2022. Such restructuring may present labor unrest risks. DSME has industry-standard labor management practices. However, we note evidence of labor union protests related to the restructuring and wage hikes (2019-2022).

PT Matahari has been upgraded to 'BBB' from 'BB'. Matahari's improved board structure contributes to the upgrade. As of April 2022, the board was no longer undersized with the appointment of 3 new directors; this may aid management oversight. As a retailer, it collects customer data and is thus exposed to regulatory risks in case of data breaches. Improved data security practices such as staff training and audits on cybersecurity also drive the upgrade. Yet, it lags leading peers: it appears to lack executive oversight of its data systems.Matahari has low exposure to labor management risks due to its small workforce (9,032 in FY 2021 vs. industry average of 87,619 as of October 2022). The company has industry-typical practices such as non-statutory benefits, which may help sustain productivity. However, unlike better-performing peers, it appears to lack regular engagement surveys to monitor workforce satisfaction.Matahari's corporate behavior practices are average compared to those of global peers. While it has employee training and board-level oversight of ethics standards, we found no evidence of regular audits of its ethics measures.Matahari operates department stores and thus has moderate exposure to risks of incurring increased carbon pricing costs, as per our model. Yet, its GHG emission reduction measures, such as the use of LED lamps, seem limited to its store operations. Unlike leading peers, it appears to lack lifecycle assessments for products and emission reduction targets.

Emeco has been upgraded to 'AA' from 'A'. The upgrade is driven by improvements in the company's health and safety strategies. In FY 2020, Emeco updated its health and safety policy, extending its coverage to vendors and customers. The company also continues to implement safety risk assessments and monitor its year-on-year incident rates, and leads peers in factoring safety performance as part of executive pay.The company has strong governance practices, relative to global and home market peers. Emeco's board has an independent majority and independent audit and pay committees--governance features associated with strong management oversight. Moreover, its business ethics framework continues to adopt detailed anti-corruption policies to mitigate risks. In June 2021, the company updated its whistleblower policy.Emeco's equipment leasing business presents minimal opportunities in the clean technology domain. The company's strategies do not appear to focus primarily on integrating clean technology applications. However, we note optimization solutions offered through its fleet management and mining technology platform, which could promote efficiency and productivity. However, it has yet to disclose the share of revenue from these products.

ESG_HEADLINE: Lags home market peers and most global market peers on corporate governance
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: NYPCB's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. NYPCB continues to trail home market peers in corporate governance. Limited executive pay disclosures (as of May 2021) impede peer comparison of its pay practices. Its board remains entrenched (6 of 11 directors) and continues to lack female directors; this may hinder diversity of viewpoints in board deliberations. We note a fully independent audit committee to oversee related-party transactions with the controlling owner (Wang Family: 67% shares as of FY 2021).Regulated chemicals in printed circuit boards (PCBs) and strict chemical safety laws in markets such as Taiwan (2021: ~100% of sales) may pose risks of reformulation costs for NYPCB. While its chemical monitoring system appears broad-based, NYPCB still lags industry peers in chemical safety practices. We found no evidence of a strategy to phase out potentially harmful chemicals in its products.Products such as PCBs have high potential to capture opportunities in clean technology (cleantech) markets. Yet, unlike with leading peers, NYPCB's strategic focus on developing cleantech applications for its PCBs seems limited. We found no evidence of investment targets to expand its product lines in the cleantech space.Per our model, manufacturing PCBs is typically labor intensive, exposing NYPCB to work disruption risks in case of labor unrest. However, it leads peers in labor management. It appears to conduct annual engagement surveys to help gauge morale. We also found evidence of employee training programs that may boost productivity.

UNITED ARROWS has been upgraded to 'A' from 'BBB'. Improvements in UNITED ARROWS' governance practices drive the upgrade. We found new evidence of a general policy against corruption, backed by whistleblower protection from retaliation. On corporate governance, our analysis of accounting practices in the Governance assessment no longer includes key metrics derived from accounting ratios. Our latest analysis indicates limited risks related to the company's accounting practices compared to global peers; this also contributed to the upgrade.UNITED ARROWS' small workforce (4,213 in FY 2021 vs. industry average of 87,619 as of Oct 2022) and sole operations in Japan, where the likelihood of labor unrest is low, may lower the company's exposure to labor management complexity. Nevertheless, like leading peers, it offers non-pay benefits to help retain staff and conducts annual engagement survey to monitor employee morale.As an apparel retailer operating in Japan, where privacy and data security regulations are stringent, UNITED ARROWS could face regulatory risks in case of data breach. Yet, we found limited evidence of audits on data security and an information system certified to globally accepted standards, such as ISO 27001; thus, it lags peers.UNITED ARROWS trails peers in adopting strong programs to mitigate risks of increase in purchasing costs tied to volatile energy prices. Our assessment reveals limited evidence of product life cycle assessments. This could limit its ability to manage risks, mainly in the supply chain, where the bulk of its carbon footprint lies.

ESG_HEADLINE: Relatively strong labor programs as operations expand; lags global peers on corporate governance
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Far Eastern New Century Corporation (FENC's) rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. In 2021, FENC broadened its recycling operations, with expansions underway in Malaysia, Vietnam and the Philippines.  This presents opportunities to tap the demand for recycled materials. As of FY 2021, rPET and recycled polyester filament products do not appear to constitute a substantial portion of total revenues. Its expanding operations may increase production requirements, and evidence indicates relatively it has robust employee management programs which may help manage related risks.FENC has a relatively small workforce (2021: 30,937 employees vs. 100,408 industry average, as of November 2022), which may present lower labor management complexity. That said, we found evidence of relatively robust programs covering employee engagement and professional development. Its job rotation program across country sites may also facilitate career growth.The company's business ethics practices lead those of most global peers. Its policies are overseen at the executive level and extend throughout its supply chains. Implementation mechanisms include staff training and audits; likewise, anti-corruption clauses are included in procurement contracts.FENC is a controlled company: 42.1% of voting rights (July 2022) are held by its founding family. The company is also involved in a series of cross-shareholdings with other companies, which is rare in its home market Taiwan (only 9% of companies are flagged). Potential board entrenchment (nine of 13 directors serving for over 15 years) may also limit management oversight.

ESG_HEADLINE: Lags peers in governance; M&A activity presents high exposure to staff management and quality risks
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: FAW Jiefang Group has been downgraded to 'CCC' from 'B'. FAW Jiefang lags peers in adopting robust governance structures. The former CEO, who is also a representative of the controlling shareholder, remains on the board, which may raise questions related to the subordination of minority investor interests. In 2020, FAW Car acquired FAW Jiefang, and changed its main business to R&D, production, and sale of commercial vehicles. This led to increased employee headcount, which may increase exposure to workforce management complexities.Automakers with large revenues have higher exposure to product quality risks, compared to companies with low sales footprints. Due to the business acquisition in 2020, FAW Jiefang's reported sales increased by 343% in FY 2020, relative to average sales from FY 2017-2019. Further, a lack of disclosure on warranty expenses may impede investor analysis of the company's quality management performance.Despite evidence of research in automation and smart mobility solutions, the company's three-year R&D expenditure/sales ratio of 2.35% lagged the industry average of 5.06%, as of November 2021. This may hinder its long-term innovation capacity.FAW Jiefang is exposed to risks related to productivity, owing to labor-intensive operations. Further, because of the business acquisition, FAW Jiefang's employees increased to 21,077 in FY 2020, from 6,891 in FY 2019 (205.9% increase). Yet, the company's labor management practices appear to trail those of peers, with limited evidence of robust engagement programs.

ESG_HEADLINE: M&A plans may boost cleantech strategy; robust employee programs to mitigate restructuring risks
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Keppel's rating is unchanged at 'AAA'. The company maintains its restructuring plans as of FY 2022, with the upcoming merger of its Offshore & Marine segment with rig builder Sembcorp Marine (definitive agreement signed in April 2022). The latter's involvement in clean technology (e.g., offshore wind farms and hydrogen-powered vessels) may support Keppel's pivot into the energy transition space. The company leads global peers on corporate governance and adopts industry-leading initiatives to mitigate workforce restructuring risks.Keppel derived ~41% of FY 2020 group revenue from cleantech, including waste-to-energy solutions and green-certified buildings, per MSCI's Sustainable Impact Metrics assessment. Through acquisitions and joint ventures, the company aims to expand its renewable energy portfolio, and develop sustainable infrastructures for EV charging and smart grids.The upcoming merger may pose staff integration challenges, given Sembcorp Marine's headcount of about 11,000 employees (FY 2021). Keppel's asset management, engineering, and real estate operations also require a skilled workforce. The company conducts regular surveys to help gauge workplace sentiment, and has education support and talent mapping strategies that may foster staff development.Construction and shipbuilding operations may entail high exposure to risks tied to workplace safety. Like most peers, Keppel has safety management certifications (i.e., ISO 45001). However, as of March 2022, it was under probe over a shipyard accident that allegedly resulted in a worker fatality.

Hanatour's rating is unchanged at 'B'. Travel agencies typically collect substantial sensitive data; this exposes Hanatour to regulatory action and adverse impact on reputation tied to data breach or misuse, more so with strict privacy laws in South Korea (FY 2021: ~77% of revenue). The company lags peers in mitigating the risks. In July 2022, Hanatour was issued a ~USD 7,628 fine by the Supreme Court of Korea over alleged failure to prevent cyberattacks in 2017. On corporate governance, Hanatour continues to lag most global peers.The company's board lacks a majority of independent directors, as well as an independent chair. This may limit management oversight. Further, the absence of a pay committee and limited disclosure on executive pay may not be aligned with investors' long-term interests.Hanatour has data security measures, such as encryption. However, unlike leading peers, it appears to lack penetration testing to assess system vulnerability. Also, Hanatour's information systems appear to lack certifications to globally recognized data security standards such as ISO 27001.Our model suggests Hanatour operates in regions (FY 2021: 100% of assets in Asia, including South Korea) where there is moderate to high likelihood of labor unrest. The company has industry-standard employee benefits to mitigate related labor risks. Recent company disclosures also suggest evidence of education support provided to select staff. However, we found no evidence of annual engagement surveys which may limit its ability to assess workforce satisfaction.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improvements in corporate governance and carbon emissions management
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: ENN-NG has been upgraded to 'BBB' from 'BB'. Despite being a controlled company, ENN-NG adopts measures for representation of minority shareholders, including an independent director majority on the board. Also, the removal of the key metrics derived from accounting ratios (Asset-Liability Valuation and Revenue Recognition) in the Governance assessment contributed to the upgrade due to its relatively low accounting risk compared to global peers. Further, ENN-NG enhanced its climate targets; this may help manage carbon-related risks.The company is average relative to home market peers on corporate governance. Its board has independent majority from both management and other interests; this may help provide objective management oversight. However, its disclosures on executive pay seem limited; this impedes peer comparison.ENN-NG aims to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050, underpinned by intensity reduction targets of 20% by 2025 and 50% by 2030 for scope 1 and 2 carbon emissions. With China's increasing demand for natural gas and renewable energies, besides using cleaner energy sources, the company adopts initiatives in hydrogen production technologies and renewable energy development.ENN-NG's presence primarily in China (99% of FY 2021 operations), where workplace incidents are frequent, as per our model, may expose the company to operational disruptions tied to workplace safety incidents. The company's safety management system appears industry typical. It adopts group-wide safety policies and certifies select operations to ISO 45001 standards.

Shanghai Bailian Group has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'B'. Following the resignation of a non-executive director who was a former CEO, we no longer flag the board for leadership concerns. With recent changes in board and audit committee composition, we also no longer flag any director for overboarding; this may strengthen the board and committee's effectiveness contributed to the upgrade. Overall, Shanghai Bailian's corporate governance practices are average relative to home market peers.In the wake of China's ongoing anti-corruption campaign and as a state-owned entity, the company may face increased regulatory scrutiny on its ethics practices. It undertakes training for employees and audits of ethics standards to mitigate corruption-related risks. However, we found no evidence of a whistleblower protection system.The revised evaluation of product safety risks (removal of company-specific component based on revenue) has resulted in decrease in the company's overall risk exposure, helping the upgrade. As a food retailer, it could face regulatory and reputational risks in the event of food safety issues. Like leading peers, the company conducts routine supplier inspection and trains employees on food safety to mitigate such risks.The company collects customer data through its online operations, which may expose it to potential data security-related risks. Unlike better-performing peers, it appears to lack a dedicated body responsible for data security or of regular data system audits to preempt such risks.

We initiate coverage of SHANGHAI DIESEL ENGINE at 'B'. SDE, based in China, manufactures internal combustion engines for commercial vehicles and construction machinery. Research indicates the risk of inducements to involve in unfair business practices is high in these segments. The exposure to risk appears to be higher for state-owned entities such as SDE. However, our research found limited information on policies and programs to monitor corporate behavior. Additionally, we note weaknesses in the company's practices to manage toxic emissions.While the company has an anti-corruption framework, we found no evidence of robust compliance mechanisms such as whistleblower protection or employee training, unlike leading peers. SDE's corporate governance practices appear on par with those of home market peers. However, the board is not majority independent; this may limit objective oversight of management.As a manufacturer of diesel engines, SDE's exposure to risks of environmental liabilities and compliance costs resulting from toxic emissions and waste is moderate, relative to peers. While the company has an environmental management system, we found no evidence of toxic emission reduction targets.SDE's relatively small workforce (1,890 employees vs. industry average of 15,773 employees as of April 2021) may pose lower labor management complexity. While the company offers select non-compensation benefits and career development opportunities to employees, it lags leading industry peers in mechanisms to facilitate engagement for monitoring employee satisfaction.

Highwealth's rating is unchanged at 'B'. The company's corporate governance practices are now average compared to those of global and home market peers, following some improvements related to the board structure. We note the former chair, who previously served as the CEO, was replaced by a new chair in May 2021. Further, the board is now majority independent of management. However, Highwealth continues to lag global peers in adopting robust business ethics oversight and audits, and ethics training for all employees.Real estate developers, such as Highwealth, are exposed to the risk of operational disruptions and liabilities in the event of job safety incidents. While the company conducts safety training for its employees and aims for zero occupational disasters, it continues to trail industry peers in having detailed safety controls that extend to contractors. Further, it appears to lack widely accepted safety certifications such as ISO 45001.The growing global demand for sustainable and energy-efficient properties presents growth opportunities in green buildings. However, unlike with its better-performing peers, we found limited evidence of the company's property portfolio achieving recognized green building certifications such as LEED.Residential property developers could face high warranty costs in the event of construction quality lapses. Yet, Highwealth appears to lack detailed certification and training programs for its construction contractors to enhance product quality.

ESG_HEADLINE: Lags global market peers in business ethics; limited talent management programs
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Sanan Optoelectronics' rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. Sanan Optoelectronics (Sanan) continues to trail global market peers in business ethics programs. We found no evidence of best practices, such as ethics standard audits, employee training, or whistleblower protection, that could help mitigate corruption-related risks. Moreover, developing LEDs typically requires specialized talent. Yet, Sanan continues to trail industry peers in mitigating talent attraction and retention risks.The growing demand in the mini-LED display market generally requires chip manufacturers such as Sanan to stay ahead of the curve in terms of innovation; this fuels intense competition for talent. Yet, unlike leading peers, Sanan seems to lack programs to boost workforce diversity that could help attract key talent.Manufacturing LED and RF chips may be considered water-intensive, as per our model, posing risks of operational disruptions or higher input costs for Sanan in the event of water scarcity. However, it lags industry peers in implementing strong water-conservation measures. We found no evidence of measures to assess water risk such as water-use projections of its production facilities.China's increasing reliance on imports of tin, tungsten, tantalum, and gold may expose chip manufacturers such as Sanan to reputational or regulatory risks should such minerals be traced to conflict zones. However, Sanan lags industry peers in due diligence practices. It appears to lack supplier verification schemes for its raw materials.

ESG_HEADLINE: Limited anti-corruption measures raise concerns
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: AVIC Industry-Finance Holdings has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'B'. The rating upgrade is driven by improvements in the company's practices to help manage potential adverse environmental impacts of its lending activities. We found evidence of a formal framework with industry-specific lending policies, enforced with ESG due diligence and risk assessments. AVIC Industry-Finance Holdings has also expanded its business involvement in green finance markets. Further, the company leads peers in financing underserved groups in China.The company leads peers in offering inclusive finance through its leasing, trust, and securities subsidiaries. Such initiatives may help engage with financially underserved clients, such as small enterprises (e.g., funding for procurement of wind power equipment in China). We also note its USD 11 billion funding to western China (considered a less-developed and underbanked region) in FY 2021.We note improvements in the company's efforts such as engagement surveys and education support to help retain skilled talent in the competitive environment. Its employee turnover was 13% in 2021, on par with the industry average as of July 2022.While the board has an independent majority, the chair/CEO role is combined; this may hinder board independence. While related-party transactions with the controlling owner increased to 16.7% of expenses in 2021 (14.6% in 2020), its fully independent audit committee may exert financial oversight. On corporate behavior, it lags peers in adopting a detailed ethics policy and regular ethics audits.
CompanyName: Real Estate Developmentand Diversified Activities LLC

ESG_HEADLINE: Limited environmental mitigation programs
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: We initiate coverage of Ningbo Shanshan at 'CCC'. The production of battery materials typically involves high levels of toxic emissions and waste generation; this could expose the company to risks of incurring environmental liabilities. Yet, Ningbo Shanshan appears to lack strong programs and quantitative targets to reduce emission of key air pollutants (NOx/SOx). Further, the company trails industry peers in chemical management practices. Unlike with better-performing peers, we found no evidence of plans to phase out hazardous chemicals.Owing to China's carbon neutrality goal by 2060, Ningbo Shanshan is exposed to related compliance risks. Despite this, we found no information on the company's GHG emissions figures; this may impede performance comparison with peers.Ningbo Shanshan trails global peers in governance practices. In the absence of a fully independent audit committee, related-party transactions (4.8% of expenses and 4.8% of total assets in FY 2020) with controlling shareholder (39.9% of voting power, as of January 2022) may increase the potential governance risk associated with these transactions for all investors.Ningbo Shanshan is well-positioned to capitalize on clean technology opportunities through its involvement in manufacturing of lithium batteries and photovoltaic products. Its three-year (2018-2020) average R&D/sales ratio, at 4.6%, exceeded the industry average of 3.31% for specialty chemicals sub-industry (constituents of MSCI ACWI Index), as of December 2021. However, unlike industry leaders, it appears to lack a formal cleantech strategy.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improvements in governance; but with weaknesses in pay practices
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: THDB has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'B'. We note improvements in the company's governance. Its board now has a fully independent majority, which may promote independent management oversight. THDB's ownership structure leads that of peers in China and seems to be in line with investor interests. Its pay practices trail those of global and home market peers.
