The total pay awarded to the CEO exceeded 3 times the median pay of other executives in FY 2020.Like pharma peers, THDB has high exposure to corruption risks due to multiple touchpoints with the government for approval. However, its business ethics framework lags that of industry peers. Our research found limited evidence of board-level oversight and whistleblower protection.THDB has high exposure to potential product quality risks because it develops products for direct human use. Its quality management system is on par with industry peers, and features some supplier quality certification and customer satisfaction surveys. We note no product recalls and regulatory warnings in the three years that ended November 2021.As a pharma company, THDB relies on a highly-skilled workforce and thus, like peers, may face employee-centered challenges. Its talent management efforts lag those of leading peers. Its training opportunities appear to be available to select employees only.

PT Summarecon's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. The rating factors in PT Summarecon's subpar governance practices, relative to global peers. Its board lacks an independent majority and is entrenched, as two of five directors are long-serving (as of February 2022). Weak disclosures on executive pay also impede a holistic peer comparison. Moreover, it appears to lack strong compliance mechanisms such as extensive ethics trainings for staff. On the upside, the company's product safety and quality management compares favorably with peers.Like most property developers and operators, PT Summarecon has opportunities to leverage the demand for green properties. While it invests in water-efficient facilities and incorporates green spaces in its township projects, it lags peers in demonstrating efforts to obtain third-party certifications.PT Summarecon continues to face high exposure to risks of workplace accidents, given its operations in Indonesia, where data indicates injury rates are high. Despite this, the company continues to lag peers in adopting strong governance over safety programs. We found no disclosure on injury and fatality rates; this impedes performance assessment against peers.The company's residential property development business may expose it to risks of high warranty payouts in case of lapses in build quality. While we found no evidence of widely recognized product quality certifications such as ISO 9001, the company adopts practices such as staff training on quality and responsible marketing efforts.

Hyundai Elevator's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. Presence in South Korea (88% of FY 2020 operations), where frequency of corruption is perceived to be moderate, poses risks of unethical conduct. To mitigate such risks, the company's business ethics measures include whistleblower protection and ethics training for staff. It also has strong environmental management programs relative to peers; it has ISO 14001 certification and conducts annual environmental audits--practices that could help mitigate regulatory risks on toxic and waste releases.Hyundai Elevator's independent majority board may provide strong management oversight. Although the company has recurring related-party transactions with the family owner (the Hyun family held 26.47% voting rights as of Feb 2022), the presence of a fully independent audit committee can help mitigate potential governance risk from such transactions. However, unlike leading global peers, the company has limited disclosure on executive pay; this may hinder assessment of its pay policies against company performance.Hyundai Elevator offers a range of non-pay benefits and incentives, which may help retain staff and sustain workforce productivity. However, it lags peers in monitoring job satisfaction levels of its employees.The company has opportunities to participate in the growing demand for clean technology through its energy-efficient elevators and escalators. However, low R&D investments, at 1.25% of sales (2017-20) vs. the industry average of 3.67% as of March 2022, may limit innovation capacity relative to peers.

We initiate coverage of Roland at 'BBB'. As a musical equipment manufacturer, Roland appears to take numerous initiatives to maintain the quality of its products. The company's corporate governance practices lead those of its global and home market peers. However, Roland appears to lack programs to mitigate risks of possible poor working conditions in its supply chain. We also did not find evidence of measures to remove chemicals of concern from its products.The company has moderate exposure to regulatory and reputational risks associated with potential product defects, including litigation and costs connected with potential recalls. Our research indicates Roland has robust quality management systems, including certification to the ISO 9001 quality standard, and several centers (282 as of FY 2020) focused on R&D and testing product quality.The company's corporate governance, specifically, executive pay practices and shareholder rights, appear to be well-aligned with shareholder interests. Furthermore, the company has a fully independent audit committee to help provide independent oversight of management.We estimate over 80% of Roland's products are manufactured in Asia (Malaysia and China), which poses moderate exposure to the risk of potentially poor working conditions in the supply chain. Despite this, we did not find evidence of a supply chain code of conduct or of monitoring programs to help mitigate the risk of potential labor-related disruptions.

ESG_HEADLINE: Increased chemical safety risk exposure; strong carbon management programs relative to peers
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Shin-Etsu Polymer's rating is unchanged at 'A'. Our updated exposure assessment of plastic films and packaging products manufacturing (23% of Shin-Etsu Polymer's FY 2020 revenue), which may entail the use of hazardous chemicals as additives, reflected higher exposure to risks related to regulatory scrutiny and product reformulation costs. Shin-Etsu Polymer's chemical management practices, including provisions for hazard assessment, appear to be on par with those of peers. Further, the company leads peers in managing carbon emissions.Shin-Etsu Polymer is exposed to compliance costs related to stringent carbon regulations in Japan (69% of FY 2020 assets), where there is a target for carbon neutrality by 2050. The company's GHG emission intensity (FY 2020: 95.7 tCO2e/USD million) remained lower than the average (919, as of May 2022) for the commodity chemicals sub-industry (constituents of MSCI ACWI Index).Production of plastic products is typically considered to be toxic emissions-intensive in nature, exposing Shin-Etsu Polymer to the risk of incurring environmental liabilities. The company appears to lack strong programs to mitigate key air pollutants (NOx/SOx). Nonetheless, all the company's facilities in FY 2020 were certified to ISO 14001 standards, in line with industry practices.Shin-Etsu Polymer lags global peers in corporate governance practices. The company, like many of its Japanese peers, lacks a majority independent board and has multiple executives. This could limit strong management oversight.

Inabata's rating is unchanged at 'B'. The company continues to trail global peers on corporate governance practices. In particular, Inabata trails peers in establishing strong oversight of governance processes. Its board lacks an independent majority--a typical feature among Japanese firms. Such a board structure may hinder strong management oversight. The absence of a fully independent audit committee to oversee related-party transactions with its non-controlling owner may increase governance risks for minority investors.As per US OHSA data, the risk of employee injuries and fatalities is low for companies, such as Inabata, engaged in the chemicals, electronic components, or plastics trading businesses. Its operations in Indonesia (19% FY 2020 assets), especially as it operates complementary manufacturing and processing sites in the country, may encounter more frequent workplace accidents than in Japan and Europe. Yet, we found no evidence of safety improvement targets and programs monitoring health and safety metrics such as lost time injury and fatality rates, unlike with leading peers.Our research indicates the company has been active in the renewable energy markets through its various offerings, including equipment and components for wind and solar power, and fuel cell systems. We also found evidence of investment targets to expand its clean technology offerings further. Thus, the company leads peers. Inabata aims to expand its products that reduce environmental load as part of its medium-term business plan for 2023.

IVA_INDUSTRY: Oil & Gas Refining, Marketing, Transportation & Storage
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: San-Ai Oil's rating is unchanged at 'A'. Wholesale distributors of petroleum products have low exposure to environmental and social risks compared to petroleum refiners. San-Ai Oil's entire operations are in Japan, where data from the International Labor Organization indicates the frequency of workforce strikes is lower than in emerging markets. Yet, the company trails leading peers that have all of their workforce covered by collective bargaining agreements that could help mitigate labor unrest.Wholesale distributors of petroleum products may face risk of corruption in the procurement process, including through kickbacks and fraudulent billing. San-Ai Oil has strong internal controls such as a whistleblower system to manage these risks; however, unlike with industry-leading peers, we found no provision for legal protection to whistleblowers.With its entire operations in Japan, which, in April 2021, increased its GHG emissions reduction target to 46-50% by 2030 from 26% in 2013, San-Ai Oil could incur increased carbon pricing costs under the Tokyo emissions trading scheme and a national emissions trading scheme that has been proposed to be implemented in FY 2022-23. Its GHG emissions averaged 2.87 tCO2e/USD million over 2018-2020 (vs. industry average of 313, as of March 2022). However, unlike better-performing peers, the company has yet to set a quantitative reduction target (as of March 2022).

We initiate coverage of Insun ENT at 'B'. The rating is underpinned by the company's limited initiatives to address key ESG risks associated with its business. Notably, governance practices trail those of global peers. Insun ENT is controlled by IS Dongseo (holding ~45% voting power) via a stock pyramid structure and has reported related-party transactions with the controlling shareholder. Also, its board lacks an independent majority, which could raise concerns regarding potential subordination of the interests of minority investors.As a company involved in handling construction and automotive waste, Insun ENT is exposed to environmental liabilities associated with its operations. Its waste handling efforts include upcycling auto parts and incineration. However, when compared to better performing peers, it lacks compliance audits and has not set quantitative targets to reduce toxic emissions.Waste management operations are labor intensive, which could present workforce management challenges. Insun ENT's measures to address this risk appear to be on par with those of most industry peers and include employment benefits and training programs.Insun ENT's construction waste recycling operations could expose its employees to occupational safety risks. Yet, its safety management initiatives trail those of industry peers. We found no evidence of certification to the widely accepted OHSAS 18001 standard. Also, we found the lack of disclosure on key health and safety metrics such as lost time injury rate, which impedes comparison of performance with peers.

ESG_HEADLINE: Strong green building practice, but lags peer in board practice
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Japan Real Estate Investment has been downgraded to 'BBB' from 'A'. The downgrade is mainly driven by the company's corporate governance practice which lags global and home market peers. We found evidence of related-party transactions (RPTs) with Mitsubishi Estate (100% controlling shareholder as of Sep 2022) of rent income, which accounted 43.3% of its revenue in FY 2021. The absence of an audit committee may increase governance concerns associated with RPTs for minority investors. Our revised evaluation indicates the board lacks a nomination committee.The company is managed by Japan Real Estate Asset Management. A detailed assessment of the manager's human capital development practices indicated presence of a formal grievance redressal mechanism and professional training opportunities for employees. The manager also conducts annual engagement surveys to gauge job satisfaction levels. These initiatives may have helped keep employee turnover rate at 4.8% in 2021, much below the REMS industry turnover median of 15.0% as of May 2022.The company's focus on office properties provides plenty of opportunities to benefit from the demand for green buildings, as these properties are more energy intensive than residential properties. Besides investing in energy reduction programs, the company's manager has set a 35% carbon emission intensity reduction target by 2030 (vs. 2013 levels). Further, in FY 2021, around 73% of the portfolio (by number of buildings) was certified to green building standards, higher than the 2021 Office REITs sub-industry average of 53.0%, by number of buildings.

Kanamoto's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. The company continues to trail industry peers in managing its ESG-related risks. In particular, our research indicates Kanamoto lags peers in workplace safety management. Although the company has adopted a groupwide safety policy, we found limited evidence of strong practices such as regular safety audits and incident rate monitoring--practices that are commonly adopted by peers.Kanamoto's wholesale trade of metal products and construction equipment leasing business may present minimal opportunities in the clean technology domain. Yet, in efforts to promote the use of green technologies, Kanamoto leases heavy equipment models that are fuel-efficient and have lower emissions. The company also disclosed its strategy to promote an eco-friendly rental business by upgrading equipment to hybrid models. However, Kanamoto still lags peers in developing investment targets focused on expanding its cleantech portfolio.We continue to note weaknesses in Kanamoto's governance practices. Its executive-heavy board, while common in Japan, may limit independent oversight of management. Its heavy equipment leasing business supports public construction works and may involve related bidding activities that could present corruption risks. Yet, unlike with peers, we found no evidence of a detailed policy against bribery and corruption, or audits of its ethical standards.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improvements in talent management practices and data protection framework
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: KTB has been upgraded to 'BBB' from 'BB'. The recent reassessment of KTB indicated an improvement in the company's ESG performance relative to its ESG industry peers contributing to the upgrade (as of June 2022). KTB is exposed to potential hiring and retention challenges, given its reliance on qualified bankers and finance professionals. We note improvements in the bank's employee management practices. Evidence indicates KTB has annual staff surveys and leadership development training programs, measures which may help retain talent.KTB's performance on Privacy and Data Security--which focuses on the bank's exposure to evolving privacy regulations and on its ability to safeguard sensitive data--has improved since the last rating action. Please refer to the ESG Rating Drill Down and dedicated Privacy and Data Security sections of the report for more details.Methodology enhancements to the Consumer Financial Protection (formerly Financial Product Safety) Key Issue resulted in reassessment of the bank's initiatives to preempt unethical lending and mis-selling of financial products to customers. KTB has a robust complaint handling mechanism, which may help protect consumer interests. We note a reduction in consumer complaints by more than 30% YoY in FY 2021.KTB lags global peers on governance practices. Inclusion of the Corporate Behavior Theme in our Governance assessment resulted in a greater emphasis on business ethics practices and on exposure to risks related to corruption. We found no evidence of the bank conducting regular audits of ethical standards.

Komeri's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. Komeri's labor management practices are on par with those of Japanese peers, backed by collective agreements and non-statutory benefits; these could help mitigate risks linked to low employee morale and productivity. However, the company trails peers in adopting robust data security systems. Also, Komeri lags global peers on governance practices: we note weaknesses in its board structure, and found no evidence of policies against bribery and corruption.Komeri's exposure to risks related to labor management is low due to its small workforce (4,463 in FY 2020 vs. industry average of 81,204 as of April 2022) and operations in Japan (100% in FY 2020), where ILO data indicates low likelihood of labor unrest. The company offers training programs and stock options, which may help attract and retain talent.Komeri's retailing operations entail customer data collection in Japan, where stringent data security regulations apply. Thus, the company may face reputational and regulatory risks in case of a data breach. While Komeri undertakes industry-common practices such as employee training on cybersecurity, it lags better-performing peers in conducting regular data system audits to help preempt related risks.Komeri's board, like that of most Japanese peers, lacks majority independence and has multiple executives; these may limit strong management oversight. We also note shareholder dissent to the election of a director at the AGM 2021, likely indicating dissatisfaction with his performance.

ESG_HEADLINE: Limited evidence of robust practices across all ESG Key Issues
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: We initiate coverage of KOREA CIRCUIT at 'CCC'. As a manufacturer of printed circuit boards that generally contain hazardous chemicals, Korea Circuit's exposure to risk of reformulation costs is high. Yet, it trails industry peers in chemical safety practices: we found no evidence of monitoring systems or phase-out programs. It lags global and home peers in corporate governance. Its board is undersized and lacks an independent majority; this may impede management oversight. Also, we found limited disclosures on executive pay practices.Korea Circuit trails most global market peers in ethics practices. We found no evidence of mandatory business ethics training nor periodic audits on ethics standards that could help preempt potential unethical conduct. Also, we found no information on the body that oversees the company's ethical management programs.Manufacturing of printed circuit boards is labor-intensive, as per our model. This may expose Korea Circuit to risks of work disruption in case of labor unrest. However, its labor management practices lag those of peers. We found no evidence of engagement initiatives or of formal educational support programs that may help boost productivity.Printed circuit boards could present ample opportunities to leverage the demand for clean technology, as per our model. Korea Circuit's products find use in LEDs and electric vehicles. However, we found limited evidence of a focused strategy on developing a portfolio with clean technology applications, thus lagging industry peers.

ESG_HEADLINE: Lags peers on managing environmental and chemical safety risks
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: KPIC's rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. Unlike peers, the company appears to lack strong measures to mitigate chemical safety risks linked to the manufacture of industrial chemicals and plastic materials. Its business operations are generally carbon-intensive could expose KPIC to compliance costs. Yet, its GHG emissions intensity increased at a CAGR of 8% over 2017-20 to 964 tCO2e/USD million in FY 2020, exceeding the Commodity Chemicals sub-industry (constituents of the MSCI ACWI Index) average of 919 as of June 2022.Deriving 39% of FY 2021 revenue from South Korea, where chemical regulations are stringent, the company is exposed to potential reformulation costs. Yet, unlike better-performing peers, KPIC appears to lack a formal strategy to phase out hazardous chemicals.Manufacture of industrial chemicals is typically water intensive and may expose KPIC to the risk of operational disruptions in the event of water scarcity. Yet, the company lags peers in adopting strong water management efforts such as risk monitoring and alternative water source use.KPIC lags global peers on corporate governance practices. We note recurring related-party transactions with the controlling shareholder (Lee Family holds 41.5% of the voting rights as of August 2022); this may not align with shareholder interests. However, changes in the board composition led to an independent board majority; this may improve its oversight capabilities.

Keiyo's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. Keiyo's corporate governance and business ethics practices continue to lag those of global peers. The company also appears to trail peers in implementing stringent data security initiatives. On the upside, it has a small workforce (1,094 in FY 2021 vs. industry average of 81,204 as of April 2022) and its operations are solely in Japan, where the likelihood of labor unrest is low (as per ILO data). Its exposure to risk of operational disruptions from strikes is thus lower than that of peers.Like most Japanese peers, Keiyo's board lacks an independent majority; this could limit its ability to provide management oversight. We also note related-party transactions with a non-controlling owner (~62% of FY 2021 expenses); this, in the absence of a fully independent audit committee, may increase governance risk for minority investors. As regards business ethics, we found no evidence of anti-corruption policies and employees training on ethics standards.As a retailer with online operations, Keiyo collects and handles customers' data; this may expose it to regulatory and reputational risks in case of data breach. However, unlike with better-performing peers, we found no evidence of data system audits or employee training on data handling.The company offers industry-typical non-statutory benefits and training programs to attract and retain staff. We also found evidence of collective agreements; this could help workers negotiate for better working conditions and benefits.

Morinaga's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. Morinaga set environmental targets in 2021, including reduction in Scope 1 and 2 emissions by 30% (vs. FY 2019 baseline) and in plastic use in select product lines by 25% (vs. FY 2020 baseline). Morinaga aims to achieve these targets by 2030, suggesting a reinforced focus on minimizing its environmental footprint. However, the company continues to lag leading peers in adopting robust environmental measures in the agricultural supply chain, where the bulk of its environmental footprint lies.Reliance on water-intensive agricultural commodities, such as sourced sugar and dairy, for confectionery production may pose the risk of increased input costs in case of water shortages. Though Moringa has assessed water-related risks in its operations, we found no evidence of broad measures to reduce water use or of engagements with agricultural suppliers on water conservation and resilience.Morinaga lags global and home market peers on corporate governance. We found limited disclosures on executive pay, resulting in a lower score than that of global peers. Also, like most peers in Japan, it lacks an independent majority board; this may limit strong management oversight.Like those of leading peers, most of Morinaga's operations are certified to the Global Food Safety Initiative-benchmarked FSSC 22000 standards. The company conducts regular audits of raw materials to help enhance its oversight on food safety-related risks; this may help mitigate regulatory and reputational risks tied to potential food safety incidents.

ESG_HEADLINE: Industry-standard staff management programs; limited investments in clean technology development
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Misumi's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. Misumi's labor-related programs appear average, relative to peers. The company offers non-pay benefits and stock option plans, as well as training to upskill employees. Its governance practices are also generally average relative to global peers. However, while most peers in the machinery industry accelerate innovation and align strategies to develop clean technology (cleantech) products, Misumi seems to lag peers in increasing its capacity to tap opportunities in the cleantech space.Our research found some improvements in the company's board structure and pay practices. At the 2022 AGM, the company included one female director and no directors received significant negative votes (2 directors; 2021 AGM); this may indicate shareholder satisfaction. The company has also disclosed the CEO's pay details. However, it continues to have a non-independent majority board, which while typical among Japanese firms, may limit management oversight.Misumi's factory automation and die components segments (53% of FY 2021 revenue) may offer growth opportunities in the cleantech market. While we note the company's focus on developing products that enable digitalization and energy efficiency, it appears to have limited investments in cleantech development. The company's three-year average R&D/sales investment--a potential indicator of long-term innovation capacity--was 0.38% during 2018-2021, lower than the industry average of 5.13% as of October 2022.

ESG_HEADLINE: Strong labor management practices; trails peers in corporate governance
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Nitori's rating is unchanged at 'A'. Nitori has a small workforce (18,984 in FY 2021 vs. industry average of 87,619 as of Oct 2022), and it solely operates in Japan where the frequency of labor unrest is low, as per our model. As a result, its exposure to risks associated with labor complexity is relatively low. Like leading peers, we found evidence of collective agreements and non-statutory benefits. On the downside, the company lags global peers on overall governance practices.Nitori's business ethics framework is reinforced with a detailed policy against bribery and corruption to preempt potential unethical dealings. It also has a whistleblower policy against retaliation. However, like Japanese peers, its board lacks an independent majority, and 2 of 12 directors have had tenures of over 15 years (Jun 2022). These factors could limit management oversight.As a retailer with online presence, Nitori collects and handles customers' data; this may expose it to regulatory and reputational risks in case of data breach. While our reassessment indicates the company has data breach prevention and response plans, it appears to lack external data system audits and certification such as ISO 27001, unlike leading peers.Nitori is exposed to risks related to labor rights violation in the supply chain, as ~90% of its products (FY 2021) are sourced from developing countries, where incidence of poor working conditions is high as per model. Yet, it appears to lack audit of all suppliers (tier 2 and tier 3).

ESG_HEADLINE: Lags most peers in demonstrating programs to manage ESG-related risks and opportunities
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Vista Land & Lifescapes' rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. Real estate developers are exposed to risks of workplace accidents and fatalities. Vista Land & Lifescapes lags peers on employee and contractor safety initiatives. We found no evidence of the ISO 45001 certification and targets to improve its health and safety performance. Further, the company trails both global and home market peers on governance. Vista Land & Lifescapes also lags most peers in demonstrating a strong focus on sustainable property investments.As a developer of residential properties, Vista Land & Lifescapes has moderate opportunities to leverage the demand for green investments, as these properties are less energy intensive than retail or office assets. While the company tracks and monitors the energy usage of its projects, we found no evidence of properties certified to green building standards, unlike with better performing peers.Residential property development poses regulatory and reputational risks related to construction quality. Vista Land & Lifescapes monitors its customer satisfaction score to keep track of service quality. However, it appears to lack a warranty management system to help mitigate risks of high warranty payouts in case of lapses in construction quality.Vista Land & Lifescapes' board lacks an independent majority and independent key committees; this may impede management oversight. However, the company's ethics framework features best practices such as a detailed anti-bribery policy and ethics training.

Maxvalu's rating is unchanged at 'A'. The firm faces low labor-related risks due to a small workforce (2020: 2,801 vs. average as of January 2022: 158,542) and presence in Japan, where the incidence of labor unrest is low per ILO. Nevertheless, it offers non-statutory benefits and employee stock plans to help retain workforce. Further, the firm's data protection measures in its retail operations are relatively on par with those of peers. However, the firm lags most global peers on corporate governance.Maxvalu's online and in-store retail transactions may expose it to risks tied to data breach and misuse. To mitigate such risks, the company has delegated a data protection officer, and implements periodic system audits and employee training on cybersecurity.As a food retailer with a wide variety of private label brands, Maxvalu relies on environmentally intensive commodities, such as palm oil. This may expose its sourcing practices to high NGO scrutiny. Like better-performing peers, Maxvalu sources a portion of its palm oil from RSPO-certified sources. However, it appears to lack a groupwide target to source all its palm oil volumes from stringent RSPO schemes--segregated and identity preserved.Maxvalu's internal controls, reinforced with mandatory trainings, are on par with those of peers. However, we note recurring related-party transactions (13.5% of FY 2020 and FY 2021 expenses) with the controlling owner; this, along with the absence of a fully independent audit committee, may increase risks posed by such transactions.

Hub24 has been upgraded to 'A' from 'BBB'. The upgrade is largely driven by improvements in governance practices--Hub24 leads global peers on corporate governance and in adopting business ethics practices. Recent assessment indicates Hub24 incentivizes sustainability performance in its current executive pay policies through variable pay components. Further, it leads industry peers in data protection practices such as cybersecurity training for employees and periodic audits of IT systems which may help prevent security incidents.Inclusion of the Corporate Behavior Theme in Hub24's governance assessment resulted in a greater emphasis on business ethics practices. The company has adopted a robust business ethics framework which includes whistleblower protection and anti-corruption policy; these may help preempt potential unethical misconduct.Like industry peers, Hub24 relies on skilled staff and may, thus, be exposed to risks of employee attrition. The company acquired Class Limited in February 2022, and we note an increase in total workforce by ~75% YoY; this may expose the company to potential workforce integration challenges.Hub24's performance on Responsible Investment--which focuses on the company's efforts to integrate ESG factors in its investment management activities--has weakened since the last rating action. In our recent reassessment we found no evidence of dedicated staff to assess ESG risks in its advisory operations. Please refer to the ESG Rating Drill Down and Responsible Investment sections of the report for more details.

CMG Pharmaceutical's rating is unchanged at 'B'. We have revised our evaluation of exposure to product safety and quality risks by removing a company-specific component which was based on the size of operations. This has resulted in an increase in the company's overall risk exposure. CMG Pharmaceutical appears to trail industry peers on quality assurance: we found limited evidence of industry-standard practices such as company-wide certification to external quality standards. Also, we note weaknesses in the company's governance framework.The company lags global peers on corporate governance practices. The lack of an independent board majority and multiple executives on board may limit management oversight. Further, limited executive pay disclosures by the company limit the assessment of its pay practices.CMG Pharmaceutical is exposed to corruption-related risks due to factors such as multiple touchpoints with government for regulatory approvals, based on our model. While the company has anti-corruption polices and trains employees on ethics standards, we found no evidence of regular audits of ethics practices.As a company focused on manufacturing pharmaceuticals products, CMG Pharmaceutical is highly reliant on a skilled workforce. The company has channels for employees to confidentially report grievances, but appears to lack employee engagement and talent development initiatives--practices adopted by leading peers.

ESG_HEADLINE: Poor governance performance drives low rating
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Eugene Technology's rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. Eugene Technology continues to lag peers across most ESG Key Issues we assess for semiconductor equipment manufacturers. The company trails market peers on corporate governance, notably, board structure. Also, unlike leading peers, Eugene Technology appears to lack a strong business ethics framework with detailed anti-bribery policies and provisions for whistleblower protection. Further, the company lags industry peers on talent management programs.The board is undersized (three members) and lacks an independent majority. The controlling shareholder (35% voting rights, as of August 2022)--who is also a CEO--serves as the executive chair alongside a co-CEO on the board. These factors may limit management oversight.Due to its involvement in manufacturing semiconductor deposition equipment, the company has lower reliance on a highly skilled workforce than chip manufacturers. That said, unlike leading peers, Eugene Technology seems to lack annual engagement surveys and career progression programs--measures that may help retain talent. Also, we found no staff turnover data; this impedes peer comparison.As a semiconductor fabrication equipment provider and upstream supplier for semiconductor markets, Eugene Technology has limited opportunities to capitalize on opportunities in clean technology (cleantech) relative to industry peers. Unlike with better-performing peers, the company appears to lack strategic initiatives to expand into the cleantech space.

ESG_HEADLINE: Limited evidence of talent management and business ethics practices
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Helixmith has been downgraded to 'CCC' from 'B'. Our updated assessment of Helixmith indicates weaknesses in the company's performance across key ESG parameters, notably in talent management and governance. Like its biotech peers, Helixmith relies on skilled workforce to support its R&D and manufacturing operations. Yet, its talent management practices appear subpar. We found no evidence of engagement and employee development initiatives--practices adopted by leading peers. Further, its overall governance practices lag those of global peers.Helixmith's board lacks an independent majority and has multiple executives; this may hinder strong management oversight. We also found limited executive pay disclosures; this may limit investors' ability to assess its pay practices. Further, methodology enhancements to the Corporate Behavior theme resulted in a greater emphasis on business ethics practices and exposure to risks related to corruption. Yet, we found no evidence of a formal anti-corruption policy or of whistleblower protection mechanisms.Helixmith appears to have lower exposure to product safety and quality risks than peers with a larger product portfolio. We found no evidence of regulatory warnings or product recalls as of end-2021. However, it appears to lack certification to international quality standards.As a biotech firm, Helixmith could face risks in the event of toxic byproducts from its operations. We note weaknesses in its toxic emissions and wastes management; we did not find evidence of audits or certification to international environmental standards.
CompanyName: Real Estate Developmentand Diversified Activities Global

ESG_HEADLINE: Subpar governance and talent management practices
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Bioneer's rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. The company's corporate governance practices lag those of most global peers. While we note the board is no longer undersized and has independent members, it still lacks an independent majority, is potentially entrenched (four of the seven directors have served for more than 15 years as of August 2021), and has no female directors. These may limit oversight of management and diversity in viewpoints in decision-making. Bioneer also lags most global peers on business ethics practices.Factors such as multiple touchpoints with the government for approvals could expose Bioneer to corruption risks. We found limited evidence of policies against bribery and corruption, and a mechanism for whistleblower protection. However, the company appears to lack compliance mechanisms such as audits and ethics training for employees.Reliance on a highly skilled workforce for R&D activities exposes biotech companies to talent-centered risks. While we found evidence of a grievance channel, Bioneer still lags peers in implementing robust staff management programs such as employee engagement surveys to gauge job satisfaction.We have revised our evaluation of exposure to product safety and quality risks by removing a company-specific component based on the size of operations. This has resulted in an increase in Bioneer's overall risk exposure. The company's industry-typical quality management practices include ISO certification. However, unlike leading peers, Bioneer appears to lack practices related to responsible marketing.

ESG_HEADLINE: Weaknesses in corporate governance relative to global peers; lags peers across all ESG Key Issues
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: NEOWIZ has been downgraded to 'CCC' from 'B'. A recent industry reassessment indicated a lower ESG performance score for NEOWIZ than ESG industry peers, contributing to the downgrade (as of June 2022). The company trails most global peers on corporate governance. Its board has multiple executives, including the executive chair and two co-CEOs (July 2022); this may impede management oversight. Also, the controlling owner held 38% of voting rights (July 2022) via a stock pyramid structure; this may not align with minority investor interests.Limited executive pay disclosures by NEOWIZ limit the assessment of its pay practices. We also found limited disclosure on its business ethics framework and related compliance programs; this impedes comparison with those of global and home market peers.Reliance on tech-oriented talent to develop games may expose NEOWIZ to talent management challenges. The company appears to have an internship program, which may help sustain a steady talent pool. However, unlike leading peers, it seems to have limited employee incentivization and career upskilling programs, which may help incentivize productivity.NEOWIZ derived 89% of FY 2021 revenue from South Korea--where data laws are stringent--and may thus face regulatory and reputational risks in case of a data breach. The company's cybersecurity framework has provisions for extensive user rights and practices for preemptive breach mitigation. However, NEOWIZ appears to lag leading peers that conduct regular external audits of IT systems and have third-party certifications (e.g., ISO 27001).

Ricoh Leasing's rating is unchanged at 'A'. Ricoh Leasing continues to lead industry peers in human capital initiatives. Its workforce engagement program includes quarterly employee engagement surveys which could help to gauge employee morale. Its average employee turnover of ~1.9% in the three years through 2021 remained below the industry average of ~10%. Further, Ricoh Leasing's corporate behavior is average relative to global peers.Ricoh Leasing provides leasing and finance services focusing on office-related equipment to small and medium enterprises. This  may help improve access to financing and support growth opportunities in that segment.The inclusion of the Corporate Behavior Theme in the bank's Governance assessment resulted in a greater emphasis on business ethics practices. It has a whistleblower protection program; however, we found limited disclosures on audits of ethics practices and on employee training, measures that may help mitigate potential unethical business conduct.The board has an independent majority, and its fully independent pay committee may help oversee the alignment of pay practices with investor interests. However, we note significant votes against two directors at the 2022 AGM, indicating potential shareholder dissatisfaction with their performance. Further, we note the presence of related-party transactions with Ricoh Japan (owning 33.67% as of March 2022), which can raise concerns for minority shareholders.

Proto has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'B'. The improvements in the company's board structure drive the upgrade. Its board has 33.3% female directors, following the appointment of two independent board members in June 2021. Further, board independence improved from 20% to 33.3% (as of January 2022). However, Proto lacks an independent board majority. It has low exposure to corruption-related risks due to operations in Japan, where the incidence of corruption is perceived to be low. We note it appears to lack an anti-bribery policy.Despite some improvements in the board, Proto lags global and home market peers on ownership structure. The presence of a controlling shareholder (Yumegen Co., Ltd with 33.9% voting rights as of January 2021) and the company's complex cross-shareholding ownership pattern may pose risks to minority shareholder interests.With businesses ranging from information publication to internet retailing and real estate, Proto relies on skilled talent to maintain its business operations. The company continues to lag industry peers in implementing strong employee management initiatives such regular engagement surveys that may help gauge staff morale.Internet-based retailing services and operations in Japan (FY 2020: 100% revenue), where strict data privacy laws apply, could expose the company to regulatory and reputational risks in case of a data breach. Evidence suggests Proto undertakes industry-common measures, such as encryption technology and employee training on data security, that may help safeguard data security.

Arcs has been downgraded to 'B' from 'BB'. New evidence indicates Arcs has cross-shareholdings with multiple companies, despite calls for reduction in those under Japan's revised corporate governance code. Such arrangements may lead to double-counting of equity values; this leads to the downgrade. Overall, the company's corporate governance practices lag those of global peers. While common in the Japanese market, Arcs lacks a majority independent board; this could limit the board's management oversight capabilities.Our revised model evaluation, specifically the removal of a company-specific size component, has resulted in a decrease in Arcs' product safety-related risk exposure. Unlike leading peers, it appears to lack periodic supplier or raw material audits; this could limit Arcs' ability to preempt potential product quality issues.Increasingly stringent data protection laws in Japan (FY 2022: 100% revenue) may expose the company's data handling practices to higher regulatory scrutiny. Nonetheless, the company continues to lag peers in implementing robust data protection measures, such as incident response plans or annual IT system audits.Arcs has low exposure to labor unrest risks due to its small workforce (5,810 as of FY 2022 vs. 158,542 industry average as of January 2022). The company provides market-typical non-statutory benefits and development opportunities; this may help sustain employee morale and productivity.

ESG_HEADLINE: Strong labor and safety programs; lags industry peers in corporate governance practices
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: SCG's rating is unchanged at 'AA'. Our assessment indicates SCG continues to demonstrate robust labor management practices such as leadership development programs and variable performance pay benefits. Further, its employee safety programs and performance lead those of its industry peers. However, 33.3% of directors on its board are over-boarded; this might negatively impact their effectiveness on this board. SCG trails global peers on corporate governance practices: we found limited disclosures on its executive pay practices.SCG's diversified business (cement - 33%, chemicals - 44% and packaging business - 23% of FY 2021 revenues) lowers its risk of facing fines and operational disruptions if it falls short of stringent toxic and carbon emission norms compared to pure play cement peers. Research indicates it continues to increase adoption of alternative energy sources as part of its carbon mitigation strategy. Further, it targets to reduce its GHG emissions by 20% by 2030 and become net zero by 2050.Cement manufacturing activities typically expose the workforce to risk of workplace accidents. Our analysis indicates SCG's employee safety initiatives are stronger than those of its peers. It reported LTIR of 0.39 per million hours in FY 2021 (vs MSCI ACWI construction materials industry average of 21.30 as of Dec 2021), indicating presence of robust safety measures.SCG's corporate ethics practices are on par with those of peers, with programs such as detailed anti-corruption policies, staff training on ethics standards, and board oversight.

ESG_HEADLINE: Strong business ethics framework; lags peers in water management
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: PI Industries has been upgraded to 'BBB' from 'BB'. Our updated assessment of the company's business ethics and chemical management practices contributed to the upgrade. PI Industries has a formal anti-corruption policy and provisions for whistleblower protection. Further, we found evidence of initiatives to develop safer alternatives to hazardous agrichemical products. Yet, unlike better-performing peers, the company appears to lack formal plans to phase out hazardous chemicals.PI Industries' corporate governance practices compare favorably with those of global and home market peers. Most directors on the board and the chairman are independent--features that could help in oversight of management.PI Industries mainly operates in India (FY 2020: 99% assets), where carbon emission regulations are less stringent than in developed markets like the EU; this results in low exposure to potential compliance costs relative to peers. Unlike industry leaders, it appears to lack time-bound quantitative targets to reduce GHG emissions.PI Industries is exposed to water scarcity-related risks, as water stress is perceived to be higher in India than in other countries. The company's withdrawal intensity of 1,201 m3/USD million in FY 2020 was lower than the average of 19,665 for the fertilizers and agricultural chemicals sub-industry (constituents of MSCI ACWI Index), as of February 2022. However, unlike with better-performing peers, we found limited evidence of quantitative water reduction targets.

BAT-M's rating is unchanged at 'AA'. Exposure to product safety and quality risks was revised to capture the inherent negative health impact associated with the use of tobacco. Tobacco companies are also subject to stringent regulations over the sale and advertising of their products globally. Our research indicates BAT-M has adopted strong marketing programs related to the consumption of tobacco products, including the prohibition of youth targeting, and reports instances of non-compliance with its policy.Growing of tobacco and manufacturing of cigarettes are water intensive. The company continues to demonstrate strong water management initiatives, encompassing time-bound targets and Y-o-Y water consumption reduction from 2019 to 2021.BAT-M's expectations from its tobacco suppliers are laid out in its standards of business conduct policy, which contains important provisions on labor standards, including the prohibition of child and forced labor and adoption of a safe working environment. However, BAT-M's parent BAT faces allegations of human rights violation at suppliers' facilities. This exposes BAT-M to operational disruption risks, as it sources all products from its parent.The company has low exposure to chemical safety risks, as all its operations are in Malaysia, where regulations are less stringent than in the EU or US markets. Unlike with its parent BAT, we found limited disclosure on the formulation of BAT-M's products or commitments to any reformulation initiatives.

Sundaram Finance has been upgraded to 'A' from 'BBB'. The upgrade is largely driven by improvements in the company's data protection policies and human capital management programs. We found evidence of security audit procedures and of a board-level committee constituted for oversight of cyber risks; this may help prevent risks of potential data breaches. It also has a robust grievance redressal mechanism, which may help in employee retention. However, we found no evidence of programs to improve workplace diversity.Sundaram Finance adopts robust customer protection policies, relative to industry peers. Its debt collection policy has provision for employee training. We also found evidence of transparent advertising procedures that could help safeguard consumer interests. It also has an ombudsman mechanism for customer complaint resolution. However, customer complaints increased ~140% y-o-y in FY 2020.The company leads global peers on corporate governance, particularly board structure; this could support independent management oversight. The inclusion of the Corporate Behavior Theme in the Governance assessment resulted in a greater emphasis on the bank's business ethics practices. We found no evidence of regular ethics audits and limited information on staff ethics training.While the company appears to offer specialized products, such as machinery term loans and working capital loans, to small and medium enterprises, we found limited evidence of lending to underserved markets.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improved governance practices, but fatalities continue to increase
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Vedanta Limited has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'B'. Improvements in the company's corporate governance structures drive the upgrade. As of 2022 AGM, Vedanta Limited was no longer flagged for significant votes against directors (3 directors; 2021 AGM), indicating potential shareholder satisfaction. Also, it incentivizes sustainability performance in its current executive pay policies. We also note strong strategies to manage biodiversity and water-related risks in its diversified mining operations. It lags peers in safety performance.As a miner and smelter, Vedanta Limited is exposed to risk of operational disruptions tied to workplace incidents. Like peers, it has adopted a safety management system certified to ISO 45001. Its target to reduce injury rates covers contractors. However, our research indicates it has yet to (as of FY 2021) achieve its zero-fatality goal: fatalities have increased YoY from 8 in FY 2020 to 12.Vedanta Limited operates in India (~36% of assets as of 2021), which targets net zero emissions by 2070. Yet, its goal is to achieve this by 2050. It has since launched green aluminum, produced using renewable energy sources. Yet, its GHG intensity remains above the industry average (FY 2021: 3,587 vs. 1,010 t CO2e as of Q3 2022).As a diversified natural resources company, Vedanta Limited is exposed to community conflicts posed by its extractive activities. To manage such risks, it has established grievance channels to facilitate community engagement. Also, like leading peers, it provides human rights training to its security personnel.

ESG_HEADLINE: Trails peers in mitigating risks related to tailpipe GHG emissions and product liability
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Tata Motors' rating is unchanged at 'B'. The company is the market leader for electric vehicles in India, with 87% market share in FY 2021 (FY 2020: 71.4%). This may help drive revenue growth, with the Indian EV industry expected to grow by 49% (CAGR) till 2030 (per IESA). Yet, EVs constituted just 2.6% of the company's unit sales for 2021, lower than that of leading industry peers. This, along with the relatively high exhaust CO2 footprint of the performance-dedicated Jaguar Land Rover fleet may expose the company to related risks.In September 2022, South Korea's ministry for transport imposed a penalty on Tata Motors' subsidiary, Jaguar Land Rover Korea, over alleged lapses in vehicle safety standards. Also, Tata Motors' three-year (FY 2019-21) average warranty expenses/sales (3.46%) exceeded the industry average (1.52%, as of November 2022).The company continues to trail most global peers on business ethics: a May 2021 investigation by the Competition Commission of India over alleged anti-competitive practices still weighs on its rating. Tata Motors' corporate governance is average relative to that of global peers: with the addition of an independent director in May 2022, the board has majority independence.The labor-intensive nature of its operations exposes the company to risks tied to potential labor unrest. Also, it operates in regions with moderate to high exposure to risk of labor unrest, as per our model. Tata Motors' mitigation measures are industry-typical: we note engagement surveys, which may help monitor job satisfaction.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improvement in governance practices
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Torrent has been upgraded to 'BBB' from 'BB'. A recent industry reassessment indicated a higher ESG performance score for Torrent, relative to its ESG industry peers, contributing to an upgrade. We also note improvement in its governance practices. Its business ethics practices are average relative to those of Indian peers. We found evidence of ethics training and whistleblower protection from retaliation; these contributed to the upgrade. Torrent's corporate governance practices are average relative to those of global peers.The removal of key metrics derived from accounting ratios (Revenue Recognition, Expense Recognition, and Asset-Liability Valuation) in the Governance assessment has improved its Governance score due to its relatively low accounting risk compared to global peers. That said, we note three non-executive directors are overboarded (as of October 2022); this may hinder management oversight.We have revised our evaluation of exposure to product safety and quality risks by removing a company-specific component based on the size of operations. This has resulted in an increase in Torrent's overall risk exposure. Further, we note one Class II (moderate), five Class III (minor) product recalls, and one Form 483 warning from January 2020 to November 2022.Like pharma peers, Torrent relies on highly skilled staff for its operations. Yet, it lags peers in talent management: we found no evidence of variable pay or employee stock benefits--measures that may aid in talent attraction and retention.

ESG_HEADLINE: Strong business ethics practices; perceived human capital challenges tied to recent layoffs
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Tech Mahindra's rating is unchanged at 'A'. Tech Mahindra maintains a robust business ethics framework that leads home market peers. Per our reassessment, it has executive oversight and extends compliance training to contractors. As an IT consulting firm, Tech Mahindra relies on highly skilled talent. Layoffs and a higher employee turnover rate of ~23.5% (FY 2021) vs 13.3% (FY 2020) may increase the company's exposure to potential labor management complexities; this may impact the morale of the remaining staff.Tech Mahindra's corporate governance is average compared with global peers. It has adopted a majority binding principle in director elections--enhancing shareholders' ability to influence board structure. However, the company lacks a majority independent board; this may limit management oversight. Also, we note three directors are overboarded; this may limit their ability to fulfill fiduciary responsibilities to this company.As a provider of IT consulting and allied IT-enabled services, Tech Mahindra handles significant volumes of data. Besides, more than 74% of its FY 2021 revenue came from markets with stringent privacy regulations (the Americas and Europe). Its data security practices may, thus, be subjected to regulatory scrutiny. To mitigate the risks, Tech Mahindra has adopted a company-wide information security management framework that is ISO 27001-certified. However, unlike with leading industry peers, we found limited evidence of an overarching privacy framework that covers all business affiliates.

ESG_HEADLINE: Robust service quality management and governance
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: We initiate coverage of Hong Seng at 'AA'. Hong Seng's mixed businesses of medical laboratories (87.7%, FY 2022) and holding companies (9.58%), among others, pose lower service quality risks than for peers that provide in-patient care alone.  Its service quality system is on par with that of peers and has ISO15189 certification and customer feedback survey. We note no regulatory warnings and product recalls since its launch of glove manufacturing in 2021, as of March 2022. It leads most of global and home peers on governance.Hong Seng's pay practices lead those of global peers and appear in line with shareholders' interest. Its board structure is on par with that of global peers. We note related-party transactions (RPTs) in FY 2021. Its fully independent audit committee may help mitigate risks associated with RPTs. We note its audits of ethics standards and whistleblower protection. But its business ethics framework lags that of peers and seems to lack compliance trainings.Medical laboratory operations are labor intensive. This may expose Hong Seng to risks related to operational disruption in case of work stoppages and strikes. Its labor management lags that of peers, and appears to lack labor union that may help protect workers' welfare and variable pay that may help incentivize performance.The company collects sensitive information of patients  and may thus face exposure to potential data breaches. Its data security system lags that of peers. It appears lack of audit practices in managing its data security system.

Aisino has been downgraded to 'BB' from 'BBB'. Our granular reassessment of the risk profile of IT consulting and cybersecurity solutions providers, such as Aisino, indicates higher exposure to data security-related risks than pure-play enterprise software development peers. Further, updated exposure data based on a review of latest regulations in China on data privacy and data protection has resulted in a higher risk assessment for the company, leading to the downgrade. Moreover, Aisino still trails most peers on data security management.Aisino's operations entail handling large volumes of sensitive data of clients, majorly based in China (FY 2021: 99% revenue), which in 2021 introduced the Personal Information Protection Law to regulate the protection of online data. While the company has adopted measures that focus on third-party security certifications, the scope of these programs is unclear. We also note a US FBI alert over allegations of malware in a tax software provided by Aisino; this may indicate data security limitations.Aisino's corporate governance is average compared with global peers. Its single equity class structure aligns investors' economic exposure with voting power. Yet, the absence of a majority independent board and fully independent key committees (audit, pay) may impede management oversight.Like peers in the skill-intensive IT sector, Aisino may face talent management challenges. The company has industry-typical talent management programs. It received external recognition as a top employer by Forbes in 2020; this may help attract talent.

Fuji Kyuko's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. Fuji Kyuko engages primarily in leisure park and transport operations. These are typically labor-intensive businesses, thus, exposing it to labor unrest risks. However, its operations are focused in Japan, where ILO data indicates low likelihood of labor unrest. The company is on par with peers in initiatives to mitigate the risks. However, we found no evidence of safety measures, such as staff training, to mitigate regulatory and reputational risks in case of park ride or traffic accidents.Our research indicates the company offers benefits such as housing allowance; this is beyond Japan's statutory requirements. Fuji Kyuko also offers skill development training programs. These measures could foster employee retention.The company's transport segment (2020: 27% of revenue), which includes bus, railways, and taxi operations, may expose it to risks of additional costs linked to carbon pricing amid increasingly stringent carbon laws in Japan (2020: 100% of assets). Fuji Kyuko lags peers in mitigating the risks. While we note efforts such as the use of hybrid buses, we found no disclosure on its GHG emissions or of carbon reduction targets.Fuji Kyuko trails most global peers on corporate governance. The board's lack of an independent majority, while common among Japanese firms, along with potential entrenchment risks, may limit management oversight. Further, evidence indicates cross-shareholdings by the company, despite the country's governance code calling for the reduction of such structures.

ESG_HEADLINE: Corporate governance practices lag global peers; relatively robust R&D investments
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Shanghai Construction Group Co., Ltd. (SCG) has been downgraded to 'B' from 'BB'. As of June 2022, the company's corporate governance practices lag those of global peers. SCG is a controlled company, with 50.1% of voting rights held by the state. While government representation on the board is common for state-owned entities, we note that both its board chairman and CEO are government representatives; this may potentially undermine minority shareholder interests. The company's executive pay practices also lag those of global peers. These have contributed to the downgrade.SCG's presence across the infrastructure value chain includes construction, consulting, concrete manufacturing, and infrastructure finance. These may capitalize on the demand for sustainable urban infrastructure. Its three-year average R&D/sales ratio (FY 2019-2021) at 3.35% was above the industry average of 1.14%. However, sustainable projects have yet to comprise a substantial portion of revenues.Construction activities in large-scale sites and high-rise buildings are associated with relatively high safety-related risks, based on our model. Evidence indicates limited safety risk controls. We also found no evidence of tracking safety performance against injury reduction targets; this impedes peer comparison.State-owned entities involved in project financing with multiple stakeholders (e.g. public-private partnerships) may face increased scrutiny of business practices, as per our model. Despite this, its business ethics framework appears to lack regular audits and whistleblower protection, lagging leading global peers.

ESG_HEADLINE: Strong data security measures; weaknesses persist in ownership structures relative to global peers
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Minor's rating is unchanged at 'AA'. Hotel (2021: ~60% of revenue) and restaurant (~28%) operations entail substantial customer data collection. Thus, Minor is exposed to regulatory risks tied to cybersecurity, more so with operations in regions (2021: ~96% of revenue from Australia, Europe, China, and Thailand) where strict data laws apply. The company leads most peers on risk mitigation. Minor continues to lead most global peers on corporate behavior. Its ownership structures may pose risks to minority shareholder interests.Increased revenue from online channels (from 24% in 2020 to 28% in 2021) may add to Minor's exposure to cybersecurity and privacy risks. The company's privacy policy provides customers with full control of their data. Like those of most leading peers, Minor's information systems undergo third-party penetration testing to help mitigate risks.Minor has lower exposure to food safety-related risks than pure-play restaurant operators due to its diverse portfolio. We note strong food safety measures relative to peers. The company maintains raw material supplier oversight through audits and ingredient traceability.Minor has policies against corruption, reinforced with whistleblower protection. On corporate governance, the board is no longer flagged for potential entrenchment, following changes in composition. However, the controlling shareholder, the Heinecke family (33% of voting rights, as of June 2022), continues to reinforce control through representatives on the board (2 of 11 directors, including the chair, as of June 2022).

STECON's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. Its capabilities in heavy construction, where incidents of occupational accidents are high as per our model, may expose STECON to higher health and safety (H&S) risks relative to peers. It has adopted practices on par with peers to help manage risks. Its H&S policy is overseen at the executive level and supported by internal safety audits. However, it lags better-performing peers in establishing detailed targets to improve H&S performance. Corporate governance practices lag those of global peersSTECON's board has an independent majority. However, it continues to have entrenched directors--five of 11 members have served for more than 20 years. This may limit management oversight. We also note significant votes against two directors in the 2022 AGM which may indicate potential shareholder dissatisfaction with their performance.While its heavy construction business line, where incidence of bribery is high as per our model, may expose STECON to corruption-related risks, its business ethics practices are on par with global peers. It has adopted executive oversight of ethics standards and policies against bribery and corruption which may help manage the risks.The construction of wastewater treatment plants and mass transit systems may help STECON capitalize on the demand for sustainable water solutions and energy efficiency. These activities accounted for 36% of FY 2021 revenues, better than the industry average of 13% (as of October 2022). However, we found no evidence of targets to increase investments in clean technology.

Sumitomo Forestry's rating is unchanged at 'A'. Sumitomo Forestry continues to be among leading industry peers in occupational safety management. The company also leads peers in managing construction quality-related risks. However, while it maintains strong biodiversity management policies to help decrease the ecological impact of its forestry business, it appears to lack strong focus on green building certifications--considered to be an important climate change mitigation tool for property developers.Homebuilders such as Sumitomo Forestry run the risk of high warranty payouts in the event of lapses in construction quality. Like leading peers, the company has ISO 9001 certification for some of its operations. However, as of 2019, it continues to face investigation/criticism for alleged violation of Japan's Building Standards Act by its subsidiary; this may indicate gaps in the implementation of its safety and quality measures.Like most Japanese peers, the company's board lacks an independent majority and has strong executive presence. This structure may limit its capacity for objective management oversight. However, Sumitomo Forestry's anti-corruption framework has provisions for whistleblower protection and staff ethics training.Sumitomo Forestry operates in Japan and the US, countries actively promoting sustainable building investments. The company employs energy and water efficiency programs for its homes. However, unlike peers, its properties appear to lack certification to recognized green building standards.

SNK has been upgraded to 'A' from 'BBB'. The upgrade is mainly driven by improvements in the company's decarbonization strategy. Given Japan's increasingly stringent carbon regulations, SNK continues to demonstrate robust carbon reduction measures and targets. Further, its programs to manage risks associated with occupational safety and key toxic emissions from its operations have improved, contributing to the upgrade. On the downside, the company lags most global peers on governance, notably pay practices and ownership structure.SNK operates in Japan, which aims to attain carbon neutrality by 2050; this exposes the company to regulatory risks linked with stringent carbon regulations. The company targets to reduce its Scope 1+2 GHG emissions by 10% (2018 baseline) by 2022. This includes programs to reduce gasoline consumption by 50% by switching to eco-cars and to convert 73% of its energy mix to renewable energy.Given the company's focus on HVAC systems, SNK has lower exposure to safety-related risks relative to peers engaged in ceramic and glass manufacturing. Yet, the company performs on par with industry peers in mitigating occupational safety risks. It conducts safety trainings and audits, and sets annual targets--measures that could help reduce workplace accidents.On corporate governance, we flag the company for involvement in a series of cross-shareholdings, despite the call to reduce such arrangements, under Japan's governance code. Further, the absence of disclosures on executive pay impedes our ability to assess its related practices.

YTL Power has been downgraded to 'BB' from 'BBB'. YTL Power was flagged for significant votes against pay practices as of November 2021, suggesting shareholder concerns. Further, the company has been flagged for controlling shareholder concerns: YTL Power is controlled by Dr. Yeoh Tiong Lay and family (68.57% of shares as of June 2022) and 7 of its 12 board members are Dr. Yeoh's children. This may raise concerns regarding the potential subordination of the interests of minority investors. These contribute to the downgrade.YTL Power lags peers in capitalizing on opportunities in the renewable energy (RE) space. Though its energy retail subsidiary, Geneco SG, offers RE certificates to end users, almost 100% of YTL Power's 4.2 GW installed capacity is fossil-fuel based. Also, we found no evidence of programs to increase RE capacity to the grid.YTL Power's operations in thermal energy generation (~42% of assets as of FY 2021) and water supply (~45%) could expose it to operational disruptions should water shortages occur. While its subsidiary Wessex Water has leak reduction initiatives, and one of its plants in Indonesia uses seawater, we found no disclosure on a group-wide freshwater withdrawal data and reduction targets, preventing a holistic assessment with peers.Operations in coal power (~19% of assets, 244 MW, ~6% of installed capacity) could pose regulatory risks should air pollution values breach limits. The company leads most peers in managing these risks as its environmental management system is certified to the ISO 14001 standard.

Trusco's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. Trusco's corporate governance remains strong relative to home market peers. While the company is considered a family firm, its ownership structure, including through its 'one share one vote' provision, promotes equitable representation among all shareholders. However, its business ethics practices fall short of best practices. We did not find evidence of robust anti-corruption policies and internal controls.Trusco's machine tools and equipment wholesale operations are in Japan, where ILO data indicates workplace accident rates have been historically low. The company adopts a group-wide safety policy, although we found no evidence of strong practices commonly adopted by many peers, such as audits and the use of safety metrics to gauge safety performance.Trusco offers LED lights and non-gas sprays, and includes optimization technologies as part of its distribution services. While these may potentially open opportunities in the clean technology space, its strategies to expand offerings to cleantech applications lag those of peers.With 67,700 private brand (PB) products as of December 2020 in Trusco's offerings, the company is exposed to reputational risks in the event of product quality issues. Trusco has a quality control section for PB products but appears to lack strong supply chain programs. We also found evidence of several recalls of PB products over FY 2019-21, though the scope in comparison to revenues was undisclosed.

ESG_HEADLINE: Strong labor and safety management; weaknesses in corporate governance practices persist
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: BTS Group's rating is unchanged at 'AA'. The company leads peers on labor management. With 100% operations in Thailand, its exposure to risks of labor unrest is relatively low, per our model. Also, a small workforce (FY 2021: 5,357 vs. industry average 23,584) may indicate fewer labor management challenges. We note strong employee welfare benefits and engagement programs, including annual surveys--measures that may help gauge staff morale. It lags global peers on corporate governance.BTS Group maintains a strong safety management system relative to peers and employs leading measures such as contractor oversight and safety targets. Its lost time incident rate (CAGR, FY 2018-21) recorded a decline of 10%, in line with the industry average reduction, as of January 2023.BTS Group operates an electrified mass transit system, deemed less carbon-intensive than diesel locomotives operated by its peers. Its average GHG emission intensity remained low: 77 tCO2e/USD million sales (2019-21) vs. 470 industry average, as of January 2023. However, it increased by 29% vs. a 1% drop for the industry (CAGR: 2018-21). Also, unlike many peers, it appears to lack carbon reduction targets.The board is not majority independent and is potentially entrenched--have served for over 15 years; this may limit the board's ability to provide management oversight. Further, the controlling shareholder (40% of voting rights) holds the CEO and chair roles; this may pose risks to minority shareholder interests.

ESG_HEADLINE: Lags in decarbonization initiatives and governance structures
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Shanxi Coking Coal's rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. The large environmental footprint of coal mining (~80% of FY 2021 assets), particularly on account of potential carbon emissions or adverse impact on biodiversity, exposes Shanxi Coking Coal to related compliance and regulatory risks. Despite this, we note weaknesses in its environmental management efforts compared with peers. Further, the company's governance framework, particularly on board and business ethics structures, continue to lag those of global and home market peers.The company may face heightened risks from compliance costs due to the increasingly stringent carbon emission regulations in China. The company lags industry peers in implementing strong measures to manage GHG emissions. Moreover, we found no disclosures on emissions data or reduction targets, impeding peer performance comparison.Mining operations could face disruptions in the event of workplace accidents. However, unlike the case with peers, we note limited evidence of initiatives for safety management. These include extending safety programs to contractors and obtaining certification to international standards such as ISO 45001.The company, which is a state-owned entity, lacks an independent majority board, and has multiple government representatives (4 out of 9 directors, August 2022), including the chairman; this may pose risk of subordination of minority shareholder interests. On business ethics, Shanxi Coking Coal seems to lack internal controls such as whistleblower protection and an anti-corruption policy for suppliers.

ESG_HEADLINE: Changes in corporate governance structure post SK Square spun off, Robust data security measures
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: SK Telecom has been upgraded to 'AA' from 'A'. Following changes to board composition post the SK Square spin-off (Nov 2021), SK Telecom's (SKT) board no longer includes overboarded directors. Board changes primarily drove the upgrade. The removal of the key metrics derived from accounting ratios in the Governance assessment also contributed to SKT's upgrade due to its relatively low accounting risk compared to global market peers. Also, its measures to mitigate privacy and data security risks seem strong compared to those of industry peers.As a mobile carrier service provider, with 31.9 million users as of FY 2021, the company handles substantial personal data. The company employs preemptive and reactive measures against data breach and inspects the level of personal data protection of suppliers, an industry-leading practice which could help mitigate privacy risks.SKT continues to lead industry peers on measures to mitigate labor management challenges. The company has a labor union, covering 92% of employees as of FY 2021, which may work as a formal communication channel to address labor-related issues. Further, the company monitors employee satisfaction through annual surveys.Recurring related-party transactions with the controlling owner (SK: 30.1% voting power, as of June 2022) and other sister companies may pose potential governance risks for SK Telecom's minority investor interests. We also note the company is involved in cross-shareholdings. Further, multiple controversies related to alleged anti-competitive practices weigh on its rating.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improvement in carbon management practices; decline in GHG emission intensity
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Nan Ya Plastics has been upgraded to 'BBB' from 'BB'. The upgrade is driven by improvements in the company's carbon management strategy. Nan Ya Plastics has a target to become carbon neutral across all operations by 2050. Further, its GHG emission intensity of 411 CO2e/USD million was below the average (914) for the Commodity Chemicals sub-industry (constituents of the MSCI ACWI Index, November 2022). However, the company's corporate governance practices trail those of global peers.As Nan Ya Plastics derived 71.5% of its FY 2021 revenue from China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan, where stringent chemical safety regulations apply, it is exposed to potential reformulation costs.
