Like leading peers, it appears to conduct systematic identification of chemicals, and has provisions for hazard risk assessment.Manufacturers of plastics face exposure to risk of environmental liabilities associated with toxic emissions. We note 100% of Nan Ya Plastics' facilities are ISO 14001 certified. Further, its FY 2021 NOx and SOx emissions intensities (0.07 t/USD million and 0.03 t/USD million, respectively) were below the industry average (NOx: 0.39; SOx: 0.1) as of November 2022.The company's board is entrenched: 9 of 15 directors have served for 15 or more years, while 2 directors were 70 years of age as of June 2022; this may impact the board's ability to provide effective management oversight. Meanwhile, its business ethics practices include common practices such as executive oversight and whistleblower protection.

Mie Kotsu Group has been upgraded to 'BBB' from 'BB'. Improvements in health and safety practices drive the upgrade. Notably, we found evidence of internal audits and employee trainings on safety management across the company's transport segment (30% of FY 2020 assets). We also note a concluded controversy, as of April 2021, following settlement of fines over alleged unpaid overtime in FY 2019. While it has appointed two new outside directors in June 2021, Mie Kotsu still lacks an independent majority board and lags global peers on governance.Evidence indicates Mie Kotsu has cross shareholdings with related firms, despite Japan's regulatory call to minimize such arrangements. Also, Mie Kotsu appears to lack strong business ethics practices; we found no evidence of an overarching policy against bribery and corruption and of oversight mechanisms.The company's employee programs lag those of peers: we found limited evidence of performance incentivization and staff engagement measures. That said, its small workforce (3,338 in 2020 vs. industry average of 88,240, as of March 2022) and operational focus on Japan, where worker strikes are minimal per ILO data, reduce labor management complexity.Mie Kotsu derived an estimated 7% of its FY 2020 revenues from environmentally friendly solutions, such as electric bus transit systems and solar power generation. Also, the company's real estate segment has begun to integrate net zero energy house (ZEH) standards in its housing offerings, with the Japan government aiming to establish ZEH as the standard for new homes by 2030.

Techmatrix has been downgraded to 'BB' from 'BBB'. The company trails global peers on corporate governance, notably board structure. At the 2021 AGM, two of the 11 directors received over 20% negative votes; this may indicate shareholder dissatisfaction with their performance. Our granular reassessment of Techmatrix's business indicates higher exposure to privacy-related risks due to a focus on IT consulting, which entails access to sensitive data. Also, we found limited evidence of industry best practices on data security management.While Techmatrix has an independent majority board, which includes two female directors, female representation remains below 30% (May 2022); this may hinder diverse views in board discussions. Also, we found limited disclosures on its executive pay; this may impede peer comparison. Also, on corporate behavior, we found no evidence of board-level oversight of business ethics programs, unlike with leading peers.Techmatrix derived 100% of revenue in FY 2021 from Japan, where stringent privacy laws and costly remediation apply in case of a data breach. Techmatrix has certified its operations to ISO 27001 and conducts external independent audits. However, we found no evidence of an overarching privacy policy.Competition for skilled talent in IT industry exposes Techmatrix to recruitment and retention challenges. While Techmatrix provides competitive non-pay benefits and stock-based compensation, it lags leading peers in adopting employee engagement channels and formal grievance redressal mechanisms, which may help gauge staff morale.

ESG_HEADLINE: Weaknesses in corporate governance practices persist relative to global peers
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: FCFC's rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. The company's governance practices continue to trail those of global peers. FCFC had cross-shareholdings as of June 2022--a practice which may lead to double-counting of equities' values. Moreover, the board lacks a nomination committee: this may limit oversight of board recruitment and succession planning. Further, the company lags peers in instituting strong chemical safety management initiatives to mitigate risks tied to its production of industrial chemicals.FCFC may face risk of reformulation costs, as it derived 78% of FY 2021 revenue from Taiwan and China, where chemical safety regulations are stringent as per our model. The company has measures to integrate environmental and health standards into its products. However, it appears to lack formal plans to eliminate potentially harmful chemicals, unlike leading peers.As a producer of industrial organic chemicals, FCFC may face risks of environmental liabilities tied to air pollutants and waste. The company's FY 2021 NOx and SOx emission intensities of 0.1 and 0.03 t/USD million, respectively, were lower than the industry averages (NOx: 0.38; SOx: 0.1) as of December 2022. However, it appears to lack quantitative targets to reduce key air emissions (NOx/SOx).Owing to the water-intensive nature of its operations, FCFC is exposed to risks related to potential water scarcity. We note the company's water management strategy has executive-level oversight. Further, FCFC recorded a YoY decrease of 35% in water withdrawal intensity in 2021.

Arcland Service's rating is unchanged at 'B'. Model revisions to evaluation of exposure to food safety risks, by removing a company-specific component based on revenue, increased Arcland's risk exposure. Yet, Arcland continues to lag peers in obtaining certification to stringent GFSI-benchmarked standards, which entails routine product inspections and supplier audits. The company lacks an independent majority; although common in Japan, such a governance structure may limit management oversight, thus lagging most global peers.Arcland also lacks key board-level committees, such as pay and nomination. This could impede the company's oversight on pay practices as well as recruitment and succession planning for key executive roles. Also, Arcland's business ethics framework lags those of global peers: we found no evidence of regular audits or employee trainings on ethical standards.Arcland's reliance on single-use packaging for takeout and delivery could result in substantial waste. This, amid stringent packaging regulations in Japan, could expose its packaging practices to high regulatory scrutiny. Yet, unlike leading peers, it appears to lack sustainable packaging initiatives such as lightweighting or use of eco-friendly content.Arcland's exposure to labor-related risks may be low, given its small workforce and operations in Japan, where incidence of labor unrest is low (as per ILO data). Arcland's labor management practices are industry typical: it offers variable pay and non-salary benefits to employees to help boost their productivity and morale.

ESG_HEADLINE: Continues to depend on coal, despite plans to accelerate closure of two coal plants
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: AGL Energy's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. AGL's operations continue to be dependent on coal-fired power plants (6.8 GW, ~62% of installed capacity as of FY 2021); indicating carbon and water footprints remain sizeable. Its three-year (FY 2018-20) average Scope 1 emission intensity (0.96 t CO2e/MWh) was higher than that of industry peers (0.4). However, AGL plans to accelerate the closure of its two coal-fired plants (Bayswater: from 2035 to 2033; Loy Yang A: from 2048 to 2045). AGL leads global peers on corporate governance practices.AGL targets net-zero emissions by 2040 for Scopes 1, 2, and 3. In March 2022, the company rejected a takeover proposal from Mr. Mike Cannon-Brookes and Brookfield Asset Management--a consortium planning to speed up the closure of AGL's three coal plants and invest ~AUD 20 billion in renewables and storage capacity. The impact of this unsuccessful takeover on AGL's plant closures and carbon targets remains to be seen.Fossil fuel-based energy generation (FY 2021: ~65% of assets) could expose the company to risks of operational disruptions in case of water shortages. AGL's risk management efforts lag those of industry peers. We found no evidence of plans to install water-saving technologies in the company's cooling processes. Further, its three-year (2018-20) average freshwater withdrawal intensity of ~62 m3/MWh thermal energy generation was higher than the industry median of ~6 m3/MWh (as of March 2022).AGL's board and key committees have the requisite independence, expertise, and diversity to support management oversight.

We initiate coverage of Australian Ethical Investment at 'AA'. Australian Ethical Investment's (AEI's) ESG performance is driven by its strong commitment to integrate ESG factors in its investment decisions. The company is a signatory to leading industry standards such as the United Nations Principles for Responsible Investment. AEI also discloses its engagement and voting policies for addressing ESG considerations in its investment portfolio. Further, the company's corporate governance practices appear to lead those of global peers.AEI has an independent majority board with separate CEO and chairman roles and independent audit and pay committees; this could support strong management oversight. The board also has more than 50% female directors--studies have linked diversity to better decision making. While AEI offers whistleblower protection, its business ethics practices appear unremarkable compared to those of peers that disclose detailed anti-corruption policies.AEI relies on skilled investment professionals to manage its portfolio funds. It may thus face challenges in attracting and retaining talent. Like peers, the company conducts annual engagement surveys which can help gauge workforce morale. Yet, AEI lags peers in adoption of industry leading workforce management practices.AEI handles sensitive client information and like peers has high exposure to risks related to privacy and data security. We found limited evidence of best practices such as employee training on cyber security and penetration testing of security systems to preempt data breaches.

ESG_HEADLINE: Subpar environmental management practices
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Unid's rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. Our reassessment of the company's basic inorganic chemical business (67% in FY 2021) indicates higher exposure to risks related to water scarcity. Yet, Unid trails industry peers in water management practices. We found no evidence of quantitative targets to reduce water use. Further, the company appears to have limited measures aimed at managing environmental risks, particularly related to toxic emissions and waste.Producers of inorganic chemicals face high exposure to the risk of incurring environmental liabilities associated with toxic emissions and waste. We found limited information on the company's programs to mitigate key air pollutants (NOx/SOx). Moreover, unlike better-performing peers, it appears to lack quantitative targets to reduce emissions.In FY 2021, Unid derived 61% of its revenues from South Korea, where chemical regulations are stringent. This exposes the company to potential reformulation costs. Yet, it lags industry peers in chemical management practices, with no plans to phase out hazardous chemicals from its operations.While we note the company's corporate governance practices are above par relative to those of home market peers, its business ethics practices trail those of global and home market peers. We found no evidence of a detailed anti-corruption policy and compliance mechanisms such as regular audits of ethics standards.

ESG_HEADLINE: Continues to lag peers across ESG Key Issues
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Yunnan Aluminium's rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. Yunnan Aluminium is engaged in vertically integrated aluminum processing in China. These activities, in general, translate to a large environmental footprint, and may expose the company to regulatory risks and liabilities associated with potential adverse impacts on the areas of operation. Our research indicates the company trails peers in adopting strong measures to address such risks. Further, it lags global and home market peers on governance, notably on board and business ethics practices.As a state-owned entity (FY 2021: Government of China, 47.32% stake), the company has high exposure to corruption-related risks, as per our model. Yet, its compliance mechanisms (i.e., audits and training on ethics standards) fall short of best practices. Further, we note related-party transactions (FY 2021: ~25% of revenue) with the controlling owner; this may not align well with minority investor interests.As a China-based aluminum producer, Yunnan Aluminium may incur carbon-related costs amid stringent national regulations to achieve neutrality by 2060. We found no evidence of reduction targets to help manage the risk. Also, we found no disclosure on the company's emissions data, impeding peer comparison.Aluminum manufacturers could face the risk of environmental liabilities due to toxic air emissions and waste. While we found evidence of certification to the ISO 14001 standard, the company lags peers in setting quantitative targets to reduce emissions and in undertaking regular environmental audits across all its sites.

ESG_HEADLINE: Strong performance on toxic emissions and freshwater use; weaknesses in governance persist
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Shanxi Taigang Stainless Steel has been upgraded to 'B' from 'CCC'. The upgrade is driven by improvements in the company's performance on toxic emissions and water withdrawal to mitigate related environmental risks at its steel operations. Shanxi Taigang's NOx, Sox, and freshwater withdrawal intensities decreased by CAGR of 44%, 41%, and 25%, respectively, in 2018-2021. The company, however, trails global and home market peers in governance practices.As a state-owned subsidiary, Shanxi Taigang may face increased regulatory scrutiny on its business practices, given China's ongoing anti-corruption campaign. Yet, we found no evidence of a detailed anti-corruption policy and provisions for whistleblower protection. Further, the lack of an independent majority and the presence of government representatives on the board could pose risks of subordination of minority shareholder interests.The company's steel manufacturing operations are energy-intensive, posing risks of increased costs related to carbon caps from China's emission trading scheme. Yet, we found no evidence of reduction targets or programs to mitigate risks linked to climate change.Labor-intensive steel manufacturing activities could pose operational challenges such as labor unrest. Like peers, Shanxi Taigang conducts annual engagement surveys and offers non-salary benefits, which could help monitor staff satisfaction and boost productivity, respectively.

Boryung has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'CCC'. The upgrade is driven by improvements in Boryung's practices and disclosures across most ESG Key Issues. While it had related-party transactions with other companies under the controlling owner in FY 2021, these reduced to 0.3% of revenue in FY 2021 versus 22.9% in FY 2018. Also, we note the company reported CEO pay in FY 2021. However, the company continues to lag global peers on corporate governance. It lacks an independent-majority board and a fully independent audit committee.Boryung's business ethics practices are average relative to global peers. It has a detailed anti-corruption policy and whistleblower protection mechanism to preempt potential unethical conduct. Further, a controversy over alleged rigging bids on public tenders for vaccines was concluded and excluded from our assessment; this contributed to the upgrade.Boryung, like pharma peers, relies on highly-skilled staff for its operations. Its talent management practices are average relative to peers. The company offers non-salary benefits to its staff, which may help attract and retain talent, and has a grievance channel that could help protect their interests.Boryung promotes several products to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events such as heart failure; this may allow the company to cater to underserved disease areas. However, it appears to lack detailed measures to promote access to healthcare in emerging markets.

LOTTE Fine Chemical's rating is unchanged at 'B'. The company continues to trail peers in governance practices. It appears to lack detailed disclosure on executive pay, limiting our ability to assess its executive pay practices relative to peers. Further, it is controlled by the Shin family via a stock pyramid structure; this may undermine the interests of other investors. However, the inclusion of regional groundwater availability in our evaluation of country level water stress resulted in a lower risk assessment for the company.LOTTE Fine Chemical's water withdrawal intensity of 10,361 m3/million USD sales was below the average (20,915) for Diversified Chemicals sub-industry (constituents of the MSCI ACWI Index), as of November 2021. However, it appears to lack a formal water management strategy with quantitative targets to reduce water use.The carbon-intensive nature of industrial chemicals and plastic production exposes LOTTE Fine Chemical to compliance risks related to carbon regulations. However, we found no evidence on strong mitigation programs with provisions for use of renewable sources and measures to increase energy efficiency.As LOTTE Fine Chemical derived 67% of its FY 2020 revenue from South Korea, North America, and Europe, where chemical safety regulations are stringent, it is exposed to compliance risks and potential reformulation costs. While we note the company undertakes reformulation of specific products, it appears to lack a formal plan to phase out all hazardous chemicals from its operations, unlike better-performing peers.

ESG_HEADLINE: Subpar corporate governance practices; overall environmental management efforts lag those of peers
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: New Hope Liuhe's rating is unchanged at 'B'. New Hope Liuhe has related-party transactions with the controlling shareholder and founder, Mr. Liu Yong Hao, who held 54.59% of the voting power as of November 2021 via a stock pyramid structure. This, combined with the board's lack of an independent majority, may raise concerns of potential subordination of minority shareholder interests. Our reassessment of the company's business ethics practices suggests it has regular staff training; however, it still lags peers that conduct regular audits.The company relies on third-party producers and, to some extent, farm households, to produce its agricultural feed ingredients and raise chickens and hogs--activities which are water intensive. This could expose New Hope Liuhe to the risk of higher input costs in case of water shortages. Our research indicates the company has adopted water recirculation systems in its own operations. However, New Hope Liuhe appears to lack broad engagements in its agricultural supply chain for water conservation and resilience, lagging industry peers.As a company engaged in poultry and hog farming, New Hope Liuhe is exposed to reputational and regulatory risks tied to potential negative impacts on the environment and biodiversity (e.g., contamination of land and water bodies). The company is on par with peers on risk mitigation practices. Our reassessment suggests New Hope Liuhe has committed to minimizing its environmental footprint through measures such as implementing Good Agricultural Practices and investing in wastewater treatment technologies.

ESG_HEADLINE: Overall ESG strategy trails that of peers
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: We initiate coverage of Jizhong Energy at 'CCC'. Jizhong Energy is a China-based company primarily engaged in the production and sale of coal. Our research indicates it lags peers in instituting a strong management strategy to mitigate the adverse environmental impacts of its coal mining activities. Further, we note weaknesses in its policies and programs to address the social risks associated with its operations, relative to peers. Additionally, it lags global and home market peers on governance, particularly on business ethics framework.Jizhong Energy is exposed to risks of potential involvement in unethical dealings to maintain mining permits. Yet, its business ethics compliance mechanisms (i.e., audits and training on ethics standards) fall short of best practices. Further, it is controlled by the Government of China (FY 2021: 57.2% of votes). This along with the presence of government representatives on the board could pose risks of subordination of minority shareholder interests.Coal mining activities (FY 2021: 87% of operations) expose the company to risks of production disruptions tied to potential workplace accidents. Unlike with most peers, we found no evidence of a group-wide health and safety policy and safety targets, which could help manage the risk.Open-pit coal mining operations expose the company to the risk of incurring liabilities in case of adverse impact on local ecosystems. Yet, it lags peers in adopting natural resource management initiatives, such as concurrent site rehabilitation and species protection; these could help mitigate the risk.

ESG_HEADLINE: Weaknesses in policies and programs to address most ESG Key Issues relative to peers
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Huagong Tech's rating is unchanged at 'B'. Huagong Tech trails most global market peers on corporate governance. Its board lacks an independent majority and has a combined CEO/chair role--structures that may impede management oversight. Further, laser devices typically contain minerals that could be sourced from conflict regions. Thus, the company may face regulatory risks if such minerals are found in its products. Yet, it lags peers on responsible sourcing practices. We found no evidence of raw material origin tracing schemes.Huagong Tech's business lines in optoelectronics and laser equipment are perceived to be highly labor intensive. This could pose work disruption risks in the event of labor unrest. However, its labor management policies trail those of peers. We found no evidence of a dedicated labor rights policy and upskilling support through formal certifications.Optical communication and laser devices may contain chemicals of concern. Also, Huagong Tech derives revenue from China (FY 2020: ~88%), where chemical safety laws are stringent. Thus, the company may face risks of incurring reformulation costs. Yet, it lags peers on chemical safety practices. We found no evidence of phase-out plans for chemicals of concern in its products.Through its laser-based products, Huagong Tech may have moderate opportunities to capture the demand for clean technology. Its cleantech initiatives are on par with those of peers. Evidence suggests its products have applications in 5G and Internet of Things that may enable industrial optimization technologies.

ESG_HEADLINE: Lags peers in governance and talent management programs
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: NICE Holdings has been downgraded to 'CCC' from 'B'. NICE Holdings (NICE) provides credit information services that include credit bureau, corporate information and differentiated credit rating offerings. The inclusion of the Corporate Behavior theme in the company's governance assessment is a key contributor to the downgrade due to the company's weak business ethics policies and practices relative to peers.NICE appears to lack policies for addressing bribery and corruption risks. We also did not find evidence of audits and employee training on ethical standards, as well as whistleblower protection.Moreover, its board lacks an independent majority and has yet to separate CEO and chairman roles. We also note the company's related-party transactions with its controlling shareholder, as well as limited transparency on its executive pay; these factors may pose governance risks.Like its financial industry peers, the company depends on skilled talent and is thus exposed to human capital management challenges. However, the company appears to trail peers in its efforts to address these challenges. We did not find evidence of strategies for gauging workforce satisfaction to help it stay ahead of productivity and morale issues.

Bohai Leasing's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. As of 2022 AGM, the company's board had an independent director majority. This may bolster management oversight. Following the restructuring of HNA Group in 2021, Bohai Leasing is no longer controlled by HNA Capital Group, which now holds 28% voting rights (30% in FY 2020). However, the company still has recurring transactions with the non-controlling owner, and lacks a fully independent audit committee; this may increase potential governance risks for minority investors.Companies in the aircraft leasing business rely on skilled employees. We note Bohai Leasing's efforts to address potential talent recruitment and retention challenges through career development initiatives, performance appraisals and incentives, which may help boost staff morale and productivity. However, unlike better-performing peers, Bohai Leasing appears to lack robust recruitment strategies to attract highly skilled employees.Aircraft leasing appears to present limited opportunities to capitalize on growth opportunities in clean technology. Bohai Leasing offers new aircraft models, with an average fleet age of 5 years (vs. average of 9.6 in 2021 for the airline industry, MSCI ACWI Index); this may help provide increased energy efficiencies than older planes. We also found evidence of involvement in the development of e-vehicles through its venture in China.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improved corporate governance; but weaknesses in corporate behavior and talent management persist
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Daan Gene has been upgraded to 'BB' from 'B'. Daan Gene leads home market peers in corporate governance, and improvements in board structure drive the upgrade. Following changes in board composition at the 2022 AGM, the board is no longer flagged for being entrenched. However, the company trails global peers in business ethics framework and appears to lack provisions for whistleblower protection against retaliation. Its talent management also lags industry peers.As a diagnostic kits manufacturer, Daan Gene relies on a highly-skilled workforce to carry out its R&D operations and therefore could face challenges in attracting and retaining talent. While it seems to offer employee benefits and training support, we found limited evidence of a robust engagement program to help gauge staff satisfaction or a talent pipeline development strategy to help with recruitment.We have revised our evaluation of exposure to product safety and quality risks by removing a company-specific component which was based on the size of operations. This has resulted in an increase in Daan Gene's overall risk exposure. Its quality management system is average relative to industry peers and features ISO 13485 certification. We found no product recalls or regulatory warnings from January 2020 to September 2022.Daan Gene's operations in China (100% of FY 2021 revenue) may present opportunities to capitalize on promoting access to healthcare. We note its government partnership to improve the drug supply chain in China.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improvement in governance practices; labor management and safety concerns persist
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: CJ Logistics has been upgraded to 'BBB' from 'BB'. Improvement in CJ Logistics' governance practices drives the upgrade. New evidence indicates the presence of an anti-corruption framework, which includes detailed guidelines and an ethics code as well as annual trainings for employees. Further, we no longer flag the company for controversies related to allegations of price collusion. Also, enhanced disclosures on executive pay may enable investors to assess alignment of pay practices to company performance.The company's operations are based mainly in South Korea and the Americas (78%, 2020), where carbon regulations are getting increasingly stringent. CJ Logistics lead peers on reducing carbon emissions. It maintained a low average carbon emission intensity (24 tCO2e/USD million sales, 2018-2020 vs. 90, average for trucking peers as of December 2021), which declined by a compound annual rate of 9% (2017-2020), better than the peer average reduction of 5%.CJ Logistics trails peers in labor management initiatives. It offers industry-typical benefits such as performance-based bonus. However, it appears to lack the best practice of engagement programs which could help mitigate risks related to staff morale, especially amid rising delivery volumes during COVID-19 lockdown, which may exert pressure on its workers.While the company discloses strong safety programs, gaps in safety controls appear to persist, with reports of fatalities of delivery workers from 2018 to 2021 due to alleged excessive overtime and unsafe working conditions.

ESG_HEADLINE: Continued pureplay operations in RE; lagging efforts in governance practices
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: CECEP Solar Energy's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. CECEP Solar fully operates ~4.2 GW solar power (as of FY 2021), it faces lower environmental risks than peers with fossil fuel-based assets. The company also has ~700 MW of solar capacity under construction, allowing the company to lead peers in capitalizing RE opportunities. This also seems to align with China's 14th Five Year Plan (2021-2025), which includes a non-binding target of sourcing 20% of energy from non-fossil fuels. However, it lags global peers on governance practices.On the corporate governance front, CECEP Solar has recurring related-party transactions (RPTs, ~0.172% of expenses as recurring purchases as of FY 2021 and ~4.85% in FY 2020). Though the audit committee is fully independent of management, one member is a government representative and not independent of controlling owner's interests. This may increase governance risks associated with RPTs for minority investors.Our model suggests incidence of corruption is perceived to be high in the utilities industry--a perception heightened by state ownership. However, we found no evidence of CECEP Solar having an anti-corruption policy and a policy protecting whistleblowers from retaliation.Our model suggests the utilities industry is typically exposed to talent-related challenges due to dependence on skilled professionals. However, we found limited evidence of the company's programs to manage talent; this may impede comparison with peers.

ESG_HEADLINE: Lags peers across most ESG Key Issues
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: We initiate coverage of IMDTECL at 'CCC'. IMDTECL is a China-based company primarily engaged in coal production. Our research indicates it trails peers in adopting strong initiatives to mitigate its high exposure to environment-related risks associated with its operations. Further, we note weaknesses in its strategy to address risks related to worker safety and potential community conflict. Additionally, it lags global and home market peers on governance, particularly in board and ownership structure and business ethics framework.As a state-owned entity (FY 2021: Government of China held a 66.91% stake), IMDTECL may face increased scrutiny of its business conduct. Yet, it appears to lack best practices such as regular audits and groupwide training on ethics standards. Further, we note the presence of related-party transactions (FY 2021: ~24% of revenue and ~28% of expenses) with the controlling owner; this may not align well with investor interests.With presence in China, where work-related injury rates have historically been high, IMDTECL may face the risk of production disruptions in case of workplace accidents. Yet, it lags peers in setting safety targets and in certifying its health and safety system to international standards such as OHSAS 18001.Coal and aluminum production are carbon-intensive and expose IMDTECL to potential regulatory costs as China aims for carbon neutrality by 2060. Yet, we found no evidence of reduction targets to help manage the risk. We found no information on its emissions data; this impedes performance comparison with peers.

ESG_HEADLINE: Trails peers in on most ESG Key Issues
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Sunlord Electronics' rating is unchanged at 'B'. Sunlord Electronics lags industry peers in most ESG issues assessed for the electronic components industry. The company's workforce management programs appear weak relative to industry peers. Further, while it operates in China, where chemical safety laws are stringent, it has moderate exposure to risks tied to the use of hazardous chemicals in products. Still, it lags industry peers in chemical safety programs like adoption of substance phase out measures.Manufacturing electronic coils and inductors is typically labor intensive, and operations in China may present relatively moderate risks associated with likelihood of labor unrests. However, Sunlord Electronics' labor programs trail those of industry peers. Unlike with leading peers, we found no evidence of a strong benefits package or formal employee communication channels to help manage workforce productivity.Electronic component manufacturers such as Sunlord Electronics may use a variety of metals in their products, including those classified as conflict minerals. The company's supplier programs are subpar relative to those of peers. We found no evidence of strong due diligence measures to track use and origin of such minerals in the company's supply chain.Sunlord Electronics has an independent majority and an independent chair to support management oversight. Further, while the company has provisions for whistleblower protection, it appears to lack robust enforcement such as broad-based trainings for staff and audits.

ESG_HEADLINE: Limited evidence of programs to manage environmental and chemical safety risks
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: CNNC Hua Yuan's rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. The company lags peers on efforts to manage potential environmental risks associated with its production of titanium dioxide. CNNC Hua Yuan is exposed to risks of incurring environmental liabilities tied to toxic emissions and waste. Yet, unlike better-performing peers, it appears to lack quantitative targets to reduce key air pollutants (NOx/SOx). Further, its FY 2021 SOx emission intensity of 0.24t/USD million was higher than the average (0.10) for industry peers as of October 2022.Having derived 52% of FY 2021 revenue from China, where chemical safety regulations are stringent, CNNC Hua Yuan is exposed to the risk of incurring reformulation costs. Unlike with better-performing peers, we found no evidence of a formal strategy to phase out hazardous chemicals from its operations.Production of inorganic pigments is generally water intensive; this exposes CNNC Hua Yuan to risks related to water shortages. While the company has industry-common measures such as water recycling, we found no disclosure on its water withdrawal figures or on quantitative targets to reduce water use in its operations; this may impede peer comparison.The company trails most global peers on governance. We note the presence of a controlling shareholder--Mr. Zelong Wang held 43.5% of voting power as of June 2022. Further, its board lacks an independent majority and has a combined CEO-chair role. These structures may not align with the interests of investors. CNNC Hua Yuan also lags global peers on business ethics practices.

ESG_HEADLINE: Industry-typical data security measures; lags in corporate governance and talent management programs
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Beijing Shiji's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. Our reassessment of the company's business lines, which include enterprise software offerings and equipment distribution, indicate its privacy risks are low, given its limited custody of end-user personal data. Nevertheless, the company has industry-standard information security programs. However, despite the company's suite of IT solutions that entail a skilled workforce, we note it lags industry peers in talent management initiatives.Beijing Shiji fully operates in China (FY 2021: 100% assets), where regulations on data privacy are increasingly stringent following the enforcement of the Personal Data Protection Law in 2021. Like leading peers, the company has adopted data protection measures such as penetration testing, and undertakes ISO 27001 certification for its information security systems.Developing applied software for the hotel and leisure industries entails dependence on technically skilled employees (around 43% of its FY 2021 workforce was dedicated to R&D). While it offers market-standard benefits, it appears to lack formal employee communication channels for monitoring workplace engagement.Beijing Shiji continues to lag global peers in corporate governance. It appears to have limited pay disclosures, which may impede peer comparison. Also, we note its board includes entrenched directors (3 of 7 with more than 15 years of tenure). While we found evidence of a whistleblower policy, it seems to lack audit programs covering ethics.

ESG_HEADLINE: Appears to lack risk management practices across ESG pillars
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: We initiate coverage of DI DONG IL at 'CCC'. Di Dong Il appears to trail industry peers across ESG Key Issues. Particularly, it lags peers in instituting chemical safety initiatives such as extensive plans of phasing out chemicals of concern, despite generating the bulk of its FY 2020 revenues from France and South Korea (~89% of revenues), which have stringent chemical regulations. Moreover, it lags peers in labor management practices. It trails global and home market peers in governance practices.We found no evidence of detailed disclosure on executive pay, limiting our ability to assess Di Dong Il's executive pay practices and resulting in a lower score relative to its global peers. As regards ethical business practices, the company appears to lack detailed policies against corruption, unlike the case in better-performing peers.Di Dong Il operates in South Korea, France, and India (FY 2020: ~91% of operations), where incidents of labor unrest are perceived to be high as per ILO data, exposing it to risks of operational delay. However, unlike the case of better-performing peers, we found no evidence of engagement channels and development offerings to its staff--factors that could help gauge employee satisfaction and potential labor challenges.We found no evidence of product carbon footprint assessments and carbon reduction initiatives across its upstream stages. Our research indicates that it trails peers in this aspect.

ESG_HEADLINE: Lags peers in managing key ESG risks
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Shanxi Meijin Energy's rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. Given the increasingly stringent regulations in China and the country's goal of achieving carbon neutrality by 2060, coal miners such as Shanxi Meijin Energy could face increased costs linked to carbon emissions. Although the company has upgraded its facilities to improve energy efficiency, it appears to lag peers that use renewable energy. The company also lags peers in adopting robust biodiversity management plans and safety strategies to manage risks from mining activities.Mining activities may pose regulatory risks in case of adverse biodiversity impacts. While Shanxi Meijin Energy has rehabilitation efforts, it appears to lack targets on land use and biodiversity management plans. Further, unlike with leading peers, we found no evidence of programs to help preserve indigenous flora and fauna.Like mining peers, the company is exposed to operational disruptions linked to workplace accidents. Yet, we note limited evidence of industry best practices such as extending safety policies to contractors and linking of safety performance to executive pay. Besides, we found no evidence of health and safety management system certification to international standards such as ISO 45001.The company lags global peers in governance practices. The board's lack of an independent majority and the presence of multiple executives may hamper its ability to provide strong management oversight. Also, its business ethics framework seems limited, with no evidence of compliance audits or employee training on ethics standards.

ESG_HEADLINE: Trails peers on overall governance practices; limited disclosures on ESG-related initiatives
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Miwon Commercial's rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. The company continues to trail global peers on corporate governance practices. Miwon Commercial is controlled by the Kim family (58% of voting rights) and has reported recurring related-party transactions involving the controlling shareholder. Also, it appears to lack strong business ethics practices relative to peers; we found no evidence of whistleblower protection or of employee training on ethics standards. Further, its environmental management programs continue to lag those of peers.Producers of surfactants and other industrial chemicals typically have high exposure to the risk of environmental liabilities tied to toxic emissions and waste. Yet, we found no information on the company's programs to mitigate key air pollutants (NOx/SOx). Further, we found no disclosures on its emissions figures or targets to reduce them; this may impede peer comparison.The company derived 51% of its FY 2021 revenue from South Korea, where chemical regulations are stringent. This exposes it to potential reformulation costs. However, it lags industry peers in chemical management practices; we found no evidence of plans to phase out potentially hazardous chemicals from its operations.As a producer of organic chemicals, Miwon Commercial is exposed to compliance risks related to carbon regulations. Yet, it appears to lack strong mitigation programs such as the use of renewable sources and measures to increase energy efficiency. We also found no evidence of quantitative targets to reduce emissions, unlike with leading peers.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improvements in executive pay practices, but trails peers on product warranty
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Honda has been upgraded to 'AA' from 'A'. Improvements in Honda's corporate governance practices--particularly in disclosing details of its executives' pay--as of July 2022, drove the upgrade. We also note evidence of linking non-financial indicators, including ESG performance and employee engagement, into officer incentivization. A revision to our evaluation of exposure to product safety and quality risks, by removing a company-specific component which was based on the size of operations, also contributed to the upgrade.Given its sizeable motorcycle sales (80% of vehicles sold in 2021, 15% of revenues), Honda may face lower exposure to risks linked to tailpipe emission norms than peers that produce only four-wheelers. The company aims to achieve 100% fully electric and fuel cell vehicle sales portfolio by 2040, as part of its 2050 carbon neutrality goal.Honda adopts an industry-typical quality management system, equipped with ISO 9001 certifications (56 of 60 production sites, as of February 2022) and supply chain quality auditing mechanisms. However, its product warranties comprise 3% of its revenue (2019-2021), exceeding the industry average of 1.5%, as of November 2022. Also, as of March 2022, Honda remains linked to recall efforts and probes over alleged defective airbags.Our reassessment of Honda's employee management programs reflects lagging efforts relative to industry leaders. We found limited evidence of performance incentives and shareholding plans provided to non-officer staff--measures that may help boost labor productivity.

ESG_HEADLINE: Improvements in corporate governance practices; strong carbon reduction performance
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Air China has been upgraded to 'BBB' from 'BB'. The upgrade reflects improvements in Air China's corporate governance, which is now average relative to global peers. Related-party transactions with the controlling owner were down to 0.016% of total revenue in FY 2021 (2020: 13.02%); this may reduce potential governance risks for investors. However, as a state-owned entity whose ethics practices may face risk of regulatory scrutiny, as our model suggests, we found no evidence of best practices such as whistleblower protection mechanisms.The company's product safety and quality management practices are average relative to industry peers. Its operations are certified to the IATA Operational Safety Audit program, and its average on-time performance of 86.7% for FY 2019-2021 was higher than the industry-average of 83.6% as of November 2022.Air China has robust privacy measures to protect against breaches and address increasingly stringent data privacy regulations. Besides its ISO 27001-certified information security management system, it has established a data breach response plan and employs data encryption techniques. We also note privacy training for staff, though the scope and frequency seem to be undisclosed.Air China exhibits strong progress in reducing carbon emissions. It maintains a young fleet (8.2 years in FY 2021 vs. 9.6 industry average, as of November 2022), which may provide increased fuel efficiencies. Its three-year average carbon emission intensity of 122.5 gCO2e/rpk (FY 2019-2021) was lower than the industry average of 353, as of November 2022.

OSG's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. Methodology enhancements to the Corporate Behavior Theme resulted in a greater emphasis on business ethics practices and exposure to risks related to corruption. Corruption risks are perceived to be high among companies manufacturing metal forming tools. OSG has established an anti-corruption framework, with provisions for whistleblower protection. However, the board appears to be entrenched, which may limit its ability to provide independent management oversight.The company manages a small workforce (7,173 vs. 20,077 industry average as of June 2021) which may it easier to handle potential labor management complexities. While OSG offers career development initiatives, it appears to trail peers in providing engagement channels and performance incentives to sustain workforce morale and productivity.OSG's operations involving metal cutting machine tools pose moderate exposure to risk of environmental liabilities and compliance costs linked to toxic emissions and waste. We note ISO 14001 certification for its environmental management system. However, it has yet to tie its executive compensation to environmental performance, considered a best practice among leading peers.Through its production of lightweight products for less fuel consumption, OSG has opportunities to tap the increasing demand for clean technology products. However, low R&D investments at 1.29% of sales over 2017-20, vs industry average of 2.80% as of July 2021, could potentially limit innovation capacity relative to peers.

Nikkiso's rating is unchanged at 'B'. As 43% of Nikkiso's revenue (FY 2021) comes from electromedical and electrotherapeutic apparatus, it is exposed to risks related to potential product safety and quality issues. The company has certification to recognized quality standards such as ISO 9001 to manage the said risks. However, while it conducts quality assurance trainings for employees, we found limited evidence on product testing and supplier monitoring.The removal of the key metrics derived from accounting ratios (Revenue Recognition, Expense Recognition and Asset-Liability Valuation) in the Governance assessment has improved Nikkiso's Governance score due to its low accounting risk compared to global peers. Yet, it lags global peers on corporate governance. Its board lacks an independent majority, and has a joint CEO-chair role; although common in Japan, such a governance structure may limit management oversight.Manufacturing pumps and pumping equipment is labor intensive; this may expose Nikkiso to risks of work disruptions in case of labor unrest. Yet, it lags most peers in staff management: while it offers industry-typical non-pay benefits, we found no evidence of engagement initiatives and performance incentives.Nikkiso offers products for water treatment, which may benefit from growth opportunities in cleantech. However, its average R&D/sales ratio of 1.37% (2018-21) was below the 5.56% industry average as of September 2022; this may suggest limited innovation capacity.

Minmetals Land's rating is unchanged at 'B'. Minmetals Land continues to lag most global peers on corporate governance. It is a controlled company (China Minmetals held 61.9% of voting power as of FY 2021). While the board is no longer considered entrenched (as of July 2022), it continues to have transactions with the controlling shareholder (24% of FY 2021 expenses); this may raise potential conflicts of interests. Further, it lags global peers in business ethics practices such as provision of whistleblower protection against retaliation.Real estate developers' employees may face risk of injuries at construction sites. Yet, the company lags peers in obtaining health and safety certification, and in monitoring injuries and fatalities; this may hamper worker safety.Residential property developers may face warranty claims in case of lapses in construction quality. The company trails industry peers in practices such as responsible marketing and product quality certifications. Additionally, it lags leading peers in adopting quality assurance training for employees and suppliers.Focus on residential properties, which are less energy-intensive than office or retail assets, presents fewer opportunities to monetize the demand for green buildings. While the company has initiatives to adopt clean energy and to reduce emission of greenhouse gases, it lags industry peers in acquiring green building certifications. In FY 2021, only 9.5% of its portfolio (by number of properties) was certified vs. 28.5% industry average, as of May 2022.

Macronix's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. The development of memory devices entails reliance on a technically skilled workforce. Like leading peers, Macronix has broad-based professional development programs and clear channels of employee engagement--measures that may help retain talent. On corporate behavior, it has a strong business ethics framework with provisions for whistleblower protection and employee training on ethics. However, Macronix continues to trail global and home market peers on corporate governance.Semiconductor chip manufacturing is typically water intensive. Also, Macronix mainly operates in highly water-stressed regions of Taiwan; this could pose the risk of operational disruptions during water shortages. That said, like leading peers, Macronix has water risk assessment initiatives, including time-bound water reduction targets.Macronix's offerings in memory chips may provide some opportunities in industrial automation. However, its clean technology initiatives appear limited relative to those of its peers. Also, its three-year R&D/sales ratio (2019-21) of 10% trailed the industry average of 11%; this may indicate relatively low innovation capacity.Macronix's board lacks majority independence and is potentially entrenched: 10 of 14 directors have tenures of more than 15 years (as of August 2022); this may limit management oversight. Also, the lack of a fully independent audit committee in the presence of related-party transactions with senior executives may subordinate minority shareholder interests.

ESG_HEADLINE: Dissent votes and director overboarding indicates weakening in board structure
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Accton Technology's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. We note some weaknesses in the company's board structure that weigh on corporate governance. While the board has an independent majority, the presence of an executive chair (former CFO) may impede independent oversight. Further, lack of executive pay disclosures may impede comparison with global and home market peers. On the upside, we note improvements in the company's mineral tracing audit mechanisms and employee communication channels.Accton collaborated with suppliers to assess upstream refiners to trace potential use of conflict minerals in its products. While its FY 2020 survey of 312 suppliers as per Responsible Minerals Initiative's Conflict Minerals Reporting template received 100% response rate with no suppliers using conflict minerals, we found no information on mineral reduction targets.Accton competes for skilled talent to design open hardware for network solutions. To recruit and retain its qualified workforce, the company offers strong compensation and benefits package. However, unlike industry leaders, we did not find evidence of employee engagement initiatives to gauge employee morale.Accton supports innovation through R&D investments--3.93% during 2018-20 (vs. 10.5% industry average). Its network equipment finds application in solutions for smart home and Internet of Things. While this offers niche access to the rapidly evolving communication industry, Accton's cleantech initiatives remain on par with those of peers.

Bayer Cropscience's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. The company continues to trail most global peers on corporate governance. Bayer Cropscience's board lacks an independent majority, which could limit its ability to provide management oversight. Further, the presence of three executives (out of nine directors) on the board could potentially increase management influence on the board. Its business ethics practices are average relative to global peers. Meanwhile, Bayer Cropscience's carbon mitigation practices lead those of peers.As a producer of agricultural chemicals, Bayer Cropscience may face risks of reformulation costs. Its chemical safety programs include life cycle assessments of its products. However, it appears to lack plans to phase out potentially harmful substances. We note the company continues to face scrutiny over its production of neonicotinoids.The company's operations in India, a highly water-stressed region based on our model, indicates high exposure to risks of operational disruption in case of water shortage. Bayer Cropscience has industry-typical programs, such as water recycling. However, we found no disclosure on its water withdrawal data, which may impede peer comparison.Carbon regulations are less stringent in India than in the developed markets. Bayer Cropscience thus has lower exposure to risks of related compliance costs. Like leading peers, it has programs aimed at enhancing its operational energy efficiency. In 2022, it set a target to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions by 20% by 2024 (from a 2019 baseline).

ESG_HEADLINE: Improvement in talent management practices; weaknesses in data security measures
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Axis Bank's rating is unchanged at 'A'. Reliance on skilled professionals for operations may expose Axis Bank (Axis) to talent management challenges. We found evidence of measures such as annual engagement surveys and diversity initiatives to help retain talent. Also, the bank targets to increase women representation in its workforce to 30% by FY 2027 (FY2021: 23%). Though commercial loans constituted ~49% of its total portfolio (FY 2021), Axis lags peers in adopting sector-specific ESG policies and risk escalation practices.Axis leads most global peers on overall governance practices, owing to strong ethics policies. Evidence indicates a whistleblower protection program, which may help mitigate risks related to potential unethical conduct. While the bank has an independent audit committee, we note related-party transactions with promoters that may undermine minority shareholder interests.Axis leads industry peers on consumer protection practices. With retail loans constituting ~51% (FY 2021) of its total portfolio, the bank may face risk of mis-selling financial products. We found evidence of training for customer-facing employees on product safety and transparency; this may help protect consumer interests.Axis handles significant volumes of customer data as part of its retail loans business and may, thus, face privacy and data security risks in case of breaches. It lags industry peers in providing enhanced data control rights to customers and conducting regular audits of cybersecurity policies; practices that may help minimize risk of data breaches.

ESG_HEADLINE: Limited initiatives to mitigate ESG risks relative to peers
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Atul's rating is unchanged at 'CCC'. As a manufacturer of plastics and agricultural products, the company has a high environmental footprint. Yest, Atul continues to lag industry peers in adopting strong policies and programs to manage environment-related risks and opportunities. We note limited efforts to mitigate the risk of environmental liabilities associated with potential toxic emissions, relative to peers. Further, the company appears to lag leading peers in instituting strong water management initiatives.The water-intensive nature of plastics and synthetic materials production, along with operations in India--where water stress is high--exposes Atul to water-scarcity related risks. Yet, we found no information on its water withdrawal figures or quantitative targets to reduce water use; this impedes peer comparison.Typically, carbon-intensive operations expose Atul to compliance risks related to carbon regulations. However, unlike leading peers, the company appears to lack strong mitigation programs with quantitative targets to reduce emissions.The company's board is potentially entrenched: six directors were over 70 years of age, and six directors had served for more than 15 years (as of July 2022); this may limit its oversight capabilities. Meanwhile, Atul's business ethics framework has board-committee oversight and a whistleblower protection policy with a non-retaliation clause; these may help mitigate risks of unethical corporate conduct.

Blue Dart's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. We note continued efforts by Blue Dart to strengthen its carbon emission mitigation strategies. Notably, the company has inducted electric ground vehicles over FY 2021-22 and disclosed the use of cleaner fuels in its aircraft fleet, as part of its parent group's (Deutsche Post DHL's) carbon neutrality target for 2050. However, we found no disclosure on Blue Dart's fleet emission performance; this impedes assessment relative to peers. Also, we found improvements in its business ethics practices.The company has disclosed a policy that includes whistleblower protection from retaliation and compliance training for employees. Blue Dart's executive pay, and ownership and control practices are average relative to those of global peers. Yet, we note potential weaknesses in its board structure: the board lacks an independent majority and fully independent key committees. Such a structure may limit the board's ability to provide oversight of management and transactions with the controlling shareholder (75% of voting rights as of AGM 2022).Our model suggests air courier services are typically labor intensive and entail high exposure to labor-related risks. Further, the company operates in India, where our model indicates high frequency of labor unrest. Blue Dart's labor management is in line with those of peers. For instance, the company provides tuition subsidies and performance-based incentives and undertakes annual staff surveys to monitor workforce satisfaction--measures that may help mitigate risks of labor disputes.

ESG_HEADLINE: Robust corporate governance and consumer financial protection practices
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: CHOLAMANDALAM INVESTMENT AND FINANCE has been upgraded to 'A' from 'BBB'. The upgrade is largely driven by improvements in Cholamandalam Investment and Finance's (CIF's) initiatives for customer financial protection. Our reassessment found evidence of transparent lending policies, which may help safeguard customer interests. Further, consumer complaints decreased by ~30% YoY in FY 2021. Our research indicates CIF adopts certain industry-best practices of annual external audits and penetration testing; these may help preempt potential cybersecurity incidents.The company's corporate governance is average relative to global peers--the board has an independent majority. However, CIF is a controlled company: a single shareholder controls ~52% of voting power (FY 2022); this may pose risks for minority shareholder interests. The company lags global peers on business ethics practices. We note multiple tax controversies since 2019; this may indicate gaps in its internal control mechanisms.CIF relies on skilled staff to manage customer relationships. Yet, it lags industry peers in adopting robust employee management practices, such as talent development programs and grievance redressal mechanisms, which may support staff retention.CIF's performance on Access to Finance (ATF)--which focuses on efforts to expand financial services in underserved market segments--has improved since the last rating action. In FY 2021, the company launched a dedicated loans division to boost rural penetration in India. Please refer to the ESG Rating Drill Down and the dedicated ATF sections of the report for details.

ESG_HEADLINE: Corporate governance risks persist; lags peers in community engagement efforts
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: BCIA's rating is unchanged at 'BB'. BCIA continues to lag global and home market peers in corporate governance practices. The board lacks an independent director majority; this may strengthen the management's influence over the board and limit independent oversight. Further, the company's involvement in recurring related-party transactions with the Government of China (59% voting rights, as of August 2022), which reinforces control through board seats, may subordinate the interests of minority investors.Operating one of China's largest airports poses risks related to local opposition due to potential land-use conflicts or adverse impacts on community rights. Yet, we found limited disclosure on local community engagements or on social impact assessments to manage such risks.As a state-controlled entity, BCIA has high exposure to corruption risks, as per our model, particularly amid the Chinese government's anti-corruption drive. Like most state-owned firms, the company reinforces its anti-corruption policy with audits and ethics training for staff. However, we found no evidence of whistleblower protection.Airport operators, such as BCIA, have relatively low exposure to risks of operational disruptions tied to workplace incidents than peers engaged in port and cargo handling and rail track maintenance activities. BCIA's safety practices, which include audits and zero-incident targets, remain average relative to peers. Yet, we found limited disclosure on lost time injury rates; this impedes peer comparison.

ESG_HEADLINE: Business ethics controversies weigh on ESG Rating
IVA_RATING_ANALYSIS: Tencent's rating is unchanged at 'BBB'. Tencent faces several business ethics controversies that contribute to its current ESG Rating. These include allegations of having an indirect role in the infringement of civil liberties through the surveillance of Uyghurs and other ethnic minorities, in conjunction with Chinese government authorities. It also faces investigations by the People's Bank of China into alleged anti-money laundering violations. In 2022, it was fined USD 2.3 million over alleged violations of anti-monopoly laws.Prosus reduced its stake in Tencent to 28.8% voting rights, as of May 2022, which is below our controlling shareholder threshold (30%). However, its affiliated directors Mr. Koos Bekker and Mr. Charles Searle retained their board seats. Also, the company's VIE structure and entrenched board indicate that control remains concentrated with Mr. Huateng Ma.Tencent's diversifying global market presence may add to its talent management risks, especially relative to peers with leading talent diversity practices. We note strong practices by the company, relative to industry peers, on engagement initiatives. However, in December 2021, Riot Games (a US subsidiary) agreed to pay USD 100 million to settle a class action lawsuit over alleged gender discrimination.Tencent is on par with its industry peers in respect of data privacy management and has mitigated its risk by training its staff on cyber security and obtaining certifications for known information security frameworks, including ISO 27001.

Shenzhen Investment has been downgraded to 'BBB' from 'A'. A recent industry reassessment (as of June 2022) indicated a lower ESG performance score for Shenzhen Investment, relative to ESG industry peers, contributing to the downgrade. Also, while the company's green building practices are in line with those of peers, we note an increasing trend in its GHG intensity from 11 tCO2/USD million sales in FY 2018 to 23.5 in FY 2019 and 27.5 in FY 2020. We found limited disclosures on the proportion of total property portfolio with green certifications.Our model indicates property developers have high exposure to corruption risks due to factors such as reliance on construction permits. Further, the company's status as a Chinese state-owned entity may increase such exposure. Shenzhen Investment lags most global peers in adopting group-wide business ethics training and executive- or board-level oversight of ethics controls. We also note weaknesses, such as the lack of a majority independent board, in its corporate governance framework relative to peers.With property development constituting 56% of FY 2021 operations, Shenzhen Investment is exposed to risks of work-related injuries and fatalities. Like leading peers, the company has linked worksite safety performance to executive compensation and some of its subsidiaries are certified to ISO 45001 standards.Relative to peers, the company has strong initiatives such as inspection of construction material and quality of workm
